LENGTH: 2148 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
New Songs, Old Message: 'No War'

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES

 BODY:
SHERYL CROW didn't say a word about her opinion of war with Iraq when she had her prime-time moment performing with Kid Rock on the Grammy Awards two weeks ago. Her wardrobe spoke for her, with a big peace sign around her neck and a guitar strap that read "No War." It was a rare mass-media glimpse of something that people who lived through the 1960's had long been expecting: popular music taking an antiwar stand.
 There were reports -- quickly denied by both CBS and the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, the Grammy organization -- that musicians had been told not to make antiwar statements during the ceremonies. So of course some did. As presenters, Bonnie Raitt and Fred Durst (from Limp Bizkit) slipped extra words into their scripts, and India.Arie (getting her awards before the telecast) urged her fellow songwriters to address the war. 
 There is no war yet, only threats and preparations. But protest singers, like generals, revisit past battles, looking for parallels. Many are thinking about Vietnam; on March 1 at Joe's Pub in Manhattan, Pete Seeger and members of Sonic Youth were part of a concert drawing on "The Vietnam Songbook," published in 1969. They and the other songwriters denouncing war with Iraq are trying to speed up an artistic and political reaction that took years, not months, to gather momentum in the 1960's. And they want to abort a war, not rail against it. 
Has a protest song ever changed someone's mind? It's impossible to say. A precisely aimed topical song, like Bob Dylan's "Hurricane," can focus public attention on a specific cause. Conceivably John Lennon's "Give Peace a Chance" made some people think twice. But genuine, partisan protest songs usually reach people who already agree with them. Their job is less to persuade than to provide slogans and jingles to rally the converted and convince them that they're not alone. 
The new antiwar songs are virtually absent from commercial radio stations, where most programmers wouldn't dream of dividing or alienating their listenership. Instead, songs are arriving from various fringes -- on the collegiate indie-rock circuit, in hip-hop's activist wing and among the heirs to folky 1960's protesters. A handful of million-selling stars are beginning to join them. 
John Mellencamp has recorded an antiwar song, "From Washington," for his next album. "I don't think there's much chance of hearing this song on the radio," he said. "Guys like myself are not heavily on the playlists anymore, no matter what." 
System of a Down, which has always had a political streak in its hard rock, weighed in on its 2002 album, "Steal This Record," with bitterly skeptical songs like "Boom!" and "A.D.D. (American Dream Denial)." Chuck D of Public Enemy turned John Lee Hooker's "Boom Boom" into an antiwar stomp renamed "No Boom Boom." 
Other musicians are digging out old songs. George Michael remade Don McLean's bleak war story "The Grave" for a video that was broadcast last Monday on MTV Europe. Yo La Tengo recorded four versions of Sun Ra's "Nuclear War" as an EP, and in live shows Rosanne Cash has picked up Bob Dylan's 1983 song "License to Kill," while the English songwriter Paul Weller has been performing Marvin Gaye's "What's Going On."
Less than two weeks ago, a coalition of musicians as disparate as David Byrne, Jay-Z, Dave Matthews, Fugazi, Lucinda Williams, Lou Reed and Missy Elliott pooled their signatures as Musicians United to Win Without War (www.moveon.org), though new songs from them have yet to appear. An Australian group, Peace Not War (www.peace-not-war.org), has been quicker on the uptake; it has already released a compilation album including new and recent songs from English acts like Massive Attack, Chumbawamba and Ms. Dynamite along with Ani DiFranco and Public Enemy. 
The day may be long past when a song like Mr. Dylan's "Blowin' in the Wind" -- the all-purpose and seemingly timeless protest song that encompasses both war and civil rights -- could reach the Top 100 twice, sung by Peter, Paul and Mary in 1963 and by Stevie Wonder in 1966. Earnest, guitar-strumming disciples of the 1950's folk revival, which was the soundtrack to the civil-rights movement and then to anti-Vietnam War rallies, were able to squeeze into the Top 40 of the late 1950's and early 60's. Their music was part of a youthful movement. 
Even then, protests offered little commercial challenge to more lighthearted pop and rock. Soon afterward came the late-60's moment when the not yet formularized FM radio carried calls to revolution from the Jefferson Airplane and the MC5. Yet that moment was just a brief glimmer of anarchy before formats became entrenched and political songs were marginalized. 
Contrary to some memories of the Vietnam era, there was no unanimity among musicians or listeners. For every "Eve of Destruction" (by Barry McGuire) or "Fortunate Son" (Creedence Clearwater Revival), there was also "Ballad of the Green Berets" (Sgt. Barry Sadler) and "Okie From Muskogee" (Merle Haggard). Often, politically tinged songs like Marvin Gaye's "What's Going On" or Buffalo Springfield's "For What It's Worth" were laments and observations that stayed carefully nonpartisan.
The political pressures that created the 1960's protest-song movement have dissipated. There's no military draft to pull together a constituency and force life-or-death choices on every male teenager. And for the punk and hip-hop generation, there is no recent memory of a long, enervating war. Since Vietnam, the United States has waged only brief and overpowering military campaigns: wars that last days or weeks rather than years and that leave comparatively few American casualties. Most of the news coverage looks like fireworks and video games, not carnage. 
Music's modes of persuasion have also changed, from strum-and-sing to stomp-and-shout. Although there are still plenty of folky guitar-slingers who are writing topical songs -- including relative youngsters like Stephan Smith and Dan Bern -- it has been more than a generation since the coffeehouse singalong was close to the center of a pop mainstream. Now a song with a political message is more likely to reach a broad public if that message is slipped into a rhythm-and-blues or hip-hop song, eased along by a groove or blurted out over headbanging metal chords.
Much of the protest impulse has migrated into deliberately separatist styles of music that are content to reach fans alone. Politics moved into punk and metal, where it offered reasons for adolescent frustrations, and into underground hip-hop, where it has resurfaced periodically among rappers -- from Public Enemy to the Roots to Dead Prez -- who take seriously the idea of a songwriter as the conscience of the community. 
System of a Down's whiplash chords and sneering bursts of rhetoric, or Public Enemy's jagged funk and fractured lyrics, or Sleater-Kinney's indie-rock wail, would drive many folkies out of the room. It was difficult enough in the folky era to come up with a song everyone would join; now, after decades of niche marketing and microgenres, it's even harder. One current antiwar song, which has been growing by accretion as various contributors pass it along on the Internet, is the sarcastic "Bomb Iraq." It aims for singalongs by going back to kindergarten, borrowing the tune of the children's song "Clap Your Hands."
The ghost of Woody Guthrie still reigns over many recent protest songs. Mr. Mellencamp's "From Washington" is a rewrite of a Guthrie rewrite of a Carter Family song, while Mr. Bern uses Guthrie's talking-blues format to make uneasy jokes about terrorism. Billy Bragg's "Price of Oil" (which he made available immediately as a free download at www.billybragg.com) is straightforward fingerpicking folk-rock, as is Luka Bloom's "I Am Not at War," with a chorus that longs to become a shared anthem.
Mr. Dylan, Guthrie's most important heir, repudiated the hectoring of his own early protest songs in "My Back Pages," when he decided he had "become my enemy in the instant that I preach." And while that hasn't stopped Mr. Dylan himself from preaching on occasion, it has made later songwriters more wary of self-righteous sloganeering. 
"I like to ask questions," said Mia Doi Todd, a quietly thoughtful songwriter who released her first major-label album last year. "I don't neccessarily like to answer them for people, but I definitely like to make them turn around and question what they have taken for granted." Ms. Todd has lately been performing Joni Mitchell's antiwar song "The Fiddle and the Drum" and a new one of her own, "The Way," which mingles existential ruminations and lines like "We're junking bonds, we're dropping bombs we've made by guzzling gasoline." She has been playing "The Way" whenever she gets a chance to appear on radio broadcasts, generally noncommercial ones. "I wish it were on a single, right now," she said.
Few rock musicians expect antiwar songs to get mass exposure on radio stations that have been largely consolidated into two national networks, Clear Channel and Infinity. Yet that's unlikely to prevent songwriters from writing them. "If people are worried about losing their audience, they're not going to have their audience long anyway," Mr. Mellencamp said. "They don't sit around the studio saying, 'Are we going to offend anybody?' If they do, they should be programming radio." 
But Russell Simmons, the hip-hop mogul who corraled many rappers to join Musicians United, asserts that radio stations would not automatically reject an antiwar hip-hop song with commercial prospects. "I don't believe that there's any media that's controlling hip-hop," he said. "You throw a rap record out the window, no George Bush, nobody, can stop it if it's a hit. We don't need anybody, we never needed anybody to get our message out."
Still, the unstoppable mainstream antiwar hit has not yet been unveiled. The buildup toward war with Iraq has been short compared with the slow escalation in Vietnam; it was not until the late 1960's that rock seemed to align itself fully with antiwar sentiment. In 2003, the response to the Iraq buildup has been splintered. The craving for vengeance after Sept. 11, vented in songs like Toby Keith's "Courtesy of the Red White and Blue (The Angry American)," is still seeking a target. There also remains a chance that the Iraq buildup is brinkmanship that will accomplish its goal without warfare.
One thing is certain: a war, as opposed to the prospect of war, would quickly generate more antiwar music. "Their friends are going to die," Mr. Simmons said. "They're going to write these songs."

Deals and Discounts

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
 CHICAGO GETAWAY -- OffPeakTraveler.com, a Web discounter, has two-night packages to Chicago that include air fare and accommodations starting from $296 a person, based on double occupancy, from New York (less from some other cities). Flights are on American Trans Air, which lands at Midway Airport in Chicago, and the hotel is the Raphael in the Michigan Avenue shopping area. The price is good for Monday departures through June 2. Fees and taxes are extra. The deal resumes Sept. 8 through Dec. 15.

BERLIN BONUS -- Through April 30, the luxury Hotel Adlon in Berlin will offer four nights for the price of three. The total for two people sharing a room is $1,021 to $1,240 (at .95 euro to the dollar), depending on the room, with daily buffet breakfast. The 336-room hotel overlooks the Brandenburg Gate; (49-30) 2261-1111 or on the Web at www.hotel-adlon.de.

MATERNITY LEAVE -- Mothers and grandmothers aboard the American Orient Express's Pacific Coast Explorer trip that leaves Seattle on May 5 will get a 50 percent discount for Mother's Day. That brings the starting fare for the seven-night trip to $1,445. Those who share accommodations with them (they don't have to be offspring) will save $300, making their base rate $2,590. The train stops in the Napa Valley, San Francisco and near Hearst Castle before the trip ends in Los Angeles. There are on-board lecturers and historians. The base rate is based on Vintage Pullman accommodations, which include a toilet and sink, and upper and lower bunks; a shower room is shared. No baby pictures or other proof of motherhood is required; (800) 320-4206 or www.americanorientexpress.com.

MEDITERRANEAN CRUISE -- Fred Olsen Cruise Lines is taking 40 percent off the fare for a 22-day cruise on the 451-passenger Black Prince leaving Southampton, England, on April 5. Ports of call include Cartagena, Spain; several ports in Greece; Ceuta, Morocco; and Vigo, Portugal, before returning to Southampton. With the reduction, the fares start at $2,185 a person, double occupancy. Air fare is extra; port taxes are included. The ship has a marina with speedboats, water-skiing and wind surfing; (800) 843-0602 or at www.fredolsencruises.co.uk.

LONDON FOR LESS -- For those who can get away to London this month, 1800FlyEurope has a $207 round-trip fare from Boston or New York for departures through March 31. Taxes and security fees are extra. To add a three-day car rental, the total is $269 a person, based on two traveling together, for a manual-transmission economy car with unlimited mileage, V.A.T. and insurance. For those who don't drive on the left side of the road, a deal with three nights at the Kensington Close Hotel is $349 a person, double; (800) 359-3876 or www.1800flyeurope.com. JOSEPH SIANO

HEADLINE: Habitats/Ridgewood, N.J.; 
A New World House With an Old World Look

BYLINE:  By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
GARY AND TAMARA SEGAL were giving a tour of their newly expanded and renovated house when they were asked what seemed a simple question: How many bedrooms do they have?
 "Five," Mrs. Segal said. "No, six. Well, it depends on who counts." 
 And don't bother asking how many rooms they have in the house, because answering that is complicated too. In addition to three floors of living space, there are offices on the ground floor for his architectural practice -- a warren of rooms where young associates are hard at work. 
The Segals have been fixing up their house since they bought it more than a year ago, and it isn't finished yet, which is the way things go with architects, who are always busy on other people's places.
They moved from Oakland, N.J., to Ridgewood, N.J., in Bergen County, because they wanted to send their younger daughter, Thalia, to Ridgewood High School, which is highly regarded; their older daughter, Loreen, is a student at Cornell University. It was the first and only house they looked at.
A friend who was a broker took them to the house, which was being rented as a two-family home with a separate area as a doctor's office. They didn't actually like it, but they figured it had potential. "We saw nine-foot-high ceilings," Mrs. Segal said. "You don't find that a lot in houses here in New Jersey."
Besides, it made economic sense. "It was the right town for as high as we could even think to spend," Mr. Segal said. At $400,000, the house was a bargain for the neighborhood, where some homes sell for well over $1 million. They figured they couldn't go wrong if they fixed it up.
"It had been on the market for almost two years," Mrs. Segal said. "Nobody wanted it."
The Segals were also intrigued by the style of the exterior, which Mr. Segal said was uncommon in the New Jersey suburbs but typically found in Holland and Belgium. 
The concrete and wood-frame house, built around the turn of the 20th century, has a roof line with a stepping gable that is characteristic of the style. 
The Segals at first thought they would just do a face lift, but they eventually decided that the house had lost its grace when a porch was enclosed. Rather than tear off the enclosure, they added a new porch. They also moved the entrance to the ground-floor offices because the existing entrance, Mr. Segal said, "looked like a chicken coop."
The Segals also extended the back of the house, creating a breakfast area and a sun room. On the second story, where most of the bedrooms are, they pushed up into the attic space, giving one of the rooms a loft area. The rest of the attic was finished and turned into a bedroom suite for their younger daughter.
Although at first glance the house seems very different from the one they found, they have remained true to the original architectural style. They had considered just building whatever they wanted without regard to its history, but that didn't seem right. "If I had a ranch," Mr. Segal said, "I'd feel more comfortable to make my own rules. Many of the ranches built in the 1950's were one step better than a trailer home."
Inside, the room configurations were not drastically changed. But the kitchen and the bathrooms were redone, in different colors of marble. The master bath has an open shower with an arched window looking into the tub, in a green marble mosaic. "I dreamed about it," Mrs. Segal said. "I wanted this color, like grass."
The house has a European feel that Mr. Segal attributes partly to details like the coffered ceilings, and partly to the furniture and paintings, some of which they brought with them from Europe.
Mr. Segal, who was born in Romania, and Mrs. Segal, who was born in Hungary, met when they were studying architecture in Bucharest. Twenty years ago, they received visas to move to the United States, and they ended up in New Jersey because they had cousins in Englewood.
The Segals have a sense of humor about architectural history and the changes that every generation makes to its houses. "Maybe someone will come someday and say: 'What was in their minds? They thought this was Europe?' "
Some of the ornate details that give the house its richly layered feeling were achieved in surprising and often inexpensive ways. The front door was made of the usual particle board, but they cut out spaces and put in sculptured wood panels made in Indonesia and bought at Pier One. "It is consistent with the houses," he said, "because these houses had massive wood doors with sculptured panels or wrought-iron grills."
IN other cases, though, they stretched to create an authenticity that was important to them. The French doors between the living room and a small front parlor, for instance, have beveled glass. "When you grow up with beveled glass," he said, "you don't want to see doors without that."
The extensive use of stone contributes to the solid, Old World feeling. In the kitchen, Mrs. Segal, who once worked as an architect but is now retired, has been scratching at the sealant on the marble, trying to return the stone to its natural state, even if that means it stains. "The people who sold it to me think I'm crazy," she said. But that's the way she likes it. "You can feel the cracks," she said.
Not all the bedrooms are furnished yet. One has paintings resting against the walls, work done by their older daughter, including a self-portrait at age 13. "Probably we will let her have this as her studio," Mr. Segal said. The renovation of the house cost about $300,000, and the Segals said they could afford to do it only with substantial financial help from Mrs. Segal's father, who received reparations from Germany for the murders of his mother and sister in concentration camps.
From the attic bedroom of their younger daughter, the Segals can see across the street to the Village Hall and a large park. Their house is on a main street that historically has been home to doctors' offices. That created something of a problem when Mr. Segal wanted to change the doctor sign to an architect's sign.
He put his name in large letters outside, but the town made him remove the word "Architect," he said, because it wasn't an allowed sign in an area that can only have doctors' signs.
Mr. Segal wanted a sign, he said, because when one is placed at his office or on work sites, it brings inquiries from potential customers for his business, which handles both residential and commercial assignments. 
He figured there must be another approach. "Nobody tells you how to cut your grass or plant your bushes," he said. "I decided I will do something that doesn't have a law governing it."
So last spring, he bought dozens of big yellow mums and arranged them in his yard to spell out the word architect, a display that resulted in a story in the local newspaper on the beauty of mums. It also, he said, stopped traffic. 
"Every kick in the back," he said happily, "is a step ahead."

HEADLINE: Q. & A.; 
Noise Complaints in a Condominium

 BODY:
 Q. I live in a condo building of 20 units. For two years I have been seriously disturbed by noise from another unit. We have an owners' association, and our bylaws state that the board is to "govern the conduct of the unit owners." When we brought the noise problem to the board, the president said that she would not regulate issues between individual owners and that such issues had to be worked out by the owners involved. What should we do now? . . . Pamela Windo, Jersey City.

A. Donald M. Onorato, a lawyer in Hackensack, N.J., who specializes in co-op and condominium law, said that a condo association in New Jersey has a duty to provide a fair and efficient procedure for the resolution of housing-related disputes between individual unit owners and between unit owners and the association. "This procedure is commonly known as alternative dispute resolution," Mr. Onorato said, adding that having such a procedure is a requirement of the state's Condominium Act.
 "And while many times owners take these matters into their own hands by filing housing-related complaints in court, the association cannot evade its obligation to attempt to solve these disputes," he said. 
He said that many condo associations form a committee or hire an outside mediator, perhaps a retired judge or lawyer, to hear the dispute. 
"The statute does not provide that the association must resolve the dispute," he said. "But it must provide a procedure for doing so." If the procedure does not resolve the problem, Mr. Onorato said, it would be up to the unit owner to go to court.

Changing Names On a Deed

Q. When I bought my home in 1975, I included the woman I was living with on the deed. She moved out three years later, and for the last 24 years I have maintained the house and paid the mortgage. Now that mortgage rates are low, I would like to refinance. This seems an opportune time to have the deed changed to my name only. What are my legal rights if the change is contested? What are the other person's rights? Is she entitled to half the value of the house at the time she left or is she entitled to half the current value? . . . Michael Perkins, Glenford, N.Y.

A. Michael H. Sahn, a real estate lawyer in Garden City, N.Y., said that the writer should be able to get full title without having to pay anything to the other owner, provided the property is owned as a tenancy in common. (With a tenancy in common, Mr. Sahn said, each owner owns a specific share of the property -- often an equal share -- and each has an equal right to use the property.)
He said that under the state's Real Property Actions and Proceedings Law, provided the property is owned as a tenancy in common, a co-owner can get full title through a claim of adverse possession.
One way to make the claim is to show exclusive possession for 10 years after theother owner or owners have been "ousted" from the property. "Actual ouster usually requires the possessing co-owner to expressly communicate an intention to exclude or deny the rights of the non-possessory tenant to the property," Mr. Sahn said.
Without actual ouster, he said, the law allows a co-owner to assert a claim of adverse possession if the person asserting the claim has been in continuous, exclusive possession for 20 years or more. Mr. Sahn said that while the law gives the letter writer the right to acquire full title to the property by adverse possession, legal proceedings and a court judgment are necessary to do so.
The other way unmarried individuals can own property is as joint tenants with right of survivorship. With that form, each person has an identical ownership interest, and on the death of one, the survivor or survivors become the sole owners. In a joint tenancy, he said, a claim of adverse possession is not possible. But the writer can begin an action for partition, to sever the joint tenancy. If successful, this usually results in the sale of the property, with the proceeds split proportionately.

HEADLINE: THE STATE OF THEATER; 
Empty, and Expensive

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Wendy Wasserstein brought up some valid points in her remarks about the state of Broadway theater, but she missed one of the main reasons seats are empty today. 
It's not that audiences lack courage; it's the price of tickets in a faltering economy that keeps buyers away from the ticket window. 
 Look at the movies. Big crowds, big profits, a big year, and fear has played no part in it.

CHARLIE MAIER
Lincolnwood, Ill.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
With Prices Relatively Low, Co-ops Regain Favor

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
THREE years ago, Emelda Morrissey decided the time had come to own a home again. She had raised her family in a single-family house in Irvington and moved to an apartment in Dobbs Ferry after her 30-year marriage ended in divorce. And even though she was living in an attractive two-bedroom apartment in a well-maintained building, Ms. Morrissey said, she bristled whenever it came time to write the monthly rent check. Finally, after 10 years of paying rent, she purchased a co-op.
 Ellen Elfred, a teaching assistant in the Eastchester Public Schools, owned a three-bedroom house in Croton-on-Hudson. But last fall, when her son left for college, Ms. Elfred, a widow, realized she no longer wanted the responsibility of owning and maintaining a large home. She too decided to buy a co-op. 
 While the decisions were similar, the properties were not. Ms. Morrissey chose to buy in Bronxville and spent $249,000 three years ago for a two-bedroom, two-bath unit close to the center of the village, within walking distance of the quaint shops that line the main street and across the way from St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, where she is a parishioner. Currently, Ms. Morrissey's unit -- after a $30,000 investment in a new kitchen and other upgrades -- is estimated by real estate agents to be worth $425,000 to $450,000. "I may have lost money in the stock market," Ms. Morrissey said, "but my co-op has certainly increased in value."
By comparison, Ms. Elfred's two-bedroom, two-bath co-op with parking on Warburton Avenue in Yonkers, along a strip where many apartment buildings were converted to co-ops in the 1970's and 1980's, cost $105,000. The unit has spectacular Hudson River views, although it is not within easy walking distance to a village center. But as Ms. Elfred explained, "I don't mind getting in car to go to things, so I didn't need to pay a premium for proximity to shopping."
And, like other co-op owners, if she wants to take a vacation, Ms. Elfred enjoys the freedom to turn the lock to her front door and depart, without worrying about having the pipes burst or the basement flood, as she might if she owned a condo or a house.
After being somewhat out of favor in the early 1990's, real estate professionals say, co-ops are now a very popular option in Westchester -- mostly because they are a relatively affordable alternative to owning a house or a condominium in one of the most expensive areas of the country. The median sale price of a single-family house in the county as of the fourth quarter of 2002 was $520,000. There are fewer condos than co-ops, and the median price of a condo was more than two and a half times the median co-op price.
Patti Cunningham, an owner of Cunningham & Schneider Realty in White Plains, said co-ops are appealing to an increasingly broad range of people. Her co-op customers include empty-nesters, young professionals, couples just starting out and families -- "all of whom still want to be building some equity instead of paying rent month after month," she said.
In places like Bronxville, where the median price of a single-family home was $1.197 million in 2002 and the public school system is a major draw, co-ops are sometimes the only way a young family can afford to move there, said Sheila M. Stoltz, a saleswoman for Houlihan/Lawrence. "If you can't get into the home market," she said, "a co-op is a great alternative at an attractive price point." A two-bedroom unit in a good building in Bronxville would sell for about $390,000, she said.
Co-ops also appeal to buyers like Lou Marciano, a 40-year-old salesman for Ace Scaffolding, a construction company in Lodi, N.J., who owned a two-family house in Brooklyn but wanted to live in a more suburban setting. Mr. Marciano's decision was to sell the house in Brooklyn and purchase a studio apartment in Port Chester, "where I could still be close to the city and my work, but live a more relaxed life when I go home."
Because of uncertainty about the economy and about his future plans, Mr. Marciano, who is single, chose a studio as opposed to a larger unit. "For me right now, a studio seemed to be the smartest choice," he said. "I can still keep money available for other investments if the economy improves, and if I want to sell at some point or move elsewhere, I'm not bogged down with a huge commitment. I guess you could say that like many other people these days, I'm in a cautious frame of mind."
Co-ops have long been considered the ugly duckling of the Westchester real estate world because they have not appreciated as reliably and consistently as other types of housing. They "earned an unfair reputation back in the 1980's," when many of them lost value, Ms. Cunningham said.
CO-OPS today make up 24 percent of the county's housing units for sale, and they are selling well. Out of a total inventory of 3,700 ownership units (single-family and multifamily houses, as well as co-ops and condos) on the market at the end of 2002, 897 were co-ops.
The median sale price of a co-op in Westchester last year was $100,000, according to figures from the Westchester Putnam Multiple Listing Service, a subsidiary of the Westchester County Board of Realtors and the Putnam County Association of Realtors. That was a 20 percent above the price a year earlier and more than 50 percent above the figure as recently as 1999, $66,000.
Most of the co-ops in Westchester -- the 2000 census found 41,659 units -- were once rental apartments and are in buildings that were converted in the 1970's and 1980's.
P. Gilbert Mercurio, chief executive of the Board of Realtors, said a spate of co-op conversions occurred after the state enacted the Emergency Tenant Protection Act almost 30 years ago, which instituted rent controls and signaled to building owners that their profits would be be regulated. 
Many of the co-op sales during the wave of conversions were to insiders who saw an opportunity to buy units at a lower price and sell at a profit. "The intense speculative activity tended to inflate prices," Mr. Mercurio said. "Over all in the 80's, real estate was a hot investment. Sales volume and prices increased rapidly, especially in the co-op market."
Then in October of 1987, the stock market crashed, causing a sudden deflation in pricing nationally, with Westchester feeling the effects of the recession beginning in 1990. Many co-op owners suffered losses if they chose to sell during that period.
There were only 621 co-ops sold in the county in 1991, shortly after the market collapsed, compared with 1,680 sold last year, in a much stronger market. While prices were up sharply, the number of sales last year was almost identical to the figure in 2001. 
Ms. Cunningham noted that a two-bedroom, two-bath rental costs $1,500 a month or more in Westchester without utilities. A co-op apartment of about the same size, including a doorman, she said, can be found for $100,000 to $200,000, and it carries a monthly maintenance fee that includes some utilities, taxes and upkeep of the building. The mortgage payment for the co-op unit and the monthly maintenance fee are often less than rent, although purchasing requires a down payment, mortgage application fees and closing costs.
Unlike owners of condominiums, co-op owners do not own their apartments. They own shares in the corporation that holds the title to the building and the land. Co-op owners, however, can write off the interest on the mortgages for the building and the unit itself as well as real estate taxes.
With a co-op, the ownership corporation is responsible for upkeep on a building; with condos and homes, the individual owner is responsible.
Also, co-ops tend to cost less than condos. At $266,000, the median sale price of a condo was considerably higher than for a co-op. Dollar volume of co-op sales last year was $216.4 million, compared with $332.9 million for condos, of which 1,118 were sold. The volume for single-family homes was almost $3.81 billion. 
A drawback for co-ops in the opinion of many people is that a potential purchaser usually must be approved by the board that manages the building. Mr. Mercurio referred to the approval process as "an extra step and sometimes a complication." There is concern, he said, that some boards reject qualified buyers for illegal reasons, like race or marital status.
In an attempt to counteract such illegal practices, bills are pending at both the state and county level that would require co-op boards to provide a written explanation for a rejection within five days of turning down a buyer. Both bills seem to be languishing, however, Mr. Mercurio said.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
The Fears Are the Same, but the Strategies Vary

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE threat of war and the uncertain economic outlook are testing money managers across the board, making some take on new risks and others hedge their bets much more than usual.
 Katherine Schapiro, portfolio manager for international equities at Strong Capital Management, is struggling to improve performance in what she fears could be the fourth consecutive year of decline for world stock markets. Last year, the three international funds that she ran with Stacey Ho were down 20 percent, compared with a 15.9 percent decline in their benchmark, Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe, Australasia and Far East index, or EAFE; both figures include dividends. 
 The 2002 performance was attributable in part to the two managers' very conservative approach to their stock selection, shunning riskier and volatile market sectors, including telecoms, technology, media and financial services. Because of that strategy, the three Strong international funds did not do as well as the overall market during the fourth-quarter rally. They rose about 4.75 percent for the quarter, compared with a gainof 6.5 percent for the EAFE. (In an effort to reduce costs, the funds will become one -- under the Strong Overseas name -- at the end of this month.) 
Now Ms. Schapiro is picking up some riskier stocks on the expectation that they will quickly move higher when world equity markets revive. Among the additions from Europe are Telecom Italia; Intesa BCI, an Italian bank; and STMicroelectronics, the semiconductor company. From Japan, there is NTT, the telephone company.
Ms. Schapiro knows that she is taking on more risk, but she contends that she is getting some of these and other stocks at even lower prices than were available last fall.
"It is not about being bullish on the market," she said. "It's just that some better values are coming into play."
Ms. Schapiro said she was also focusing on some longer-term bets -- stocks that may not leap immediately when a new rally begins but have a good chance of doing better than the overall market over the next 12 to 18 months. One is Tesco P.L.C. the British-based food retailer whose stock is down 33 percent over the last 12 months.
William M. Fitzgerald, head of fixed-income investing at Nuveen Investments in Chicago, is seeking to minimize risk -- the risk of being wrong on the direction of interest rates. He is trying to walk a path between the possibility of rates staying near current levels -- close to four-decade lows -- or jumping about half a percentage point, a big move in the current environment.
He expects the jump in rates if the United States wins a quick victory in a war with Iraq and can resolve its current disagreements with France, Germany and Russia. But rates will climb just a bit, if at all, he predicts, if a war lasts longer than expected and if the disagreements persist. The threat of retaliation from terrorists because of a war could also keep uncertainty high and interest rates low, he said.
TO prepare for either of these outcomes, Mr. Fitzgerald is concentrating Nuveen's municipal bond funds on maturities of 10 years to 15 years, avoiding bonds with shorter or longer maturities.
If interest rates rise, short-term maturities will be the best bet because their prices will fall the least. But their yields are so low that if interest rates do not rise, the return for Nuveen's funds will be too low, Mr. Fitzgerald said.
If interest rates stay about the same, bonds with 20 years to 30 years until maturity will bring the best return because their yields are higher. But because these longer-term bonds will also produce the biggest price losses if rates do rise, they are too risky for Nuveen's midstream strategy.
Ten- to 15-year securities provide a good-enough yield if rates are stable and more modest price depreciation if rates do climb.
Neither Ms. Schapiro's nor Mr. Fitzgerald's approach is the preferred strategy; each is a compromise. And both are a reminder that this is a difficult year for managers of both stocks and bonds, who now have fewer havens from war and uncertainty.

PERSON: David F. D'Alessandro 

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR; 
Bold Enough for Hancock Himself

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
IF the rules were changed to favor David F. D'Alessandro, the next Winter Games would include a biathlon of business and marksmanship. That is how precisely the chief executive of John Hancock Financial Services has taken aim against the United States Olympic Committee in recent months.
 Mr. D'Alessandro has long been an outspoken critic of the International Olympic Committee, as in 1999 when he fought to clean up the I.O.C. after the Salt Lake City bribery scandal. 
 His most recent complaint is that the American committee hasn't told him how much money in its budget actually goes to the athletes. It led to his threatening to cancel about $50 million of worldwide sponsorship that Hancock has promised for each four-year Olympic cycle if the committee does not allow a third-party audit. He testified before Congress on the matter, and in newspaper interviews likened the committee's accounting methods to a shell game.
His campaign has helped to accelerate change. The U.S.O.C.'s chief executive, Lloyd Ward, resigned on March 1, the day that Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said information that he had gathered while investigating the committee suggested possible criminal activity. The U.S.O.C.'s chief operating officer, Fred Wohlschlaeger, quit on Monday.
It seems an unusual and time-consuming crusade for a chief executive with no particular athletic aspirations. Then again, there is little usual about Mr. D'Alessandro, who came to Hancock in 1984 as its senior public relations executive and became chief executive in 2000. He was 49 then, the youngest chief executive in the company's 140-year history.
He arrived cheerful for a recent meeting at his office on the 59th floor of the John Hancock Tower, despite spending the morning pumping water from the basement of his home west of Boston and borrowing a contractor's unheated van when none of his handful of cars would start.
Settling with a cup of coffee into a butter-cream leather chair, he played down the energy he has expended on the U.S.O.C. "They are so incredibly inept it doesn't take a great deal of effort, actually," he said. He said he first became seriously concerned about the committee after he asked for information while he was on vacation in January.
"I expected I would get a pretty precise, easy response," he said. "Instead, it was like Armageddon: 'Why do you want to know?' and 'We don't know' and 'That's confidential.' It was kind of like, 'Oh, so it's that bad, is it?' "
Mr. D'Alessandro, who has a 4-year-old son with his second wife and two grown children from his first marriage, was on another vacation when he decided to write an op-ed page article for The Boston Globe about how the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston was handling the issue of child molesting by priests. He was one of the first business leaders to call for Cardinal Bernard F. Law to step down.
He was also one of the first to side with a janitors' union when thousands of people who clean Boston's office buildings, including his own building, went on strike last fall. He criticized the developers who were resisting raises in pay and health care to the workers, many of them immigrants.
He said many of the developers were themselves "the sons and daughters or grandsons and granddaughters of immigrants," invoking the memory of his grandfather, an Italian immigrant, who owned a small grocery store in Utica, N.Y. "And now they're saying, 'We've got ours; you can't have yours.' "
Mr. D'Alessandro's public relations experience is deep. He graduated from Utica College, then part of Syracuse University, with a degree in journalism and public relations in 1972. He worked for two New York advertising agencies and held various marketing jobs, designing campaigns for clients as varied as the National Bowling Council and Citibank.
More interesting is how Mr. D'Alessandro, who has never taken a business course, has become John Hancock's chief strategist. Three years after revamping the company's advertising and sponsorships as vice president for corporate communications, he was invited to take over the group life and health division. He later ran Hancock's retail division before becoming president in 1998 and chief executive two years later.
He acknowledges that the job leaves little time for dealing with things like the U.S.O.C., but he cuts out other distractions, like serving on the boards of other companies.
Keeping Hancock profitable has been difficult in the current economy, he says. But having taken the company through an initial public offering three years ago, he has many analysts on his side.
"He is clear on what he expects the company to be able to accomplish and communicates that on a regular basis," said Elizabeth Malone, who follows the insurance industry as a managing director for the Advest Group.
He certainly does not dress up what John Hancock does: sell insurance and make investments.
With his iconoclastic sense of humor, he plays down his management skills. "This business is not complicated; it's about bookmaking and loan-sharking," he said. He also likes to use a casino analogy. "We're the house," he said. "People are going to stay at the table long enough for us to collect money off them."
It's more than a streetwise comparison. His father, he says, was a compulsive gambler whose debts to loan sharks lost the family its store; David was in college at the time. "My dad was brilliant," he said. "He was crazy, but he was brilliant."
While claiming to be no genius himself, he said his natural curiosity has served him well.
"You have lots of experts around you, certainly, but they're more numbers-oriented versus strategic-oriented," he said. He said he recently spent 10 hours researching planes on the Web because Hancock invests in that industry.
HIS office overflows with autographs from people like Lincoln and Napoleon and trinkets once owned by celebrities like John Lennon and Marilyn Monroe, vestiges of a memorabilia store he owned briefly in Baltimore. But lest anyone confuse his nostalgia for sentimentality, Mr. D'Alessandro blinks back no tears when saying that the sale of the John Hancock Tower, the tallest building in Boston at 62 stories, is under way. ("The building is simply capital," he said.) Nor does he fret that John Hancock itself, if the economy recovers, may be a prime target for merger or acquisition. ("Hanging on to the job does not drive me," he said. "I'll find something else to do in life.")
Despite his affection for the Olympics, he is willing to drop the whole relationship if it threatens to sully John Hancock's name. "They're in a box because they either do the audit or we come out and say they refuse to," he said. At that point, he added, "they may was well just find a wall and a blindfold."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Bear Market May Be On Its Last Legs

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
MARCH 10, 2000. For many investors, it was the day the music died.
 Three years ago tomorrow, the Nasdaq composite index peaked at 5,048.62. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index did not stop rising until two weeks later, but investors look back on that Nasdaq peak as a turning point, the end of a decade-long run. 
 Steven C. Leuthold, the chairman of Leuthold Weeden Capital Management in Minneapolis, has dealt with bull and bear markets for more than four decades. Last week, he discussed his view of the future. Following are excerpts from the conversation: 

Q. Investors have turned away from technology stocks. Are they right?

A. We believe technology is the way to make money now. About 25 percent of our money is in tech stocks. Three years ago, we had zero. One of the things that has happened in the intervening period is that analysts, who have been beaten up so badly for so long, may be underestimating earnings growth.
Cuts in expenses and costs have been so dramatic that a little bit of revenue growth may translate into much bigger profits than analysts can currently see. 
At a time like this, when some of these stocks have been beaten down so badly, I think if you are patient you can make six or seven times your money. 

Q. Are stocks cheap?

A. At a level of 840, the Standard & Poor's 500 index is exactly at its median multiple from 1957 to date. That's not particularly cheap but it's not expensive, either. Three-quarters of all bear markets have stopped at median valuation levels.

Q. Is this bear market over?

A. I think so. We are going through a testing process. But if we can't make new lows with all the bad stuff that has happened so far this year, it implies to me we have a pretty solid base. If we do go to war with Iraq, the odds are that it will be over very, very quickly.

Q. What other segments do you like?

A. We have a 12 percent holding in what we call diversified metals and mining -- copper stocks and other diversified mining companies like Inco.
We really do see a pickup in industrial commodity inflation, and these companies will benefit from that. Inventories are relatively low, and prices are rising. 
And we have a double market weight in health care stocks. But we are not buying any of the big drug companies yet. 
Of that, we took a new 6 percent position in biotechnology stocks. The rest is in health care/cost containment, including a lot of generic drug companies and companies that provide outpatient treatment. 
In the cost containment area, we own Omnicare, Diagnostic Products and OraSure Technologies. Our generic drug holdings include Barr Laboratories, Teva, the Israeli company, and Sicor. 

Q. Which technology stocks do you like?

A. Stocks like Cisco Systems and Qualcomm, as well as some of the old regional Bell companies, like SBC Communications. We own Avocent, which is in networking equipment. We just bought F5 Networks, which is also in the networking area. One stock that is a sleeper but is also a bit riskier is Foundry Networks. We also own stocks in the office electronics area, Xerox and Canon.

Q. Which groups of stocks are you avoiding?

A. We have nothing in financials. We look at 12 subsets of financial stocks, and not a single one is ranked attractive. People are overenthusiastic about financials; they now represent 21 percent of the S.& P. 500.
It has been our experience that when you get these big overweight parts of the market, like energy was in the 1980's and technology was in the 1990's, ultimately the market tends to correct. We don't have anything in utilities or transportation, either. But eventually some people will make big money in the airlines. It is a critical area, and people won't allow them to go out of business. 

Q. Do bonds have any appeal?

A. We have nearly doubled our exposure to junk bonds over the last year. And yields on municipal bonds are the same as on governments of the same maturity. That is the first time that has happened since 1975-1976. That encourages me to do a spread trade and go long munis and short Treasuries. It's an attractive trading opportunity.

Q. What lessons can we draw from what's happened over the last three years?

A. What we had before, that was the biggest bubble we have ever seen. Peak to trough, the S.& P. 500 is down almost 50 percent.
I think you have wiped out the public as a serious investor for maybe 10 years. Equities were 70 percent to 75 percent of the typical 401(k). I would guess that will fall to 40 percent to 50 percent. I think that is probably appropriate, but the public will probably miss out by doing that.

HEADLINE: Color Them Green (or Greedy) 

BYLINE:  By JIM MOTAVALLI

 BODY:
A LOT of publications marshal facts and figures to influence car-buying decisions. The latest, 2003 edition of "ACEEE's Green Book" is no exception, though it doesn't provide the usual fodder of top speeds or zero-to-60 acceleration times.
 Rather, the publication offers lesser-known measures like the "environmental damage index" of a car, plus estimates of the health care costs to society from the pollution produced by a particular model. The Green Book ispublished by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, an environmental group in Washington. 
 The Green Book also ranks cars by environmental standards. "The mantra of our book is to encourage consumers to buy the greenest vehicle that fits their needs and their budget," said James Kleisch, the co-author (with John DeCicco). "We don't say, 'Stay away from pickup trucks.' We say that if you're going to buy a pickup, here's the greenest one on the market."
The Environmental Protection Agency ranks vehicles based on fuel economy and emissions, too, but the Green Book assigns a "green score" that includes a life-cycle assessment, taking into account factors like how much energy is used to build a particular model.
The book includes lists of the greenest and meanest 2003 models. The highest green score -- 57 -- goes to a two-seat hybrid gas-electric car, the Honda Insight. The exotic $675,000 Ferrari Enzo ranks lowest, with a score of 9. But the group noted that cars like the Enzo are so rare that they do far less harm to the environment than big trucks.
A third list, called Greener Choices, picks what the group considers the best vehicles in categories from compact cars to sport utilities. The vehicles on this list tend to be models that consumers shun, like a four-cylinder version of the Ford Ranger pickup.
The rankings can be confusing, as several of the greenest vehicles are California-only editions that receive higher green scores than their counterparts on the Greener Choices list. The Toyota Prius is the same from coast to coast, but it is classified as a super-ultra-low-emission vehicle in California, where low-sulfur gasoline is sold, and as an ultra-low-emission vehicle elsewhere.
Highlights of the rankings are on line at www.greenercars.org. The E.P.A.'s list is at www.epa.gov/greenvehicles.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Putting Banks in Touch With Their Retailer Side

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn. 

 BODY:
FOR a glimpse into the future of banking, Robert H. Steele turns not to predictions of economic growth, but to a household paintbrush.
 "Home Depot is wrapping this paintbrush into a great customer experience," said Mr. Steele, the director of the Merlin Center, an idea laboratory and design showroom here that advises banks on how their branches should look, work and even smell. 
 Just as Home Depot offers wallpaper, how-to seminars and free remodeling advice as well as hardware, he said banks, too, need to think of themselves as retailers of a variety of products and services. "Look, this paint roller is not that different from a mortgage," Mr. Steele said. 
Since opening in 1995, the Merlin Center has sought to be a crystal ball for bankers grappling with their industry's big shifts over the last 15 years, including deregulation and mergers and acquisitions, the rise of the Internet and the growth of investing for the masses.
Its idea is to help banks survive and grow by becoming modern retailers. Its method is to build mock-ups of entire bank branches in its warehouselike showroom to give retail bank executives an idea of how their future might look.
"These are ideas," Mr. Steele said. "We would never be so bold as to say we know the future."
Merlin's crystal ball has sometimes seemed clouded. The center, named for the magician of medieval legend, has already undergone two multimillion-dollar remodelings that suggest it was a step behind, not ahead of, trends.
The first revamping, in 1998, underscored Internet banking -- at the height of the Internet craze. But Internet banking has not caught on. The second revamping, in 2000, emphasized the need for banks to become "open financial networks" selling other companies' financial products and services. Mr. Steele, 64, said that idea was not strategically appropriate for every bank.
Now on the drawing board, for unveiling by September, is a third remodeling, at $3 million, that will emphasize what the banking industry has spent the last year rediscovering: the importance of branches. Merlin is suggesting that some banks even equip some branches with small-business services like videoconferencing rooms; tax, copyright and other legal services; and a networking coffee bar.
The Merlin Center is part of the John Ryan Company, a privately owned financial-services merchandising firm that is based in Minneapolis and has offices in London and Madrid.
John Ryan made its name in the 1980's by designing in-store displays, brochures and promotional materials for specialty retailers like Swiss Colony, the mail-order cheese company.
Last year, nearly all of John Ryan's $50 million in revenue was from banks, said Mr. Steele, whois also vice chairman of John Ryan. He declined to disclose the company's profit. 
Mr. Steele, a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, congressman from Connecticut and bank executive, also declined to discuss Merlin's current or past clients in detail, citing client confidentiality and a need to keep proprietary information from rivals, like Willey Brothers, a financial merchandising firm in Rochester, N.H.
Some banks, like Washington Mutual and Wells Fargo, have their own design departments.
Like a Parisian couturier's outlandish creations, which draw cheers on the runways but are toned down for the stores, the Merlin Center's boldest ideas tend to be praised by bankers, but used sparingly.
The Fleet Financial Group, for example, used Merlin's one-stop-shopping idea to integrate its banking, Quick & Reilly brokerage service, mortgage and other services in 5 of its 1,500 branches in the late 1990's. The moves helped Fleet more than double the number of financial products sold to customers at the branches, said Kevin C. Barrett, a Fleet vice president for global services and cash management who worked in the bank's retail unit at the time.
MERLIN did similar projects for institutions ranging from Bank of America, which has the most branches of any bank in the country, to Centura Bank, which operates 250 branches from its headquarters in Rocky Mount, N.C.
Merlin has 25 clients, 20 of them overseas, including Deutsche Bank, Abbey National of Britain and Banco Portugues do Atlantico, Mr. Steele said. Most spend $1 million, on average, he said.
While many bankers praise the Merlin Center's inventiveness, some say its vision is a tough sell amid a weak economy. To remodel just one branch with all the technology featured in Merlin's showcase branch -- including plasma screens to display price and rate information, and "Get Smart"-style soundproof cones that permit private conversations in public spaces -- costs at least $250,000. The center does not sell furnishings or technology.
"Merlin can overwhelm people," said Bruce Wheeler, who is in charge of Fleet's New Jersey operations. "It's very innovative, but there's an awful lot to digest, and you have to pick and choose what to incorporate."
No banks, for example, adopted an earlier Merlin idea to flood branches with the scent of freshly baked cookies. The center has also scrapped the idea of posting interest rates on electronic displays like those used to announce flight departures and arrivals in airports. And it no longer recommends that banks produce television programs to pitch products to customers waiting in line.
More strikingly, Mr. Steele forecasts that the emphasis on one-stop shopping will disappear. "The mistake is in thinking that you can get the customer to do all of his shopping there," he said. "You just want him to do more of his shopping there."

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
The Ascent of the Software Civilization

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
TECHNOLOGY euphoria was in the air and stock prices were stratospheric. The shares of some software and computer services companies jumped a hundredfold in a few years. "Never before has the stock market shown quite so much enthusiasm about an industry," a writer for Fortune magazine observed.
 The year was 1968. 
 History may provide no sure guide to the future, but it does offer context and insight for the present. And, given the proper twist, history glimmers with a certain knowing humor. In his incisive, panoramic book, "From Airline Reservations to Sonic the Hedgehog: A History of the Software Industry" (MIT Press, $29.95), Martin Campbell-Kelly delivers all three -- context, insight, even occasional humor. His treatment of the similarity in the computer mania of the late 1960's and the Internet bubble of the late 1990's is one many telling observations.
Mr. Campbell-Kelly's book is not for everyone. He is an instructor in computer science at the University of Warwick in England and is a professional historian. His is not a book of insider gossip or of recreated scenes of clashing egos and executive tirades -- the stuff of so many business books. Instead, it is the product of his reading and distilling of books, professional journals, magazine and newspaper articles and historical archives over the last four decades.
The result is a sweeping survey of the software business since the early 1950's, its evolving structure, economics and marketing. The product and company names are so numerous that, at times, they seem to race by in a blur -- Cincom, Cullinane, Panosophic, Cytation, Famicom, Xenix, Comshare, Syncsort, SuperWriter, MacNeal-Schwendler and hundreds more. The book is a ready reference for any misguided soul who wants to create a computer trivia game.
Yet, along the way, Mr. Campbell-Kelly pauses for longer passages on subjects ranging from the role of the government's SAGE air defense-and-surveillance system to the decision by I.B.M. in 1969 to "unbundle" hardware and software sales. The unbundling was "a turning point," the author says, because it ensured a sizable software industry separate from hardware.
Mr. Campbell-Kelly gives the United States government credit for creating a market for programmers in the 1950's and early 1960's with SAGE, a name derived from "semiautomatic ground environment." About $150 million was spent on its software, and thousands of programmers were trained to work on the project -- a veritable "university for programmers." Its alumni went off to populate corporate data centers and to start companies elsewhere. SAGE also tackled a host of technical problems in real-time transaction processing that eased the way for I.B.M.'s development of the Sabre online reservations system, called "the Kid's SAGE," for American Airlines.
Time and again, the book shows that what seems new in the software industry in fact echoes the past. The engineers who used software formed user groups starting in the 1950's with SHARE, whose members came from companies that used I.B.M. 704 computers. The group's name, though capitalized, was not an acronym. It was what the group did; it shared programs and expertise to help drive down programming costs.
This was when software was treated as a marketing cost of hardware instead of as a stand-alone product. But, as the author writes, "one of the abiding legacies of the user groups was the perception of software as a free good." In their attitude and behavior, the user groups were very similar to those engaged in today's open-source software projects like GNU Linux, an operating system that is distributed free and is steadily improved and debugged by a network of programmers.
IN the late 1960's and early 70's, there was great excitement about -- and investment in -- the notion of computing as a utility-like service that could be delivered to offices and homes to solve all manner of problems. The idea flopped because it proved to be too complex a challenge to write the software needed to distribute computing as a service from a central time-shared machine to many users. Besides, microcomputers, later called personal computers, were about to arrive, putting affordable computing on desktops thanks to the miracle of the microprocessor.
Today, the utility concept is making a comeback. This time, the industry is betting that 30 years of advances in software, hardware and networking can deliver utility computing. I.B.M. is promoting "on demand" computing, and Hewlett-Packard, Sun Microsystems and others have similar offerings. Companies like Salesforce.com are offering software as a service in an emerging market for so-called application service providers, or A.S.P.'s. "Because the concept was never fully tested in the 1970's," Mr. Campbell-Kelly writes, "history has few lessons to offer the A.S.P. industry." Well, the A.S.P. start-ups certainly hope so.
As software became a product in its own right, marketing became more important. In the fledgling personal computer industry, some of the tactics were particularly inventive. In 1980, George Tate, a former electronics industry salesman, began marketing a database program he named dBase II. There was no "I," but "II" suggested a second, improved product. This ploy was not uncommon. But in 1983, Mr. Tate took the more imaginative leap, renaming his company Ashton-Tate.
"There was no Ashton," the author writes, "but it was considered a euphonious and high-sounding name."
Mr. Campbell-Kelly argues convincingly that Microsoft's stature in the software industry as a whole tends to be overstated. After all, he notes, Microsoft dominates only about 10 percent of the industry, while it has no such sway over large portions of the software business like corporate software, software contractors and consultants.
"If this book serves no other purpose," he writes, "I hope it will serve as a corrective to the common misconception that Microsoft is the center of the software universe around which all else revolves."
Mr. Campbell-Kelly is dismissive of the federal antitrust suit filed in 1998. "Exactly why the action was brought remains a mystery," he writes. He is fastidious with footnotes, but there are none near that sentence. It's his opinion, period.
He may not understand the Microsoft antitrust suit, but he lucidly analyzes Microsoft's mastery of using software and business acumen to build a lucrative technology platform. In Microsoft's case, of course, the technology platform is the Windows operating system. The company encouraged and helped software developers write programs that run on the Microsoft platform, increasing the value of Windows and prompting even more applications to be written on top of Windows. Economists call this commercial snowball "network effects."
It is nothing new, really. I.B.M., as Mr. Campbell-Kelly explains, did the same thing with its operating system for the I.B.M. 360 mainframe and follow-on products.
And Sony, in video game consoles, deftly used software to build its technology platform and a thriving ecosystem of game developers supporting its PlayStation platform. Once Sony mastered the economics of software, Sega's Sonic the Hedgehog never had a chance.

HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY WITH: TIKI AND RONDE BARBER; 
Atop Their Game, Ahead of the Market

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
IT was 1996, long before Ronde and Tiki Barber had become high-octane National Football League stars whose success and style would usher them into the glamorous worlds of money and media.
 The brothers -- identical twins -- were still seniors at the University of Virginia. They had not even hired an agent to negotiate the contracts that would soon make Ronde the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' star cornerback and Tiki the star running back for the New York Giants. Super Bowl XXXVII, in which Ronde's dazzling defensive plays helped lead the Buccaneers to victory, wasn't even a glimmer. 
 Yet the young men, who needed scholarships for college, hired a financial adviser to help them prepare for the riches they are now reaping. 
"I had my financial adviser before I had any other adviser," recalled Tiki Barber, the soft-spoken one who takes more interest in their investments. "I hate to be critical of my peers, but I think a lot of them just let their football agents handle their money as well." 
Through a friend, the Barbers and their mother, Geraldine, met Charles Banks, a partner at CSI Investments, which handles the assets of celebrities like the singer Alanis Morissette and the basketball player Kevin Garnett. Within days, the brothers had engaged Mr. Banks.
The Barber twins, now 27, have strong views about money -- and much to gain, or lose, from the management of it. In 2001, Tiki Barber signed a $25.5 million six-year deal with the Giants with a $7 million guarantee up front. That same year, Ronde Barber signed an $18.5 million six-year deal with the Buccaneers with a $2.5 million guarantee.
"It is counterintuitive to let an agent hire a financial manager," Tiki said during a lengthy interview at the Manhattan cooperative he shares with his wife, Ginny; their 7-month-old son, Atiim Kiambu; and Ginny's parents. Dressed in slacks and a black T-shirt and stretched out on the living room sofa with his son on his knee, he continued: "If the guy messes up, he is not going to tell you. He is going to tell your agent, so you have no checks and balances. I wanted to be sure I had a football guy, a marketing guy and a money guy -- three different people."
The Barber twins seem to have inherited their financial sense: their mother, now 50, graduated from Virginia Tech with a degree in business. She divorced their father when they were 4 and supported them by working 12-hour days doing a wide variety of jobs. "She is our mentor," Tiki said. "When we went off to college, she went back and got her M.B.A. with straight A's."
That made things easier for Mr. Banks, who has managed their money, in separate accounts, ever since. With the stock market so depressed, the twins now have about 65 percent of their money in bonds and cash, about 25 percent in stocks and the balance in private equity and real estate. Their portfolios, which are generally the same, have averaged a gain of about 3.5 percent a year the last four years -- a period when the stock market had one year of big gains and three years of declines. Their return included a tiny gain of about 1 percent last year. 
Mr. Banks recalled his first meeting with the twins, which took place over drinks at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Washington. "Their biggest concern was paying for the draft, because that costs money," he said. Many players, for example, hire trainers and nutritionists to improve their performance, thus raising their profiles for the N.F.L. draft.
"A lot of agents lend the players money," Mr. Banks said. "The kids borrow too much. They spend too much. They think they're Bill Gates, but they don't have the money to live like that."
To Mr. Banks, the Barbers were unusual clients. "They understood it was a once-in-a-lifetime chance, and they weren't going to squander the money on jewelry or buying friends first-class tickets," he said. 
Ronde Barber confirms the feeling. "We were both commerce majors, so we knew what he was talking about," he said in an interview. "We wanted to get the financial stuff out of the way first."
Football players are vulnerable to financial problems because of the nature of their contracts. If a team decides to cut a player, he loses his salary for the remaining years; the salaries of basketball and baseball players are guaranteed, even if they are cut from their teams.
"Mr. Banks is always saying, 'Keep your eye on the big numbers -- $10 million,' " Tiki said. "If you have that and you don't want to work a day in your life, you can do it." 
Mr. Banks has also encouraged the Barbers to live off the income from their work off the field. "Tiki doesn't touch his Paragraph 5 money," said Ronde, referring to the section in football contracts that states the size of the annual salary. "I'm getting there."
Tiki has so far accumulated about $7 million, while Ronde has about $3 million. That's because Tiki's contract is larger and he makes more commercials and corporate appearances, meeting with employees or customers for companies like Footlocker. He was also the sports anchor on "CBS 2 News This Morning" in New York from 1999 to 2001. 
Because Tampa is a smaller market, Ronde, who has his home there, has drawn less attention. But the Super Bowl victory is closing the gap. Demand has grown recently for Ronde from companies like Reebok, for which he is shooting a print advertisement, and Anheuser-Busch, where he recently made an appearance before employees.
A commercial for Visa cards featuring the twins, first broadcast last October, has underscored their marketing appeal. "The commercial is huge," Tiki said. "Half the people looked at it, and they didn't even know I am a twin." 
The brothers, who grew up in Roanoke, Va., and shared a room until their junior year in college, are quietly competitive about their accomplishments. "I still make more money than him," Tiki said of Ronde. "But he has the Super Bowl, and I don't. So what do you want -- the money or the Super Bowl?"
Tiki covets both, of course. "I don't want them to say, 'He was a great guy, but he didn't win a championship,' " he said. "That is what the focus is now: winning a championship."
Ronde, smiling broadly at the thought, knows that his victory is killing his brother. "Isn't it though?" he says. "He's got to deal with it.
"It is the ultimate success, but in the long run, it is just a game," he added, noting that the championship had not changed their relationship.
The competition goes the other way, too. Last year, it seemed to Ronde, who often talks by phone with his brother, that "Tiki was doing something every day; I would call, and he was always going here and there."
So Ronde, who married two years ago and is expecting a second child, hired Mark Lepselter, whose firm, Maxximum Marketing, was already working for his brother. 
The twins differ a bit in style. Ronde, for example, recalled the day he flipped on CNN to see his twin on the floor of the American Stock Exchange, talking about Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. "It was something about interest rates and what you might want to do with your money," he remembered.
When Ronde was filmed at the exchange, he said, "it was an appearance; they didn't ask me for any financial advice." 
Still, the two are clearly focused on accumulating capital. When they went pro, they set up a conservative line of credit with banks for the draft, rather than borrowing money from a football agent. 
"They didn't want to go out there and get hammered in practice and not have any money at the end of the day," Mr. Banks said.
Although Ronde can seem the more laid back of the two, their football agent, Ethan Lock, said he had always remembered Ronde's reaction when he was going into his fourth N.F.L. year. After the third year, the Buccaneers had the right to offer Ronde a one-year contract at a fixed price. "I said to Ronde: 'Should I push for a long-term deal?' " Mr. Lock recalled asking.
Ronde could have turned it down and negotiated a long-term contract at that point, but he would have received less than the $18.5 million he ultimately got. Ronde said: "No, I would rather wait. I am not going to take something that is below my value. I can do a lot of other things. If I don't play football, I am going to be successful anyway."
Tiki, too, has a long-term view. "Football is awesome because I think I raised the average starting salary in my business class," he said. "Hopefully, I will make history playing football, but I am going to be done by the time I am 31." 
They clearly learned to think ahead from their mother, who turned down a scholarship in home economics from Virginia Tech because she was determined to major in business. After she and her husband, James, a college football star, were divorced, she often worked long hours at jobs like assistant executive director for finance at the Virginia Skyline Council of the Girl Scouts. At night, she transcribed legal documents for insurance companies.
"We lived in a town-house-type apartment," Tiki said. "It was middle class. She didn't want us to be in the inner city where the low-income housing was. She wanted us to have as normal a life as she could buy.
"We had lots of friends," he continued. "By the time we were 12 or 13, we could stay on our own. We had each other to stay out of trouble."
MRS. BARBER taught them about money when they were youngsters. "I can remember when the kids wanted stuff they couldn't afford," she said in a telephone interview from her home in Roanoke. "I would say, 'Here is my paycheck. Here are the things I have to pay for: the rent, car insurance. Whatever is left, you can have.' They saw early that you can't get your paycheck and just go out and have fun." 
But Ronde said he never had a steady after-school job: "My Mom never made us feel like we were struggling. She made sacrifices. Obviously, we realize it now, after the fact."
Mrs. Barber said she believed that getting good grades was her sons' main job. "I did not want them to pay for the choice I made in getting a divorce," she said. "It was nothing they asked for, and nothing they deserved."
She said she was prepared to take on all kinds of student loans. "I was going to borrow whatever I needed to get them through college," she said, "as long as they had good grades." 
The twins got the message. Tiki was a valedictorian in high school, and both were named academic all-Americans at Virginia. 
Mrs. Barber missed only one game during her sons' high school years and just two in college. Once, in 1996, when she had a double mastectomy on a Monday, she had a friend drive her from Roanoke to Charlottesville that Saturday to watch them play. 
With her sons in college, she dealt with her empty nest by earning that M.B.A. at Averett University. She is now one of two assistant finance directors for Roanoke County. 
When the twins signed their rookie contracts, including a $700,000 signing bonus for Tiki and $400,000 for Ronde, they bought Ms. Barber a Mercedes.
The young men also bought her a new home in 1997 and, on her 50th birthday in January of this year, they gave her a Corvette.
AFTER college, for the first time, the twins' lifestyles diverged. Ronde loved Tampa. Tiki loved the pace of Manhattan. Tiki remembers Ronde saying, " 'Dude, don't you love it down here?' and I'm like, 'What in the hell do you do here?' " 
Their approach to business, however, has remained similar. They have kept the same team of advisers for seven years, which Mr. Lock says is somewhat unusual. "More people change their agents than keep them," he said.
In their first four years as pros, both men were earning good money. Ronde's contract, including his signing bonus, was just over $1 million. Aside from his bonus, Tiki's salary rose to $450,000 in the fourth year from $325,000 in his first year.
"In the grand scheme of football, you are just a working stiff," Tiki said. "You are not set for life. I live in a three-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side. The cost of living is high here."
Initially, Tiki's portfolio was more aggressive because he was more interested in stocks, and his larger advance let him put money in some private equity deals. But the decline in the market has left the brothers' asset allocations roughly the same -- with only about 25 percent in stocks, according to Mr. Banks. Among the equity holdings are General Electric and Procter & Gamble.
Though their returns have dwindled from about 10.5 percent in 1999 to about 1 percent a year the last three years, Tiki said he was not worried. "I am a long-term investor," he said. "And basically in the last year and a half since I got my money, there has been no clarity in the world, so you don't really know what you want to do. So we have been very conservative."
Tiki generally talks directly with Mr. Banks, sometimes as often as once a week. Ginny takes care of the household expenses. "If I left the household bills for him, we wouldn't have any electricity," she said.
Ronde said that before his marriage in 2001, "I definitely took a lot of advice from Tiki."
"I don't think I was capable enough, confident enough to do it by myself," he added.
That changed after his marriage. "At one point, I was trying to handle everything, and my wife, Claudia, was like, 'Tell me about this and tell me about that,' and I was like, 'Why don't you just talk to them yourself?' "
Now, he said: "Claudia handles everything from CSI these days. I probably talk to them about five times a year, and Claudia talks to them once a week. I obviously have the final say."
Even though the twins handle their investment business separately, when it comes to the business of football, there is no disagreement. 
Like Tiki, Ronde becomes immersed in contract issues.
"My job is to play football," he said. "I handle those things."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 4
