HEADLINE: THE THEATER WALKOUT: OVERVIEW; 
Empty Chairs at Bargaining Table in a Drama That No One Applauds

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
Matinee and evening curtain times came and went yesterday, and all but one Broadway musical stayed dark, as musicians continued their strike over minimum orchestra sizes, and actors and stagehands joined their picket lines.
 The strike did not adversely affect "Cabaret," which operates under a separate contract, straight plays or Off Broadway shows, which performed on schedule yesterday. 
 As placard-wearing musicians banged drums and blew trumpets in demonstrations throughout Times Square, theatergoers lined up at box offices to seek refunds or exchanges, and both sides in the labor dispute refused to budge. 
Producers said they were waiting for a call from the musicians after making an offer Friday night regarding the minimum number of players required in an orchestra pit. "We don't have anybody to be at the table with," said a producer of "Hairspray," Margo Lion. 
The musicians said the producers' offer of a 15-musician minimum had been proffered as final, closing off further negotiation. "We need to hear from them that it's not a final offer," said Bill Dennison, assistant to the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. "We are happy to come back to the table."
The impasse was expected to last through the weekend. Many people said they hoped that afterward both sides would feel compelled to return to the table, since the strike by the 325 musicians has idled many of Broadway's estimated 6,000 workers. Broadway theaters "provide thousands of jobs to New Yorkers, attract millions of tourists and generate billions of dollars of economic activity," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said in a statement. "I urge the theater owners and musicians' union to resolve their differences as quickly as possible."
Indeed, many Broadway insiders predict that the unity among the unions will be quickly strained if the strike drags on. The last musicians' strike, in 1975, lasted 25 days, a duration theater professionals said Broadway cannot afford in this economic climate.
"This will decimate us," said William Ivey Long, one of Broadway's leading costume designers. "I'm frantic. I've called all my wardrobe supervisors. We're holding hands over the telephone." 
Although actors were seen in an upbeat mood at various Broadway bars on Friday night hours after the strike began, their tonewas considerably more sober yesterday.
"I'm definitely worried, not only as far as my own paycheck," said Shoshana Bean, a member of the ensemble in "Hairspray." "I'm concerned that people are standing their ground in this strike, and some shows will close, and friends will be out of work." 
The 18 musicals on Broadway represent $1 million in gross sales per performance, according to the League of American Theaters and Producers, which represents the producers. As of tonight, the strike will have cost nearly $5 million. 
"The unions have turned out the lights," said the theater league's president, Jed Bernstein. "Theatergoers are certainly the ultimate losers."
Throughout the day, the parties involved and Broadway veterans were trying to figure out what went wrong. On Friday afternoon, it looked as if the shows would go on with virtual orchestras, which provide digital accompaniment. But at 5 p.m., Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, which represents the stagehands, voted to honor the picket line, a move that took producers by surprise. 
A few minutes later, Actors' Equity Association, which represents actors, voted to do the same, leaving the bulk of Broadway shut. 
But the support was clearly not offered easily. Officials of Actors' Equity made a point of saying that its position could change, depending on how negotiations proceed. And the stagehands did not say they would honor the picket line indefinitely.
Indeed, in conversations yesterday, many people who work on Broadway said they felt divided. "My one power I have is doing my own services and on Thursday getting paid for them," said Gavin Creel, who plays one of the leading men in "Thoroughly Modern Millie." "When somebody asks me to forfeit that power, I want to make sure I'm doing it for the right reasons."
Underlying the actors' support is the fact that their contract expires in June 2004. "I worry that we may have backed them too readily," Ms. Bean said. "A lot of the reason we did it is so they back us when we need them. They haven't backed us in the past."
The executive director of Actors' Equity, Alan Eisenberg, said he has tried to broker a deal between the two sides. But some producers say Mr. Eisenberg lost credibility with them after Sept. 11, 2001, when he waited until the stagehands offered concessions to help Broadway through a rough patch before coming up with his own.
Mr. Eisenberg said Equity had been preparing those concessions simultaneously.
The issue that prompted Friday's walkout was the minimum number of musicians required in Broadway's pits, currently 3 to 26, depending on the size of the theater, although exceptions have been granted. 
Both the musicians and producers acknowledge having made considerable headway on achieving flexibility in the process by which these exceptions are granted.
The producers' latest proposal would reduce the minimums for the largest theaters to 15. The musicians have refused to move from a minimum of 24.
When negotiations began early last month, the producers at first demanded an end to minimums. They say the musicians have not shown a similar willingness to move from their starting position. "We've moved six times in the last seven days," Mr. Bernstein said. "They haven't moved at all."
Mr. Dennison, of the musicians' union, said the union has in fact moved to the 24-musician minimum from 25 and 26 for the largest theaters. "Our concern is that they remain houses where a large orchestra can perform," he said. "There is no way we're going to protect the right to have an orchestra unless we protect the minimums."
The producers argue that the minimums allow the musicians to appropriate creative control. Because of the growing costs of mounting musicals on Broadway, they are also concerned about keeping costs down.
The musicians maintain that reducing the minimums will make it increasingly difficult to have full orchestras on Broadway, because producers will almost always opt to use the fewest musicians possible to save money. While a handful of productions have employed more musicians than the minimums called for, typically, music professionals say, producers stick to the minimums.
"The minimum is the same as the maximum," said Jonathan Tunick, the orchestrator behind most of Stephen Sondheim's musicals. "My experience has been consistently that when a new show is being planned, I am dictated the number of musicians I'm allowed by the producer. It's a condition of employment." 
Mr. Tunick is currently preparing the revival of "Nine" for Broadway. The first orchestra rehearsal is scheduled for Wednesday, with 15 musicians, down from the original production's 26 in 1982.
"They now have the minimums so low," Mr. Tunick said, "they're unworkable."

HEADLINE: For a Legend, A Fitting Encore 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
THE Danbury Museum and Historical Society, which owns the former practice studio of Marian Anderson, the singer who was the first African-American to perform at the Metropolitan Opera, is working to restore the studio and turn it into a permanent exhibition where musicians can take advantage of its extraordinary acoustics.
 In just a few weeks, the Anderson studio will open the exhibition on the life and career of the singer, who moved to the city in the early 1940's and lived there until she died in 1993. 
 "In the future, we hope to start an oral history project on the life of Ms. Anderson," said Brigid Durkin, executive director of the Danbury Museum and Historical Society, which is supervising the renovation of the Anderson studio. " Singers could use this space in the same way that Ms. Anderson used it, as apractice hall in which the singer can hear exactly what his or her voice would sound like in a well-attended concert hall." 
The studio had been designed by Anderson's husband, Orpheus Fisher, an architect.
"An unusual feature of the studio is its so-called cove ceiling, which means that both the ceiling itself and its juncture with all four walls are curved," said Max Ferro, a preservation architect based in Weare, N.H., who is a consultant in the renovation.
"This diffuses the sound, making this relatively small room the acoustical equivalent to a much larger concert hall."
Already, the construction company under contract to do the renovation, APEX Development Corporation, has built a new foundation for the studio and is starting to renovate the interior. Scott McCarthy, president of APEX, said he expected the renovation to be finished by early spring. The formal opening is expected to be in September. In a life filled with big moments, perhaps Anderson's biggest came in 1939. Anderson was scheduled to sing at Constitution Hall in Washington on Easter Sunday as part of a national concert tour, but the Daughters of the American Revolution, which owned the hall, cancelled her appearance because she was black, Anderson wrote in her autobiography. 
Outraged, Eleanor Roosevelt withdrew her membership from the organization, and Harold L. Ickes, President Roosevelt's secretary of the interior, offered the steps of the Lincoln Memorial as a substitute. About 75,000 people showed up for her performance there.
"When I started to sing our National Anthem," Anderson later wrote, " "I felt for a moment as though I were choking. For a desperate second, I thought that the words, well as I know them, would not come. Yet I sang. I don't know how."
After that concert, which made Anderson an international celebrity, she and her husband-to-be began house hunting throughout New York, New Jersey, New Hampshire and Connecticut. They joked about having traveled more than 10,000 miles in their quest, but the matter was not always amusing. Some property owners took their houses off the market when they discovered that the couple were African-Americans.
According to Allan Keiler's biography "Marian Anderson: A Singer's Journey" (Scribner, 2000), her husband once wrote to Anderson, who was on tour: "I am sorry about the Golden house, but my dear one must expect these things in a country so full of hate and prejudice."
Eventually, they settled on a 12-room, three-story Victorian farmhouse on 100 acres on Joe's Hill Road at the western side of Danbury. The owner, according to the biography, tried to stop the sale, but it was too late. Anderson later confided, Mr. Keiler reported, that they had to buy twice as much property as they needed "so we wouldn't contaminate the neighborhood."
It would be her home for nearly 50 years. Anderson was a familiar figure in Danbury during her life there, and she is remembered fondly by many in town who came to know her.
"She was never aloof," said Nancy F. Sudik, executive director of the Danbury Music Centre who knew Anderson in the 1970's when they were both on the board of the center, a nonprofit organization that presents musical programs at the local high school and elsewhere. "She was a true aristocrat, genteel even when elderly and frail."
Recalling Anderson's deep interest in music education, Ms. Sudik said, "During the Bicentennial celebration in 1976, long after Ms. Anderson had retired as a concert artist, she delivered the narrative section of Aaron Copeland's 'A Lincoln Portrait' at Danbury High School." 
John Cherry, who teaches at Danbury Elementary School and was a neighbor of Anderson, recalled her friendliness.
"I remember that one day after she had returned from a concert tour in India, she regaled us for at least half an hour with stories about the customs she had run into over there," he said. 
She was also self-effacing, Mr. Cherry continued: "She came to my sister's wedding and arrived late. My sister was just about to appear at the reception, so Ms. Anderson ducked and hid so that she wouldn't take attention away from my sister."
Anderson sold the Danbury house to a developer in 1982 with a provision that she and her husband could continue to live in it for the rest of their lives. Fisher died in 1986. When Anderson died in 1993 at the age of 96, the three-story house was demolished and several homes built on the property, but the single-story studio remained. The developer donated it to the Danbury Museum and Historical Society in 1999, when it was moved behind the museum at 43 Main Street.
The moving and renovation of the 24 foot by 20 foot studio is expected to cost $266,000, Ms. Durkin said. Because of the lobbying of Ms. Durkin and Deborah Grover, a Danbury lawyer who said she was introduced to Anderson as a child, $190,000 has been raised through bonds from the State Department of Economic and Community Development. Ms. Durkin said the rest is expected to be donated by local banks. 
"The renovated studio," Ms. Durkin added, "is a tribute to Ms. Anderson's success as a singer, an artist, a friend and a role model for women everywhere."

HEADLINE: Big Surprise, A Fare Hike 

BYLINE:  By JEFF HOLTZ

 BODY:
THE 15 percent increase in Metro-North fares included in the budget proposal for 2003-2004 that Gov. John Rowland announced last week would be the biggest that riders have seen in nearly 20 years. But early indications are that they are not too upset by it. 
 "We haven't had an increase in years," said Jim Korchak of Stratford, a computer consultant waiting for a New York-bound train at the Stratford station on Wednesday. "If you look at it from a perspective of what the rate of inflation has been, I think it's fair. They're not asking for a ridiculous increase." 
 Just a few yards away, Theresa Shaw of Glastonbury said, referring to the governor: "I guess if we're in a crisis, what's he supposed to do?"
According to the Metro-North Railroad and the Connecticut Department of Transportation, the increase would be the highest since a 20 percent increase in 1984 and the first since a 4.5 increase in 1998.
James Cameron, vice chairman of the Connecticut Metro-North/Shoreline East Rail Commuter Council, an advocacy group representing rail commuters throughout the state, said he preferred to consider the increase more like a group of smaller ones that might have been spread out over the previous four years, such as the annual 5 percent increases in the mid-1990's.
"We have gone four years without an increase, and that doesn't mean that the cost of operating the railroad has gone down in any respect," he said. "That obviously keeps going up, too."
According to Harry P. Harris, chief of the Bureau of Public Transportation for the state's transportation department, the increase, which could take effect as early as Oct. 1, would help to cover the 65 percent of Metro North's deficit for which the state is responsible.
"What the governor has said is that the state's subsidy toward that deficit is being frozen at the level it's at this year," he said. "Therefore, any increase has to be picked up through the fare.
"The other alternative is to cut the size of the deficit. The only way to do that is by cutting service."
On Wednesday, Mr. Cameron said he had received "only a handful" of electronic mail regarding the increase. None appeared angry.
"They seem somewhat resigned to the inevitability of a fare increase, especially given the alternative, which would have been some reduction is service," he said.
Under the increase, a monthly commutation ticket from Stamford to New York City would go from $218 to $250.

HEADLINE: BY THE WAY; 
She Did It Her Way

 BODY:
It turns out mother knew best. When Amy Schapiro needed a subject for her history thesis at American University, her mom suggested Millicent Fenwick. 
About all Ms. Schapiro knew at that point was that Ms. Fenwick was a politician. "I thought she was a senator," said Ms. Schapiro, now an author who works for the federal Justice Department. 
 Ms. Fenwick, who died in 1992, was a politician -- a famously colorful and independent one -- but she was never a senator. She ran for that office in 1982, after four terms in the House of Representatives, suffering her first political defeat at age 72 to Frank R. Lautenberg. 
But there was much more to Ms. Fenwick's life than politics, as Ms. Schapiro demonstrates in the book that grew from her thesis, "Millicent Fenwick: Her Way," released this week by Rutgers University Press. 
A chapter called "Love, Scandal and Marriage" tells the story of a short-lived union that ended with Ms. Fenwick as an unemployed mother who had two children to support and a pile of debts run up by her ex-husband. Her luck started to change when Vogue magazine hired her to write captions. In time, she began writing feature articles, as well as "Vogue's Book of Etiquette" in 1948.
The book is enriched by the fact that Ms. Fenwick's son, Hugh, granted Ms. Schapiro exclusive rights to his mother's personal papers. "This included unlimited access to the Fenwick attic, in which I found correspondence from Millicent's father, grandmother and, of course, her," the author said. "The most valuable items were her personal journals, photographs and correspondence with her husband."

HEADLINE: Training a Changing Work Force 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
FOR eight weeks last year, Leona Cottle went to her job-training center here every day learning how to cook, finally earning a certificate in culinary arts.
 But Ms. Cottle cannot feed her family of nine children, aged 5 to 21, on her own because she still can't find a job, and so she continues to collect welfare. For now, she makes a few dollars selling cakes and pies to friends at her church, the Faith Holy Temple. 
 She just finished another eight-week job-readiness training program administered through the state Department of Human Service, and hopes to find full-time work at a day-care center. So far, she has had several interviews, but no job offer. 
"I've learned a lot here," Ms. Cottle said one recent morning in the offices of RespondWorks, a community-based training agency financed by the state. "I know I can do this job, if I can get the chance."
In an effort to help Ms. Cottle and more than 200,000 other people in the state in a similar position, New Jersey is planning a major reorganization of its job-training programs that could have far-reaching implications for thousands of unemployed workers. 
While the state is facing a cyclical economic downturn, workers are also confronting deeper changes in the economy that make it more likely than ever that they will need job training at some point, regardless of how well educated or highly skilled they are. 
Yet Governor McGreevey says state training programs are not doing the job.
"New Jersey needs to be able to focus on those skills that are required in the marketplace," the governor said in a speech at Rutgers in January while outlining his plans. "For too long, we have developed skill-based training programs that were not necessarily responsive."
New Jersey's unemployment rate is hovering at 5.5 percent, just below the national average of 5.7 percent. In the past two years alone, more than 92,000 workers in the state have lost their jobs, according to the John J. Heldrich Center for Work Force Development at Rutgers. A shaky economy has put not only low-wage workers at risk; mass layoffs at large companies affected more than 56,000 workers in New Jersey last year, up from 45,173 in 2000, according to the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.On top of that, new research by Rutgers indicates job tenure has declined in the state, especially for men in mid-career. In 1983, the share of men aged 40 to 44 who had been with the same employer for 25 years was 51.1 percent, while last year it was 37.7 percent. 
In response, the governor plans to shift responsibility for the bulk of the state's job training to the Department of Labor, which he says has closer ties to the private sector and more experience with training programs for workers at all levels of skill than the Department of Human Services and the Education Department, which currently administer many of the programs. That is just the beginning of a long-term effort to bring government training plans in closer alignment with the needs of business, Mr. McGreevey said. 
He believes that just as states provide incentives to lure plants or office complexes, developing a competent work force can be an economic development tool, particularly in today's tenuous economy. 
"When I was a young man growing up in the community of Carteret, someone would graduate from high school, walk down to the chemical manufacturing plant and find a job that was going to provide a lifetime of opportunity and benefits," Mr. McGreevey said. "That time has long passed."
Today, workers can expect to change jobs seven times during their working lives, the governor said. "The only aspect that is certain is the ability of a worker to take skills from job to job and opportunity to opportunity," he added. "It is our moral obligation to provide for a skilled work force."
For now, the biggest change in job training proposed by the administration will transfer welfare-to-work training and adult literacy -- now managed by the Department of Human Services and the Department of Education -- to the Labor Department. 
To be sure, some of those who work with training programs for the economically disadvantaged are wary of the governor's plan.
"We are concerned," said Marlene Lao-Collins, associate director for social concerns at the New Jersey Catholic Conference. "We don't believe the Department of Labor is really equipped to deal with this population. These people have a unique set of problems. It's not just about job training. Very often there is substance abuse or mental illness. These people have a whole bunch of other barriers to deal with. I think we're going to have some problems."
Under the plan, expected to be in place by July, the Department of Labor will administer as much as $450 million in state and federal job-training money. To underscore the department's new scope, it will be renamed the Department of Labor and Work Force Development.
Mr. McGreevey said the plan was not expected to save money for the state, which has a $5 billion budget deficit, but he insisted that it would not present the state with any additional costs. The goal, he said, is rather "making the system work better."
At this point, welfare recipients are hoping that this amounts to more than simply rearranging the furniture within the bureaucracy. Many are coming to the end of extensions on their five-year limit mandated by the federal welfare-reform program, Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, that took effect in 1997. In New Jersey, 22,198 welfare recipients are required to work or participate in such training programs.
Asia White has been on and off welfare for two years. A 24-year-old Newark resident, Ms. White is learning how to wire components at a job-training program run by Catholic Community Services with funds administered through the Department of Human Services. She had trouble keeping jobs at a hospital and as a teacher's aide because she had to turn attention to her 2-year old son, who had to be hospitalized for a foot ailment and for breathing problems. 
Ms. White is attending the eight-week program in hopes of earning $28 an hour, and she has little concern about which arm of the state government is administering the program. 
"As long as we're still getting the training for us, it really doesn't matter who is running it," she said.
Carl Van Horn, director of the Heldrich Center for Work Force Development at Rutgers, which has worked closely with the state on developing work force policy, said other states were moving in a similar direction.
Mr. Van Horn noted that while New Jersey was not at the bottom of the heap in terms of job training, it had plenty of room for improvement. 
"I would give us a C," he said.
As for Governor McGreevey's plan, Mr. Van Horn said it represented a radical change from the more traditional practice of tinkering with job-training programs through incremental change. 
"This is really unprecedented in the state," he said.
As he explained it, the confusing web of programs lies mostly in federal mandates, since about two-thirds of the funds come from the federal government.
Still, Mr. Van Horn said, there will be obstacles to the governor's plan, notably an entrenched system of administrators and contractors who oversee the programs, "people who don't want to give up their turf."
But the officials who will lose turf to the Department of Labor -- Gwendolyn Harris, commissioner of the Department of Human Services, and William Librera, commissioner of education -- said they support the new approach.
"Employment is a tangible recognition of our value to society," Ms. Harris said. Through the reorganization, she said, "We'll help people to affirm that." But advocates for the poor fear that the Labor Department lacks the expertise to manage the problems that confront people who are enrolled in welfare job-training programs or seeking literacy help.
D. Miller Jr., president of Legal Services of New Jersey, said he was concerned that welfare recipients and others currently enrolled in job-training programs managed through the Departments of Education and Human Services needed broad counseling services to keep them in training and on the job. Often they are entangled in crises that make it hard to participate in training or employment programs.
"If the landlord is about to evict you, or you have a sick child, you are going to need some very intense case management and guidance as well as cash assistance," Mr. Miller said. "These kinds of services have not traditionally been provided within the labor system nationally, not just in New Jersey."
Nonetheless, Mr. Miller said he would need to see more details about the governor's plan before saying whether he would oppose it. 
"All this is not to say that the current service provision is perfect," said Mr. Miller. "It is not."
For his part, Albert Kroll, commissioner of the Labor Department, said his agency was up to the additional responsibilities.
"We're comfortable that with the cooperation of everyone, we're still going to be able to provide these services," Mr. Kroll said. "If I were not comfortable, I would not push for this."
As he sees it, welfare recipients and others receiving job training will welcome the more streamlined system. Now three departments oversee 20 separate divisions administering the welfare-to-work program, he said.
Holding up a chart showing the state adult literacy programs and how they link into other programs, Mr. Kroll commented, "It looks like a recipe to make a nuclear bomb."
Overall, a network of 484 outside contractors provide services to the three state departments involved in work-force training. Mr. Kroll said it was not clear if there would be any effect on these contractors, many of them nonprofit social service organizations.
Mr. Kroll said contractors should welcome the change because they will have to apply to just one department for work-related grants, all scheduled to expire at the same time.
Tom Blatner, president of Janus Solutions in Hopewell, a private consulting company that has designed work force development programs for Camden, Essex and Hudson Counties, said he supported the changes.
"This recognizes what social services does best, which is determine eligibility and provide the necessary support services, but it moves the work-related dollars into the mainstream of the state's work force development," Mr. Blatner said.
The roots of the consolidation now under way lie in several years of policy analysis questioning the state's strategy for developing its work force. In 1996, the New Jersey State Employment and Training Commission issued a paper titled "Crisis of the Work Force," which criticized government-run training programs for using a "supply side" approach in finding jobs based on the "needs of the agencies" rather than the needs of business.
Henry Plotkin, executive director of the commission, said the state's failure to provide relevant job-training programs bred social inequality.
Mr. Plotkin said that an emphasis on college preparation and a determination to provide equal education to all worked against those who dropped out of school but no longer could turn to manufacturing jobs.
In that regard, Mr. Plotkin said, Western Europe had done a better job in linking education and training to the labor markets. 
"The U.S. is learning it must be more targeted and strategic and nurturing of its work force to stay competitive internationally," he said. "If you do this right, you simultaneously help economic growth and achieve social justice by giving people a fair crack. Under the current system, they're not getting a fair crack."
Mr. Plotkin said government could also help train workers for small businesses, an increasingly important part of the employment market, that did not have the resources to do it on their own.
Mr. Van Horn said government has had to change its approach to unemployment. Beginning in the New Deal era and continuing through the early 1990's, unemployment benefits were meant to smooth out the disruption of temporary layoffs.
"It was intended to hold the work force in place so that it could be hired back when needed," Mr. Van Horn said. "Now the layoffs tend to be permanent. They're never going to be called back." 
In response, he said, government has tried to extend the benefits, and encourage people to invest in retraining. But he said job loss through industrial consolidation and international competition was not going to ease up.
"The only way you can deal with it is mainly with education and training," he said.
To design strong training programs, the state needed to have a better handle on business's needs, Mr. Van Horn said. 
For example, a study prepared by the Heldrich Center for the state's pharmaceutical industry found the higher education system in New Jersey would not be able to produce enough workers to meet projected demand for 15,000 new jobs in the next three years. 
To address Governor McGreevey's concern about the mismatch, Mr. Plotkin said his commission, along with the Labor Department and the Heldrich Center, would soon embark on a survey of businesses in seven leading areas to determine what skills would be needed in the future. 
Currently, he said, the department relied largely on existing job openings to gauge what would be needed.
"That is like generals fighting the last war," said Mr. Plotkin.
He said the results of the survey, which are expected to be ready and made available to schools and other work force development programs in the fall, would help workers adjust to changing labor patterns.
"This will give us a much more forward-looking understanding," Mr. Plotkin said, "so we can be more proactive rather than just reacting as we have in the past."

HEADLINE: When Mommy Or Daddy Can't Read 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA ROWE 

 BODY:
NELLA BRAIOTTA was 35 years old when she decided to come clean. She had a job as a nursery school aide and was narrating a picture book to a little boy when it happened. The child looked at her accusingly. "That's not the way the story goes," he said. "You're reading it wrong."
 All through her own childhood Ms. Braiotta had faked, pantomiming her way through life, pretending she could understand the words on job applications, medication bottles and on the pages of her beloved Bible. She graduated from high school, but she did not even know what a vowel was. 
 "I thought, 'Oh my God, even a 4-year-old kid can see this,"' said Ms. Braiotta, now 50, who lives in White Plains. "'I've got to do something."' 
Close friends and family knew. For years they had urged her to find a literacy tutor, even as they helped camouflage her deficiencies by supplying Ms. Braiotta with cheat sheets of basic information to hide up her sleeve and copy onto forms as needed. Asking for help from a stranger was a crushing humiliation. But after the nursery school incident, she picked up the phone and called Literacy Volunteers of Westchester County.
"I need help," she said softly. "Basically, I can't read."
A few weeks later Ms. Braiotta was sitting at a small table in the Mamaroneck Public Library, ready to meet her tutor and begin at the beginning.
"It was very hard," she said. "We started with 'A is for Apple. E is for Elephant,' and I'd come home crying to my husband, 'I'm 35 years old, I can't believe I have to do this!"'
So many different categories are within the group of Americans deemed functionally illiterate, and so many different causes, that no single definition applies. The numbers, however, are staggering: More than 20 percent of adults in America -- approximately 44 million people -- have such weak reading skills they find it difficult to fill out a bank deposit slip or to understand an article in the newspaper, according to studies published over the last decade by the National Institute for Literacy. Westchester mirrors this profile, though in certain areas of the county the figures are even higher. 
Those seeking to learn English as a second language -- many of them functionally illiterate in their own tongues -- have further swelled the numbers. 
At Literacy Volunteers in Elmsford, the vast majority of those seeking help are immigrants, many of whom can barely read or write in their native languages. But about 20 percent of clients are American-born, either high school dropouts or elderly people who went to work full time while still children; or, like Ms. Braiotta, students who were funneled into special education programs and passed along with minimal expectations.
After a year of struggling through textbook exercises that explained the sound of "ph" and "th," both Ms. Braiotta and her tutor, Paula Cancro, were discouraged. 
"Nella was my first student and I was terrified," said Ms. Cancro, a 47-year-old corporate computer trainer. "I thought I was doing everything wrong. I was sure I was going to make it worse."
Finally, she asked Ms. Braiotta to bring in something she truly wanted to read, thinking it might provide motivation for them both. She expected to see a novel or some other ambitious work. Ms. Braiotta returned with a copy of Cosmopolitan magazine.
"I thought, 'Well, this is going to be interesting,"' Ms. Cancro said. "But then I realized, of course, this is the kind of thing Nella sees every day, something anyone would want to be able to pick up and understand."
LIKE Helen Keller's epiphany under the water spigot, letters and sounds finally came together as words for Ms. Braiotta within the pages of the women's magazine. After that, she was unstoppable. Next she wanted to learn about the seizure disorder that had been holding her back all her life. It was the reason she'd been placed in special education to begin with, she said, the reason people thought she was slow and the reason she was forced to swallow 21 pills a day. 
Ms. Braiotta and her teacher began by reading simple medical brochures, which led to a support group, which led Ms. Braiotta to discover that her condition had been curable all along. She found a doctor who agreed to perform the needed brain surgery and has been seizure-free for the last 13 years.
"It's very simple," she said. "Reading saved my life."
Now a member of the Literacy Volunteers' board, Ms. Braiotta often speaks with legislators in Albany about her story and the need for financing literacy services. She is a shy, polite woman who has spent a lifetime learning to assert herself. But she remains bitterly angry with the Westchester County public school she says let her down. 
"I faked it for years and I was ashamed all my life about this," she railed. "I resent it tremendously because what's a diploma if I didn't even know my vowels?"
Ms. Braiotta asked that her former high school not be identified -- "they know who they are," she said -- and among literacy experts there is a similar reluctance to blame public education outright. They feel their job is to patch holes, not point fingers. 
Still, Bob Hassinger, program coordinator at the Center for Continuing Education in Yonkers, believes the state's current emphasis on Regents diplomas for all students will result in higher dropout rates among those who can't meet the standard and further contribute to the population of functionally illiterate adults.
Each week, many of them trudge up the steep hill to the center's worn-out building on the former Elizabeth Seton College campus. Some 4,500 come for help each year. Three-quarters have children in the Yonkers schools, Mr. Hassinger said, though the free classes are open to anyone.
In early February, Daniel Hill, dressed in a suit and tie, timidly stepped inside. He was tired of being unable to understand his mail. 
"It hurts me so much to say to people, 'Excuse me, could you read this bill for me? Could you tell me what this letter says?,"' said Mr. Hill, who is 51 and has supported himself with a patchwork of custodial and trucking jobs. "But I was raised in the South, in North Carolina and mostly, we farmed a lot. We didn't go to school much. I have so much anger about all that. I feel like if I'd had the tools, I could have been a doctor or a lawyer or owned my own business."
Currently unemployed, he shows up at the center every day, carrying his homework in a briefcase. After his first week of classes, Mr. Hill broke down in grateful tears.
"There's a lot of people out there just like me, who are ashamed to come forward," he said. "People look down on you if you don't have any education. They treat you sort of bad sometimes."
Among those learning to read in Westchester, Mr. Hill is something of a rarity. At Literacy Volunteers, only 30 percent of the clients are men, and at the Yonkers continuing education center, women have also been the majority, though Charles Whelan, the principal, said that is beginning to change. He believes the shift is a result of the economy and more men being out of work. Others suspect that it is simply more difficult for men to ask for help.
"A lot of the women are single mothers and they come in when their kids start to know more than they do," said Janet Zinman, who has been teaching at the center since 1966. "They say, 'I want to help my child and how can I do that when I can't even help myself?"'
In 37 years as a literacy tutor, Ms. Zinman said the pattern remains essentially the same:
"It's kids who missed the lesson on Monday and come back on Tuesday, lost because they don't know what happened on Monday. By Wednesday, they're saying, 'I'm not going to go to school because I'm so behind I don't even know what's going on."' 
According to federal figures, more than a quarter of adults in Yonkers may have difficulty with base-level skills like deciphering a food label, understanding a bus schedule or reading stories to their children. In Mount Vernon, with more poverty and more immigrants, many of whom had little opportunity to attend school in their home countries, those figures rise to 37 percent. 
For Patricia P. Rajala, the executive director of Literacy Volunteers of Westchester County, the human toll is overwhelming. Her group, which accepts only adults with a fifth-grade reading level or lower, has approximately 350 reading tutors on staff -- all volunteers -- helping 1,100 students. Another 250 pupils have been interviewed, assessed and are waiting for help. At Literacy Volunteers' satellite office in the Yonkers Public Library, 300 people inquire about services each month, though many are referred to other, more appropriate programs. It is Ms. Rajala's greatest thrill to tell someone with an eighth-grade education, "Sorry, you're too good for us." 
Robin Osborne, who coordinates literacy services for the Westchester Library System, said she had found that those learning English as a Second Language often have an easier time asking for help than do lifetime residents in one of the wealthiest counties in the country.
"It's easier to go someplace and say, 'I need to learn English,' than to say 'I'm 25 years old and I never learned to read,"' she said. "There's a lot of stigma, but these people are in our community." And the financial implications, she noted, are enormous. 
A study released by the American Medical Association in 1998 found that people who could not read directions on a medication bottle or fill out insurance forms cost the health care system between $50 billion and $73 billion in excess costs each year. 
"Just think about it," said Dr. Joanne Schwartzberg, the medical association's director of aging and community health. "The average instructions are written at 12th to 17th grade level and the average American is at about an eighth-grade level. Even perfectly literate people sometimes have trouble understanding how to take their medicine, but about half of us can get on the Internet and educate ourselves. The other half of us can't do that."
PEOPLE with low literacy were twice as likely to be hospitalized, twice as likely to say they were in poor health and far more likely to use emergency rooms as a first choice for health care, the study found.
"They said that filling out forms in doctor's offices was very difficult for them," Dr. Schwartzberg explained. "It's usually something they're terribly ashamed of -- over 60 percent of illiterate people have never even told their spouse -- but if you go to an emergency room, someone else fills the forms out for you."
Beatrice Pinckney might well have been standing by and watching. A former nurse's aide at several Westchester hospitals, the 50-something grandmother has worked seven days a week, holding two or three jobs simultaneously since she was 15. She has also raised five children on her own, four of whom she adopted. But she never learned to read. A year ago, one of Ms. Pinckney's grown daughters finally called Literacy Volunteers insisting that her mother get help.
Candace Benson, the tutor assigned to Ms. Pinckney, was amazed: . a woman who had spent a lifetime caring for other people couldn't write a letter. Ms. Pinckney had left school in South Carolina in the seventh grade, traveled north to work as a housekeeper in Scarsdale (lying about her age to the employment agency) and sent money home to her family each month. 
"We were poor," Ms. Pinckney said with a shrug. "When you're poor, you're poor, and that's it."
She watched her employer's children go off to college and then moved on to jobs as a nursing home aide, hospital worker and security guard. Before last November, she had never voted.
Ms. Benson, a 56-year-old artist from Larchmont, asked her pupil, "Do you know the word democracy?" Ms. Pinckney did not.
"This is not a stupid woman," Ms. Benson said. "No one could do what she's done without an innate hunger, even brilliance. Beatrice has that. But she has been cheated out of so much. I asked her: 'Do you know how this country was founded? Do you know the basic principles?' She said no. And when she finally voted last fall, she was elated."
Despite her dignified bearing, Ms. Pinckney giggled like a girl at her tutor's praise.
Now twice a week the two women -- casually dressed Ms. Benson and impeccably garbed Ms. Pinckney -- bow their heads together over workbooks in the Port Chester Public Library. The first texts Ms. Benson chose for her student were fictional diaries about a South Carolina slave who taught herself to read by dusting the master's library. At the time, the older woman did not know how to sound out a word. Now she is working her way through "Death of a Salesman." 
Not every student and tutor make such a perfect match. The work can be slow and frustrating. Both Ms. Benson and Ms. Pinckney had disappointing experiences before they found each other -- a prior charge of Ms. Benson's, aggravated by his sputtering progress, dropped out after she had invested months working with him; Ms. Pinckney's first tutor moved out of the area. To avoid situations like those, Literacy Volunteers asks that each party commit to a year of working several hours each week because that is how long it takes to raise reading skills, and if enthusiasm flags in one person, it can be devastating for the other.
"It's a real commitment," Ms. Rajala said. "But it's a very rewarding one."
Certainly it was for Ms. Braiotta, whose brain was altered in the most dramatic way when she finally learned to read. But what she savors most are the everyday changes. Her husband, she said, laughing, no longer has absolute control over the checkbook, since she has learned to take care of the banking. She reads aloud in Bible study instead of shaking her head and shrinking away, and best of all, she can curl up with a romance novel -- Barbara Taylor Bradford is her favorite -- gleefully telling her husband: "You'll have to wait for dinner. I've got to finish reading this chapter."

Assessing Reading Levels
THOSE who sailed through school and are watching their children do the same might consider appropriate fifth-grade reading to be "Black Beauty" or "Harry Potter." But for adults with low literacy, being rated at the fifth-grade level is not quite the same.
"For us, the definition is closer to seeing if someone can understand the directions on a packet of Jell-O," said Patricia P. Rajala, the director of Literacy Volunteers of Westchester County. "Adult literacy is more about being able to use information appropriately and act on it."
Literacy Volunteers of America has developed a standard assessment test. Here are examples of passages used to determine reading levels:
First- to second-grade level: 
We went fishing. I got two fish. They almost took my line. A boy got the big one. It took the worm. It was a cold day.
Approximately fifth-grade level:
I went fishing with my brother this weekend. He just bought a new Star Craft but the engine wouldn't start. We had to use an old boat but we didn't care because we were excited about fishing. We caught a couple of bullheads and a 14-inch trout. We can use the new boat the next time. We didn't mind as long as we had some fish.
Eighth-grade level (if a client can read and understand this passage, Literacy Volunteers of Westchester recommends that they enroll in a G.E.D. program): 
Last week my car developed motor trouble. I decided I needed a new valve job for one thing. Also somebody had stolen three parts of the carburetor so I had to have those replaced. The car had to be in the repair shop for about four days. Some parts probably had to be ordered from a wholesaler because a mechanic usually doesn't have them in stock. 

In a Family That Reads Together, Children Benefit
FOR many parents, teaching young children their own names or the words for shapes and colors is so rudimentary that it barely warrants a second thought. But literacy experts estimate that in thousands of homes in New York, there are no picture books to introduce these basic concepts, and no adult able to read them aloud.
The relationship between family life and literacy skills was identified nationally in 1989, after Bill Goodling, then a Congressman from Pennsylvania, observed that it made little sense to pour millions of dollars into schools if students were going home to parents who were functionally illiterate. A mother who could not read a teacher's note or understand her child's report card did not bode well for that student's chances of success. A federal program, Even Start, was begun to teach entire families how to read together. The government now spends some $250 million on that effort each year.
There are 80 Even Start programs in New York State, serving immigrant families, incarcerated families, families living below the poverty line and white, working-class families. Westchester and Dutchess Counties have four chapters -- in Tarrytown-Sleepy Hollow, Yonkers, Beacon and Poughkeepsie.
At the Tarrytown-Sleepy Hollow program, Susan Gitlitz-Tucker works with the local school district, library and child care center to guide 25 Spanish-speaking families through everything from learning to write their names to using computers. Many of the parents never progressed beyond the second grade in their own countries. Ms. Gitlitz-Tucker and her staff members teach them about Shakespeare in preparation for a trip to see "Romeo and Juliet" onstage. No matter that none have ever been to a play before. Ms. Gitlitz-Tucker is thinking ahead to the day when their children will come home from school, assigned to read theater as literature. 
"Most of our families didn't even know what a library was when they started with us," she said. 
Few had ever written a letter. They routinely spent $1 to buy a single 37-cent stamp at their corner bodega when posting bills rather than going to the post office. Some were afraid. Others did not know better. Often, their children -- addressed by pet names at home -- could not answer when asked in school: "Who are you? What is your name?"
"That was really something that shocked me when I first started working here," said Lourdes Parra, an Even Start tutor. "They didn't know their names."
Ms. Gitlitz-Tucker said: "These kids come in immaculate and well fed, but they're not prepared to sit in a circle, to listen or answer questions. Most have never been read to because our families don't have books in their homes. All of those things we often take for granted, our families aren't doing because they don't know how."
Still, persuading adults to let go of old ways and commit to Even Start's intensive, long-term course is not always easy. In Beacon, which opened a program last October, 11 families have signed up, though there is money for 48.
"The challenge is to get families to trust us," said Margaret Pfaff, the executive director of Literacy Volunteers in Dutchess County. "These are people who've had failure at every turn, particularly institutionally. They're shy. They're uncomfortable. But no matter their educational or economic background, I have never yet met a parent who didn't want things better for their child. Once we reach them on that level, we've won. All of them want a better life for their kids, and that is the ultimate goal."
If you want to help:
Even Start welcomes family literacy volunteers. Call Ms. Gitlitz-Tucker at (914)332-0209 for information.
Literacy Volunteers of Westchester County has tutor training sessions running March through April and April through May. Call (914)592-2656 for information.
A Web site, www.firstfind.info, which is a project of the Westchester Library System, is designed to help those with low reading skills understand and navigate the Internet. CLAUDIA ROWE

HEADLINE: IN THE SCHOOLS; 
State Cuts Will Mean Scrambles for Tuition

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
ERIN MALLAY loves being a student at Sarah Lawrence College.
 She loves it so much that its daunting price tag didn't deter her or her parents -- her father is a police officer and her mother is a Catholic schoolteacher in Brooklyn -- from enrolling. 
 "I go to a very expensive private school, and it's not easy," Ms. Mallay said. "Tuition is some $30,000 a year, and I don't have that. I'm on work study, and I work 15 to 20 hours a week in the college, do other jobs for people, and work during the summer. Every year I scramble." 
If Gov. George E. Pataki's budget proposals concerning cuts in state aid and tuition increases at the state university system are approved, the yearly scramble to piece together tuition, fees and living expenses will be even harder for students like Ms. Mallay. Under the governor's proposed budget, students who receive financial aid under the Tuition Assistance Program (TAP) would be required to take out loans to make up one-third of their TAP grants, with the loan payment deferred until after graduation. TAP is state financial aid program for low- and middle-income full-time students. 
"The rationale, from the conservative line, is that there's a lot of waste in education spending, that there are students who take five, six, seven years to graduate," said Brian Nickerson, director of the Michaelian Institute at Pace University in White Plains and a professor of political science there. "It doesn't make good public policy sense. This is a shortsighted policy. This hurts the vast majority of students throughout the state. Pace is a tuition-dependent institution, and there are a number of students who are reliant on their TAP awards. The proposal would force universities to withhold collection of that money until students graduate."
For students at the State University of New York's public campuses like Purchase College, the governor's proposal to raise tuition by $1,200 carries still further hardships.
"A tuition increase of $1,200 that affects 400,000 students across the state is $180 million," said Michael Stock, student government president at Purchase. "That's an incredible chunk of money. We're starting to assess how bad the damage is going to be."
For their part, state officials said, such steps may be necessary, given current economic exigencies.
"The state is looking at drastically reduced tax revenues, with New York faced with particular challenges," said David Henahan, director of media relations for the State University of New York in Albany, and the chancellor's press officer. "Forty-eight out of 50 states will be raising tuition in the fall, and 30 states will be cutting state aid to higher education. SUNY hasn't raised tuition in seven years." Annual tuition at the state four-year campuses has been $3,400.
At Westchester Community College, where tuition was recently increased to $2,450 (about $1,100 less than the average at other community colleges in the state), administrators are also concerned about the impact on their students.
"Hundreds of students could lose access to higher education," said Dr. Joseph N. Hankin, president of Westchester Community College. "If the TAP cut goes through, it will be a disaster for students. If they won't get a third of what they're going to get, it's a burden. Every time we raise tuition by $100, we lose about 1 percent of our student body." 
The governor's proposal would also cut the college's reimbursement about $4.5 million, Dr. Hankin said.
Dr. Hankin is also worried about a less noted feature of the governor's proposal, which has to do with aid that colleges receive for renting space at other sites. 
"We have classes in Roosevelt High School in Yonkers, in Peekskill, at the Cross County shopping center and elsewhere," said Dr. Hankin. "We pay $1.8 million in rent, and we get back about $900,000 from the state. We are the largest renter of space of all the state's community colleges. We stand to lose $4.5 million if the governor's budget goes through."
For Patricia Cann, a student at Westchester Community College who is pursuing a double major in computer science and liberal arts/social science, any financial aid cut is a serious matter.
"I can't get a personal loan," said Ms. Cann, a 23-year-old resident of Patterson, in Putnam County. "I depend on federal grants and state aid to go to W.C.C. If I can't find the money, I can't attend."

HEADLINE: THE THEATER WALKOUT: IMPACT; 
Theaters Silent, Rest of Broadway Shudders

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The musicians' strike that has shut down much of Broadway began taking its toll on theater-district businesses yesterday as restaurants and hotels started fielding cancellations.
 Some economists said that if settled quickly, the strike would inflict only limited damage on the city's economy over all. Others said that if it dragged on past the weekend, losses would snowball, especially considering the collateral damage to restaurants, hotels, taxis, group ticket agents and other businesses dependent upon Broadway. 
 "Even though the theaters themselves aren't a huge part of the local economy, they are part of the economy that draws people to New York," said Ronnie Lowenstein, director of the Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan city agency. "Tourism has a multiplier effect that lots of economic activity doesn't, because it's money that wouldn't be here otherwise." 
The theaters and producers yesterday estimated the cost to the theaters alone at more than $1 million for every performance missed at the 18 theaters that have been closed by the strike. That translates into $4 million to $5 million in lost ticket sales for the weekend, said Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers.
Cristyne L. Nicholas, president of NYC & Company, the city's tourism office, said a rough estimate of the city's overall losses for the weekend was about $7.2 million.
At Orso, a restaurant on West 46th Street with a reputation for being booked weeks in advance, Kevin Albert, the manager, said at least half of all the reservations for yesterday and for lunch today had been canceled.
Many worried about the possibility of further tarnish to the city's image.
"It's also the negative image that this sends about New York City," Ms. Nicholas said. "You look at the stories in today's papers about all these people that have planned for months and years to come to Broadway. This is very damaging."
She added: "What we've learned with tourism is there are other cities that are competing for our business. They have bigger budgets and better means to compete, and they also have Broadway. It's not the real Broadway, but they have Broadway productions in other cities. I don't think we can take this lightly."
The tourism industry in New York City is not easy to quantify. Some economists said it remains a relatively small part of the city's economy, dwarfed even in hard times by such industries as finance, business services and health care. But others insisted that Broadway's influence is greater than it appears, even if difficult to measure, because it draws outsiders into the city, bringing with them outside money. Ms. Nicholas said there were 300,000 tourism jobs, and she put direct tourism spending at $17 billion a year. Barbara Byrne Denham, an economist who writes The New York STAT, an economic newsletter, had a more conservative estimate of the number of people employed in the industry -- 200,000 -- which still makes up about 5.5 percent of the city's economy.
Jason Bram, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who published a paper on tourism and the city's economy in the mid-1990's, said tourism accounted for a relatively small share of economic activity. The city's economy is driven by the financial sector, and by such things as broadcasting and publishing, he said.
As for the musicians' strike, he said, "I can't imagine it having any measurable effect on the city's economy or even much of a psychological impact outside those individuals that it's close to or the industry itself." He added, "It would seem to me that going to see musicals is something people would postpone rather than just scrap."
The last Broadway strike, in 1975, lasted three weeks. Nine musicals were forced to go dark, Mr. Bernstein said. When the strike was settled, he said, all of the shows reopened and ran for at least the rest of the season. But he said it was unknown whether that would happen again in light of the weak economy, the possibility of war and the competitive nature of entertainment.
"We have twice as many shows open on Broadway now than we did then," Mr. Bernstein said. "We have a much stronger and vibrant Off-Broadway community. Television, movies, virtual reality: the entertainment menu has expanded so drastically that the opportunity for people to find other entertainment options has increased exponentially."
At the Hotel Edison on West 47th Street, only one person had called to cancel citing the strike, the resident manager, John J. Gleeson, said. He said nearly one-third of all weekend guests came for the theater. At McHales, a bar at Eighth Avenue and 46th Street, the manager, Bob DeMange, said more than half of his business was theater-related. "It'll be disastrous today and tomorrow and I think in general because of no theater," he said. "It's terrible. Everyone wants to go back to work, I'm sure, and I just hope they end it as soon as possible."
Bruce Sterman, an owner of two Manhattan Chili Company restaurants -- one on West 43rd Street, the other on Broadway at 53rd Street -- was busy making contingency plans. He said he had toyed with everything from asking his landlords for a rent reprieve to pumping up his delivery business, screening movie musicals and moving into wholesaling vegetarian chili. "Coming after 9/11, we just got back to a decent level of business," he said. "And the economy has started to tank. And we've got the no-smoking law coming in and I don't know what that's going to do to business. And now this.
"My wife and I looked at each other this morning, we're just shaking our heads," he said. "In any case, I feel like it's a challenge to my entrepreneurialism."
