HEADLINE: Merrill Plans To Change TV Channels For Brokers 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
Responding to the anger of some of its employees over how CNBC has depicted the firm, Merrill Lynch & Company is changing channels for more than 20,000 of them.
 Starting next week, employees of Merrill's brokerage operation, the biggest in the nation, will no longer be able to watch CNBC on their desktop computers. Instead, the firm will provide Bloomberg Television, broadcast by Bloomberg L.P., the company founded by New York's mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg. 
 Merrill employees said the switch was spurred, at least in part, by the reactions of some of Merrill's 14,000 brokers and some executives to what has been said about the company by CNBC commentators. Lawrence Kudlow and James J. Cramer, the co-hosts of an evening talk show, have been among the firm's harshest critics. 
Mr. Kudlow has called for the resignations of itschairman, David H. Komansky, and its chief executive, E. Stanley O'Neal. Mr. Cramer, who also writes columns for TheStreet.com, a financial Web site he co-founded, has repeatedly discussed the possibility that Merrill might fail because of its involvement with Enron. Merrill said last month that it had agreed to pay $80 million to end an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into two unusual transactions with Enron in 1999.
James Wiggins, a Merrill spokesman, attributed the desire for change to the brokers and said the switch would not affect what other employees, like stock traders and investment bankers, watch.
"This is in response to popular demand," Mr. Wiggins said. "Our financial advisers have asked for a different video feed on their desktops."
Dropping CNBC for a competitor would have been unimaginable just a few years ago. One of the first cable channels to concentrate on financial news, CNBC was the center stage in the bull market of the 1990's, the favorite venue of dot-com chief executives and the analysts who recommended their stocks.
But CNBC's audience has shrunk since then, and the network has been criticized for helping to inflate the technology-stock bubble that burst three years ago. Indeed, Bloomberg executives contend that their programming -- essentially nonstop commentary on financial markets and corporate developments -- is more popular than CNBC's.
Bloomberg's biggest handicap is that it is available 24 hours only on digital cable TV systems, which are more expensive than standard cable service and not available everywhere. The channel is shown nationwide from 5 a.m. to 8 a.m. weekdays on the USA Network.
During the first two hours of that broadcast, Bloomberg draws a larger audience than does CNBC: averaging 99,000 households compared with 53,000 for CNBC, according to Bloomberg. But at 7 a.m., when CNBC starts showing its main morning program, "Squawk Box," the situation changes. From 7 a.m. to 8 a.m., CNBC is watched in 93,000 households, on average, compared with 67,000 for Bloomberg.
"Our TV is for people that can't not watch," said David Wachtel, director of Bloomberg Media. "There's no question that our product is designed for the serious professional." But, he added, "The TV that's for the professional is for everbody."
A CNBC spokeswoman, Amy Zelvin, declined to comment and said that neither Mr. Kudlow nor Mr. Cramer would comment.
Bloomberg's programming will be piped directly to the brokers' computers, about 30,000 screens worldwide. The brokers will be able to monitor the television feed in a corner of the screen while studying clients' accounts or researching investments.
Mr. Wiggins said that Merrill would pay less for Bloomberg's service than it has paid for CNBC's, but he said that cost was only one of several reasons for the change.
Merrill is a passive, minority investor in Bloomberg L.P., but Mr. Wiggins said that stake did not affect the decision. Merrill recently chose one of Bloomberg's competitors, Thomson Financial, to provide a new computer system for its brokers. Bloomberg TV will be available on that system when Merrill starts installing it later this year, Mr. Wiggins said.
Not all Wall Street firms choose a single TV feed for their brokers. Morgan Stanley, which has about 12,000 brokers, offers them a choice of four channels: CNBC, Bloomberg, CNN and CNNfn. One Morgan Stanley employee said he had been surprised to see how many of the firm's brokers chose to watch Bloomberg over the other channels.
Neither Smith Barney nor UBS PaineWebber provides a TV feed to its brokers' computers, representatives for those firms said.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DISCORD; 
France to Veto Resolution On Iraq War, Chirac Says

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: PARIS, March 10 

 BODY:
In a dramatic break with the United States, President Jacques Chirac said tonight that France would veto a United Nations resolution threatening war against Iraq.
 "My position is that whatever the circumstances, France will vote no," Mr. Chirac said. He added that he had "the feeling" that Russia and China, which also have veto power in the Security Council, are prepared to follow France's lead. 
 Speaking calmly and deliberately during a live television interview in Elysee Palace this evening, Mr. Chirac said he was convinced that the United Nations inspections process was working and that Iraq could be stripped of its dangerous weapons without war.
"The inspectors say that cooperation has improved and that they are in a position to pursue their work," Mr. Chirac said. "This is what is essential. It's not up to you or me to say if the inspections are working."
He added, "We refuse to follow a path that will lead automatically to war as long as the inspectors don't say to us, 'We can't go any further.' "
For the United States to wage war without the assent of the international community would set "a dangerous precedent," Mr. Chirac warned.
Mr. Chirac offered Washington a way out, crediting the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf region and the threat of force for forcing the Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, to disarm.
"They have deployed 200,000 troops; they have already won," Mr. Chirac exclaimed. "I have had the chance to tell this already to President Bush."
Washington is not likely to see it that way. To Mr. Bush, the inspections process can never succeed in disarming Iraq. Only the overthrow of Mr. Hussein will do that.
To Mr. Chirac, American military pressure has allowed the inspectors to succeed in the process of disarming Iraq, and their request last week for more time to continue their work must be respected.
Indeed, Mr. Chirac acknowledged that Mr. Hussein needed to cooperate more with inspectors searching for his weapons of mass destruction. "It's not for you or me to say whether the inspections are effective, if Iraq is sufficiently cooperative -- it is not, by the way, I'll tell you that right away," he said.
Mr. Chirac seemed impervious to the warning by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell on American television on Sunday that a French veto would seriously harm bilateral relations. "I am totally convinced of the opposite," he said, adding at another point that France is "not at all in conflict with the United States."
He dismissed threats of an American-led economic embargo against France -- which has been proposed by a number of American lawmakers -- saying that in an age of globalization, such actions no longer make sense.
Mr. Chirac sat behind a long, delicate desk opposite the two interviewers from the TF1 and France 2 television channels and fiddled with a blue pen throughout the 35-minute interview.
If the United States brings the resolution to a vote, as it has promised, and France vetoes it, it would be the first time France voted against the United States since the 1956 Suez crisis.
However, Mr. Chirac also indicated that France might not have to use its veto power because, he said, the resolution did not have the necessary nine votes for passage.
Mr. Chirac spoke on a day of furious global diplomacy, as President Bush and Mr. Powell worked the phones to build foreign support for the pending, American-drafted resolution that would authorize war if Baghdad fails to surrender all its weapons of mass destruction by March 17.
Meanwhile, the French foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin, traveled to three African countries that currently sit on the Security Council -- Angola, Cameroon and Guinea -- in the hope of persuading them to oppose the war resolution. Mr. de Villepin has said repeatedly that a vast majority of the world is against the war, and would like to prove that point by winning the vote in the United Nations.
However, Mr. de Villepin today failed to secure backing for the French position during a brief stop in Angola. Foreign Minister Joao Bernardo de Miranda said that war on Iraq now seemed inevitable, and hinted that Angola would abstain. "The position of Angola is to back neither France nor the United States," Mr. Bernardo de Miranda said.
In Cameroon, the foreign minister, Francois-Xavier Ngoubeyou, refused to comment on how his country would vote.

HEADLINE: THE THEATER WALKOUT: OVERVIEW; 
MAYOR INTERVENES IN THEATER STRIKE

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg summoned Broadway musicians and producers to Gracie Mansion last night for round-the-clock negotiations and appointed a mediator to help resolve the strike that has darkened all but one major musical.
 To mediate the dispute, the mayor called on Frank J. Macchiarola, the former chancellor of the New York City public schools, who was a member of Mr. Bloomberg's transition team and has often played a diplomatic role in municipal matters. 
 "I am encouraged that theater owners, producers and the musicians' union have taken the city up on its offer," the mayor said yesterday. "I am determined that they reach an agreement so Broadway can come back to life." 
Both sides reported to Gracie Mansion about 9 o'clock last night with the assumption that they would essentially not leave the room until they came out with a settlement.
Though Mr. Bloomberg has no official jurisdiction in the dispute, he brings the political influence of his job. Concerned about the mounting economic losses from the strike, he is following in the footsteps of Mayor Abraham D. Beame, who helped settle the last musicians' strike in 1975 with lengthy negotiations at Gracie Mansion. That strike lasted 25 days.
Both producers and musicians said they were grateful for the city's intervention and optimistic about a settlement. "For the good of Broadway and for all of New York City, we are prepared to negotiate night and day to achieve a fair and equitable settlement so we can go on with the show," the producers said in a statement. Bill Moriarity, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said, "We're happy that the mayor got involved in this, and we look forward to working through the night."
Reached as he was about to be briefed on the dispute, Dr. Macchiarola said, "I'm happy to do whatever I can to get this resolved amicably."
The mayor at first appeared reluctant to become involved, suggesting on Sunday that the two sides needed to come to an agreement on their own. This frustrated at least some producers who said privately that a call from the mayor would easily embarrass both parties into returning to the table, relieving either side of having to make the first move.
The main issue leading to the musicians' walkout on Friday was the minimum number of musicians required in the orchestra pit at Broadway's largest theaters, which is 24 to 26 under the current contract.
The talks broke down Friday night when the actors and stagehands joined the musicians' strike. The producers then made what they called a final offer of 15 musicians and canceled Broadway musicals for the weekend. In recent days, the producers had privately expressed a willingness to settle for a minimum of 18. The musicians had indicated that they would consider 20 to 24.
Much of Broadway has been dark for four days, except Off Broadway shows and dramatic plays. Just one major musical remains open: "Cabaret," which has a different contract because it is performed at Studio 54, the former dance club, rather than in a traditional theater.
Early yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg made calls to Mr. Moriarity and Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, which represents the producers.
"I offered to do whatever possible to help resolve the issues that remain between the two parties," Mr. Bloomberg said. "I pointed out to them the severe economic impact on a city still recovering from the terrible tragedy of the Sept. 11 attack, the financial hardships being experienced by those employed in this and related industries, and the disappointment of theatergoers from around the world that the strike was causing."
Cristyne L. Nicholas, the president of NYC and Company, the city's tourism bureau, applauded the mayor for trying to avoid a strike that she estimated was costing the city $7 million a day. "It's some hope we have on the horizon," she said. "This has been a very painful but self-inflicted wound which I believe will start to heal tonight."
Dr. Macchiarola, the president of St. Francis College in Brooklyn, was schools chancellor from 1978 to 1983. He served on the Charter Revision Commission and was chairman of the Districting Commission that redrew New York's political map. He also spent five years at the New York City Partnership, a civic group of business executives. 
The mayor's decision to take a prominent role was unusual. In the past, he has made a point of steering clear of labor conflicts, while at the same time working behind the scenes. Even as Mr. Bloomberg was saying publicly that the city should have no role in the dispute between bus company workers and their private employers last June, for example, the city's labor negotiators were quietly working toward a settlement. The mayor was more visible in the recent brush with a transit strike, often criticizing the union for its high demands. His current labor relations with the city workers are strained because he has threatened layoffs. 
City Hall officials say Mr. Bloomberg decided to take an aggressive stance with Broadway because of his sense of economic urgency.
"Obviously the idea that musical Broadway is shut down, we see as having an economic impact on the city," said William T. Cunningham, the mayor's communications director. "It is not a normal dispute between private companies and entities, and the mayor can offer his good offices to sit and talk and come to a productive resolution of the problem."

HEADLINE: $25 AND UNDER; 
In the Village, a Seafood Place Loosens Its Tie

BYLINE:  By Eric Asimov

 BODY:
WHEN Fish opened about three years ago in the heart of Greenwich Village, I couldn't figure out what to make of it. Ambition seemed to clash with ambience, producing a dissonant muddle. 
 The little storefront had a simple, direct name and the welcome air of a waterfront dive. Oysters and whole fish glistened on ice in the front, where a small retail operation was set up at the end of a bar. In the rear was a narrow dining room. It was attractively humble, with a worn mosaic floor that looked as if it could tell tales from the days when sailors really sailed. Yet the food seemed contrived and expensive, as if a stubborn chef could not let go of a grand vision. Complex food at odds with modest surroundings can be romantic, but not here. It just felt inhibited. 
 So I was surprised and pleased a month or so ago when I walked past Fish and noticed a new simpler menu that focused on chowders, an expanded raw bar, lobster rolls and grilled fish. When I returned on a Saturday night, it was clear that the starched white tablecloth had been tossed aside, revealing the boisterous oyster bar within. The place was packed and loud, bouncing to the beat of Little Walter's "Juke." The bar was dim and smoky, the beer was flowing, and the illusion of waterfront dissolution, which gives oyster bars such character, was intact.
Edward Taylor, Fish's owner, also owns Down East Seafood, a wholesaler. His partner in Fish left recently, leaving Mr. Taylor free to change the place. Of course, the tottering post-Sept. 11 economy made his wish for a stripped-down menu sensible.
The menu is still a little too long, but I can't think of a place where I've had fresher or better oysters on the half shell ($8 to $12 a half-dozen), at least recently. The East Coast oysters are especially good now, like clean, saline Spinney Creeks, and meaty, minerally Blue Points. West Coast selections like deeply cupped Kumamotos and creamy Fanny Bays seem more sedate, with mildly briny, cucumbery notes. The flavors are so pure I like to eat the oysters unadorned, though I wish the small wine list included a muscadet, a natural accompaniment for oysters.
Simple dishes are the best, like a New England chowder ($5 a cup, $7 a bowl) chock full of clams, and an excellent, compact lobster roll ($16), with lots of lemon-scented meat and sides of terrific fries and slightly sweet cole slaw. Shrimp cocktail ($8) is unusually flavorful, and the crab cakes ($9 appetizer, $18 main) are some of the best I've had, big and meaty, crisp at the edges with a faint taste of Worcestershire in the mix. A fried clam roll ($12) was disappointing, the clams -- strips, not bellies -- tough and leathery.
I loved scallop ceviche ($10), the scallop sliced thin and marinated in lime, with slivers of jalapeno for a jolt. A fried oyster appetizer ($9) is enhanced by a foaming ginger-and-soy sauce. 
A busy weekend night may not be the best time to sample dishes that require precision cooking. A thin yellowfin tuna steak ($16) was undistinguished, while spicy lobster fra diavolo ($18) was done in by gummy linguine. A dish like lobster shepherd's pie ($18) simply raises the issue of why you would put perfectly good lobster meat in a pot pie. I don't have an answer.
On a calmer weeknight, whole roasted sea bream ($15) was perfectly cooked and pleasing. But crayfish with tomato sauce and rice, masquerading as crayfish Creole ($16), lacked subtlety or complexity.
Even so, I love the casual, rakish feel of Fish, the waiters in white aprons, the rickety tables, the scent of horseradish in the air. Yes, the ambition may be gone, but the romance beats it by a mile. 

Fish
280 Bleecker Street (Jones Street) Greenwich Village, (212) 727-2879

BEST DISHES -- Oysters on the half shell, clam chowder, lobster roll, shrimp cocktail, crab cakes, scallop ceviche, fried oysters, sea bream.
PRICE RANGE -- Appetizers, $5 to $12; main courses, $9 to $28 (for a steak).
CREDIT CARDS -- All major cards.
HOURS -- Sunday through Thursday, noon to midnight. Friday and Saturday, noon to 1 a.m.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Narrow entrance, restrooms are downstairs.

HEADLINE: Can You Put a Price Tag on Liberty? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "New Scale for Toting Up Lost Freedom vs. Security Would Measure in Dollars" (news article, March 11): 
 So now we will all have a price on our heads. The Office of Management and Budget wants to assign monetary values to the loss of liberty and the loss of privacy associated with increased security measures.
This is another example of the Bush administration's misguided tendency to see everything in economic terms.
When the almighty dollar is the only yardstick that we have, we will draw misleading -- and dangerous, potentially disastrous -- conclusions.
The damage that we're doing to our society and to our reputation abroad is immeasurable. 
As my mother used to say, some things are not for sale.

BILL KASDORF
Ann Arbor, Mich., March 11, 2003

HEADLINE: Yankee Inn, English Charm, French Approval 

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: CHAGFORD, England 

 BODY:
ONE Friday night in March 1978, an American couple opened a small hotel, lost amid the hills, hedgerows and twisting lanes of Devon, in southwestern England. It was a four-hour expedition by train or car from London.
 Equipped only with high hopes, a few pieces of antique furniture, a small but choice wine collection, a sketchy knowledge of haute cuisine picked up in the star-spangled restaurants of France and an improbably large bank loan, they seemed ill-suited to the task they set for themselves: turning a rundown mock-Tudor house, idyllically sited at the foot of bleakly beautiful Dartmoor, into one of Europe's premier inns, with food worth the trip. 
 Against the odds, they succeeded. Kay Henderson, then 37, handled the pots and pans at first, at a time when few women worked in top professional kitchens. Paul Henderson, then 39, a former management consultant and like his wife a graduate of Purdue University in Indiana, handled the books and the cellar. 
Three years after opening, their hotel, Gidleigh Park, won a star in the Michelin red guide -- the first ever awarded to Americans, as far as anyone knows -- and, 18 years after that, a second. They survived economic slumps, including the one that followed 9/11, and a devastating regional foot-and-mouth epidemic.
Last week, 25 years and eight house cats later, the Hendersons celebrated by inviting former chefs, former managers and a few longtime clients, myself among them, to return for a house party. For the occasion, they paved their notoriously potholed half-mile-long driveway for the first time since setting up shop, and uncorked one or more 1978 vintages each evening, including a sumptuous Leoville Barton.
Naturally, it rained quite a lot.
No matter. The landscape -- cited last week by Country Life magazine in naming Devon "England's best county" -- glowed wondrously. The sheep nibbled the luxuriant grass on the patchwork hillsides, and from time to time a romantic painter's shaft of light knifed through the mist.
Michael Caines, the incumbent chef, produced some of his own specialties, including local venison in a sticky, peppery sauce, with chestnuts, baby fennel and tea-soaked raisins one night, and rare roast pigeon with a potato galette in an elegantly balanced Madeira sauce another night. He also produced his own versions of fish dishes introduced by several predecessors, like Shaun Hill's scallops with lentils and coriander sauce and John Webber's monkfish on a bed of cucumber with grain mustard sauce.
When Gidleigh opened, Mr. Henderson drove his old Volvo to London once a week for supplies, and dishes that could be produced from staples, like a carrot timbale, had a prominent place on the menu. Mr. Webber described a roast pineapple dessert as "end-of-the-week pudding." Now carefully nurtured networks bring in raw materials from every corner of the kingdom.
One constant: superb cheeses from neighboring farms. I tasted Quickes Traditional Cheddar on my first visit in 1980 and again this time. Now famous around the world, it has been made for 400-plus years on a farm just 15 miles away, in Newton St. Cyres.
Bill Baker, one of the guests, commented that "great hotels are all about memories, good times and the people that you've met." He should know; a celebrated wine merchant, he met his wife, Kate, who was then the hotel's front-of-the-house manager, during a sales call here. 
For my wife, Betsey, and me, the Lucullan memories include the first night of our honeymoon, in 1982; my 50th birthday party, in 1984, a modest affair of nine courses, five 1934 wines and a 1934 Armagnac; and a night when, without Betsey, who would have known better, I helped demolish a salmanazar of Champagne (12 bottles in one) in commemoration of not much of anything.
Mr. and Mrs. Henderson's exacting standards have never wavered.
"From the first day I came here in 1980," the soft-spoken Mr. Webber told me, "I sensed a real clarity of purpose and an aversion to coasting."
Matthew Fort, the food editor of The Guardian, who was another of the guests, compares Gidleigh to Coleridge's Xanadu -- a "stately pleasure-dome" girded by "gardens bright with sinuous rills, where blossomed many an incense-bearing tree." Wood smoke rises from the chimneys 365 days a year, contributing ahaunting aroma, and the burbling little North Teign River, hurrying down from the moor, provides music to fall asleep by. Last week the snowdrops and daffodils were in bloom; the towering rhododendrons will flower in May.
Gum boots stand by the front door, and chintz covers the sofas. But this is a fantasy English country house. Real ones have dog hairs everywhere. They are not as well heated, their plumbing is not as efficient -- and, Lord knows, their cooking bears not the slightest resemblance to Mr. Caines's.

(Photographs by Jonathan Player for The New York Times); FROM PURDUE TO DEVON -- Kay and Paul Henderson, the American owners of Gidleigh Park, have been innkeepers for 25 years. (pg. F6)

HEADLINE: Restaurants On the Fringe, And Thriving 

BYLINE:  By JANELLE BROWN

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
IT was 9 o'clock on a Friday night at Mamasan's Bistro in the Mission District and the food was running a little late, but no one seemed to mind. Two dozen diners perched on folding chairs, listening to a hip-hop D.J. spin classic De La Soul in the glow of the Christmas lights dangling overhead. The restaurant's proprietor, a willowy 37-year-old woman who would reveal only her first name, Lynette, was in the kitchen placidly doctoring coconut yams on her crowded four-burner stove.
 "This place has become my second home," said Carlos Castille, an artist, as he sipped a coconut-mango cocktail. "There's a comfort to it. It's so mellow. I've brought all my friends." 
 But securing a seat at Mamasan's is not easy. The restaurant, which also happens to be Lynette's apartment, has no sign, and the only way you will ever find it is if someone tells you where it is (a quiet street, a hidden door, up a dark stairwell to the top apartment). Even then, you can't just show up: you must have an invitation. To get one you need an introduction from a previous guest. This may seem as if it's a complicated way to get a plate of grilled salmon, but Mamasan's Bistro is not a legal endeavor. Its kitchen lacks the certificates, permits and inspections required by the city of San Francisco. And although the coconut-mango cocktails flowed, Lynette does not have a liquor license.
Mamasan's is not, however, an anomaly. Restaurants of dubious legality, where food is cooked in apartments and backyards, abound across the United States. These underground restaurants range from upscale to gritty, and are born from youthful idealism, ethnic tradition or economic necessity. They lack certification from any government agency and are, strictly speaking, against the law. You dine in them at your own risk. If you can find them.
Over the last four years, Lynette said, more than a thousand customers have come through her doors to eat pungent Chamorran dishes from Guam, where she was raised in the local Chamorro culture. She cooks them with her 61-year-old mother, the Mamasan of the restaurant's name.
"I've worked at restaurants for years, and dealing with the public is a beast," Lynette said. "You don't get to edit who comes into your space, and it becomes a very sterile exchange of goods. I like knowing who is coming, and whether they understand what I'm doing."
Lynette describes her restaurant as a kind of "party" -- albeit one that comes with a bill -- and many underground restaurateurs harbor similar visions. Most chefs, after all, cook because they want to feed people great meals, but in the end, the compliments of satisfied diners are not always compensation for the headaches of running a business. 
Club Azteca, in a private home in San Pablo, Calif., is open only on Saturday mornings. Customers sometimes drive hours for its menudo and lamb birria. Azteca, which starts serving at 6 a.m., is about eight months old.
"My parents used to run a restaurant before, but it was never as much fun as this," said Erika Carravieri, 30, who helps her parents operate the place. "Everyone drinks and sings, and at 6 o'clock in the morning! When they were running a restaurant, my mom aged so much in a year." 
Gray hair is exactly what Michael Hebbe and Naomi Pomeroy hoped to avoid when they started Ripe in Portland, Ore. The young couple had cooked at a number of the city's better-known restaurants and knew, they said, how deflating and impersonal the professional cooking experience could be.
"The kitchen is demeaning," Mr. Hebbe said. "You cook for people you don't see. All you hear from guests is, 'This is undercooked' or 'This needs to be redone.' That environment doesn't seem sustainable or healthy, which is why the staff turnover at restaurants is so incredible."
Ripe, in contrast, was conceived three years ago as a twice-a-month supper club for a select group of guests. Their first night, Mr. Hebbe and Ms. Pomeroy served 22 people in their living-room-turned-dining room. Within months they had an online mailing list in the thousands and a bustling catering business.
Ripe recently moved into a tiny licensed commercial kitchen in the back of a downtown office building and is now, Mr. Hebbe said, "fairly legal." Guests pay $20 (not including wine and dessert) to eat cassoulet or risotto served out of communal bowls.
After only two years of business, Mr. Hebbe says that Ripe is also profitable, which is more than most new restaurants can say. Mr. Hebbe attributes this to Ripe's underground roots. After all, he did not have to make an initial investment in a building or lay out a bundle for licenses, or insurance, or marketing, or staff. Starting a restaurant from scratch, depending on ambition and location, can cost hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars.
"The startup cost of most operations is astronomical," Mr. Hebbe said. "It's impossible to do it by the book and make money in your first three to five years."
Working underground can also be a way for a would-be restaurateur to test the waters of professional cooking. Joseph DeSalazar, 27, an advertising executive, runs a sporadically open restaurant called Foodies, serving dinner in various rented lofts in New York City. He ventured into his floating concern after spending his weekends volunteering in the kitchens at Cafe Boulud and 11 Madison Park. "With Foodies, I didn't feel like I was making a lifelong commitment," he said. "It isn't a fixed location, I don't have any expectations to live up to, and it can change every time."
Many underground concerns are born of neighborhood necessity. According to Jim Leff, a food critic who founded the Web site Chowhound.com, apartment-based restaurants are common among Brazilian and African families who live in immigrant communities in Queens. One family, he said, might make it its business to prepare cheap takeout meals for an entire apartment building. 
"They are filling a niche that isn't filled by restaurants," Mr. Leff said, "doing it in areas where there are no restaurants, doing it at lower price points, or serving traditional dishes that restaurants are afraid to serve because they are too unusual."
Most underground restaurants are a simple matter of economic necessity. Mr. Leff's favorite, he said, is the domain of a "genius" cook who once ran the "best Venezuelan restaurant in New York." After that restaurant closed in a dispute between business partners, the cook could not afford to open her own establishment, so she began cooking out of the basement of her house in Queens.
"I've eaten there on card tables," Mr. Leff said. "She is basically a homeless chef. Housing is not the only thing that's being priced out of the league of real people."
The downside of running an underground restaurant is, of course, the chance of getting caught by the licensing authorities. Laws vary from state to state; in California, a dining establishment must comply with local zoning restrictions and be inspected by the fire department, the liquor authority and the health department. In addition, a state-certified "food handler" must be on staff at all times. New York has comparable requirements.
"It's all about how to avoid making people sick," said Jack Breslin, director of the consumer protection program at the San Francisco health department. "If no one is looking over my shoulder to see how I'm storing, processing and serving my food, the greater the risk of something bad happening."
And although the health department, at least in San Francisco, probably will not throw underground restaurateurs in jail, it will shut them down if it sniffs them out, which is one reason most advertise only by word of mouth. (Mr. Leff recommends asking taxi drivers.) On Internet sites like Chowhound.com, diners often lament the passing of beloved underground boites, like the Blue Tarp Thai restaurant in West Philadelphia, where until this summer, students and professors from the University of Pennsylvania ate green papaya salad at tables in the backyard of the Phanthavong family's row house.
Sunny Phanthavong, 18, said the family knew their restaurant was illegal, "but thought we were doing something positive for the community." After several years in business, they were discovered by an observant police officer. "He was writing a ticket for someone who was eating outside while parked illegally, and saw through the gate," Ms. Phanthavong explained.
In November, after receiving a loan from a community-oriented university program, the family reopened legally as the Vientiane Cafe, but it is not the same, Ms. Phanthavong said. "I miss the old days of the backyard," she said.
Another drawback to the business of running an underground restaurant is the simple wear and tear that occurs when strangers troop through your home. Over the years, Lynette of Mamasan's Bistro has lost, she said, "pretty much every good CD" she has owned to light-fingered guests. And one reason Mr. Hebbe in Portland decided to move Ripe into a licensed kitchen was concern about his white carpets. "Every two weeks our living room got ripped out to make space for tables," he said, "and then we had to tear it down and clean up, and then two weeks later do it again. And we had to wash every single dish by hand."
He may someday look back on those days of constant furniture rearranging and dish-water hands with fondness. Veva Edelson began her career running an illegal cafe in her home in Arcata, Calif., cooking vegetarian cuisine at bargain-basement prices. Today, although a co-owner of Firefly, a well-reviewed, popular and quite legal restaurant in San Francisco, she is sometimes nostalgic for its predecessor. "I have dreams that I'm moving Firefly into my mother's living room and that it's now a one-night-a-week restaurant, off the books and cash only, where people just come and enjoy themselves," she said. "There's so much less expectation when something is amateur."
Up in her crowded apartment, Lynette occasionally thinks about making Mamasan's legitimate. Last year, she looked into a restaurant space, but became discouraged when she realized that it would cost $250,000 to renovate it and bring it up to code. So Mamasan's continues as a part-time restaurant that, while barely taking in enough money to cover the rent, has the virtue of retaining its personal touch.
"I do it for the love, mostly," she said. "I don't exactly want to boast that I have an illegal establishment in my house, but this is how artists survive."

(Basil Childers)(pg. 7); ONE WAY TO START -- Veva Edelson, left, began her career running an underground restaurant out of her home in Northern California; she now runs a legitimate restaurant, Firefly, in San Francisco. Right, patrons gather in Mamasan's Bistro, an underground restaurant in an apartment in the Mission District of San Francisco. (Photographs by Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)(pg. F7)

HEADLINE: China Buys Another Piece Of Big Caspian Sea Oil Field 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 11 

 BODY:
For the second time in four days, a Chinese state-owned enterprise has agreed to buy a stake in a huge oil field in the Caspian Sea, expanding China's drive to secure reliable oil supplies.
 The deal, announced today by the Sinopec Group, is identical to the one concluded on Friday by CNOOC Ltd.: $615 million for a one-twelfth stake in the North Caspian Sea project in Kazakhstan. The project includes the Kashagan field, thought to hold as much oil as the North Slope of Alaska, and four other current or projected oil and gas fields. In both cases, the seller is the BG Group of Britain. 
 The investments will not help China if war in Iraq disrupts the oil market: production is not scheduled to start at Kashagan for two years, and it will not reach full output for several years after that.
Still, the Sinopec and CNOOC purchases are the biggest steps China has taken to limit its fast-growing dependence on oil from the Persian Gulf. China's domestic oil production has leveled off, with no sign of any further large discoveries to come in an already well-explored country. But the economy is expanding 8 percent a year, car ownership is becoming more common and oil consumption is rising briskly. 
Chinese involvement raises the possibility that some of the oil from the Caspian project could be piped eastward across Kazakhstan and western China to the population centers of eastern China. Mark Qiu, CNOOC's chief financial officer, said that existing pipelines could handle the low initial output from the Caspian fields, but that a decision on a new pipeline route would be needed when the new fields are closer to full production.
CNOOC is China's offshore oil company. Sinopec is mainly an oil refiner and petrochemical producer; it also operates many of China's gas stations. David Chin, an investment banker at UBS Warburg who represented Sinopec in the deal, said of the company, "They want to become a more balanced group with more upstream, midstream and downstream businesses."
BG, one of the earliest investors in the alliance developing the North Caspian project, has now sold all of its one-sixth stake in the two deals. Oil industry analysts had criticized BG for concentrating too many of its assets in Kazakhstan, especially as the large scale of the Kashagan field became clear.
The project alliance, led by Eni of Italy, also includes Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell, TotalFinaElf, ConocoPhillips and Inpex. These partners have what is called a pre- emption right, entitling them to pre- empt BG's sale to the two Chinese companies and buy BG out themselves by matching the terms offered to CNOOC and Sinopec. 
Mr. Qiu of CNOOC said in a telephone interview that adding Sinopec to the equation today reduced the chances that the other partners in the project would exercise their pre-emption rights. The existing partners are already obliged to invest large sums toward the more than $20 billion needed to put the Kashagan field into production; buying BG's shares would make them responsible for even more of a large, possibly risky investment, Mr. Qiu said.
One confusing difference between the CNOOC and Sinopec deals involves the units used to make the acquisitions. In CNOOC's case, the purchase is being made by a publicly traded subsidiary, CNOOC Ltd., based in Hong Kong, which is flush with profits from the high oil prices, not by the wholly state-owned parent in Beijing, known simply as CNOOC.
The situation is reversed with Sinopec: the state-owned Beijing parent, the Sinopec Group, is the buyer, not the Sinopec Corporation, which is publicly traded here and in New York, London and Shanghai. 
Philip Andrews-Speed, an expert on the Chinese oil industry at the University of Dundee in Scotland, said that using the state-owned parent would make it easier for Beijing to subsidize the deal for national security reasons at a time when high crude prices are hurting refiners, who have trouble passing them on to customers. 
But Mr. Chin said that Sinopec decided long ago to handle acquisitions of foreign oil exploration and production operations through its Beijing parent, and that the government was not involved in the choice.

HEADLINE: Indonesia Is Urged to Intervene in Company Loan Debacle 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, March 11 

 BODY:
The United States, Japan, Canada and eight European nations have written to the Indonesian president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, urging her to intervene in efforts to recover $6.5 billion in loans from Asia Pulp and Paper. The company, a family-owned conglomerate at the center of one of Asia's biggest and longest-running financial debacles, defaulted on $13.9 billion in debt in 2001.
 Creditors appear to be drawing close to a deal to restructure the debts of the four Indonesian units of Asia Pulp and Paper. But they remain at loggerheads with the Indonesian authorities over safeguards against a second default, according to a person close to the European export agencies involved in the negotiations. 
 A letter signed jointly by the 11 countries' ambassadors in Jakarta is the latest effort by creditors to pin down Asia Pulp and Paper. "We are trying to get the Indonesian government more involved in the restructuring," said Bo Ollison, spokesman for the United States Export-Import Bank, which is owed at least $108 million by Asia Pulp and Paper. "We are still working through the negotiation process and are hopeful that an agreement can be reached." 
But bankers close to the talks said they were doubtful that the letter would gain the creditors much leverage, given the Indonesian government's reputation for inaction and Asia Pulp and Paper's adroitness in thwarting outside efforts to wrest control from its founding family, the Widjajas.
"The family will outlast them all," said a former adviser to Asia Pulp and Paper. 
The letter sent to Mrs. Megawati emphasizes the risk that the company's defiance poses to investors' future willingness to do business in Indonesia.
But bankers in the region say the most remarkable thing about the Asia Pulp and Paper mess is how it has been walled off by the markets.
Most of the company's unpaid creditors are export credit agencies like the Export-Import Bank, or dealers in distressed debt; almost no one else has any tangible stake in the outcome, though a successful resolution would remove a cloud from the general investment climate in Indonesia, the bankers said. 
Looming much larger are questions about how a war in Iraq may affect Indonesia, a predominantly Muslim country with a presidential election due next year. The country's uncertain legal environment, corrupt courts and growing labor unrest are also scaring away foreign direct investment.
Still, the way the government handles Asia Pulp and Paper will grow in importance as the country strives to emerge next year from a $5 billion economic aid program administered by the International Monetary Fund. The export credit agencies, owed about $960 million by the company, have pointed out that Indonesia may need them to help finance an estimated $100 billion in infrastructure projects over the next decade.
"The longer it drags on, and the more complex it becomes, the more difficult it becomes for Indonesia to access international capital markets," said Steven Hess of Moody's Investors Service in New York.
Asia Pulp and Paper is the flagship of the Sinar Mas Group, a conglomerate founded by one of Indonesia's most prominent Chinese immigrants, Eka Tjipta Widjaja, now in his eighties. That his family remains in control, bankers say, is attributable in part to a byzantine corporate structure that has made it possible for the company to play some creditors off against others.
While creditors have been fighting to restructure the $6.5 billion owed by Asia Pulp's units in Indonesia, other creditors have been trying to win control of the holding company in a court in Singapore, where Asia Pulp and Paper is based. Units in China, where Sinar Mas is a major investor, have reportedly reached a separate deal with creditors. Meanwhile, the company and its former auditor, Arthur Andersen, face lawsuits over allegations of accounting irregularities.
The Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency, which became Asia Pulp and Paper's largest single creditor when it took control of the Widjajas's bank during the Asian financial crisis in 1999, signed a preliminary restructuring agreement in December with the company. The agency, known as IBRA, wants to finalize that deal by the end of thismonth. But the export credit agencies want an independent company set up to monitor Asia Pulp and Paper's operations and ensure they are repaid, and they want a mechanism that would give creditors control of the company's stock if it defaults again. IBRA reportedly opposes both ideas, and it is not clear what recourse creditors would have if it rejected them.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET-- Poughkeepsie; 
From Hotel, Icehouse and Supply Store to Offices

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
A former hotel on the Hudson River here, once a bustling way station for railroad and steamboat passengers traveling between New York City and Albany, is being renovated as a modern 60,000-square-foot office building.
 The structure's newest incarnation -- it has also been an icehouse, a brewery and most recently the home of a plumbing supply company -- reflects this city's recent efforts to rebuild not only its once-prosperous waterfront but also a local economy that was dealt a serious blow a decade ago by downsizing at I.B.M., which had three plants in the area. 
 The J. D. Johnson building, as it was known from 1938 to 1992, is in a state Empire Zone, a designated economic development area, and includes among its tenants to date R. J. Dooley & Associates, the seven-year-old construction and engineering company that owns the structure and will occupy 30,000 square feet; a law firm that is leasing 3,000 square feet for five years; two restaurants; and the offices of psychologists. 
About 25,000 square feet in the four-story brick and concrete building remains to be leased, said Laura A. Dolfinger, a real estate agent with Christine Jones Realty in nearby Hyde Park. About 4,000 square feet of that is available for retail use. 
Rents at the renovated building are $18 to $20 a square foot annually. Vincent J. DiMaso, a commercial real estate broker for 35 years, said the going rate for prime office space in Poughkeepsie is $18 to $22.
Robert Dooley, who owns R. J. Dooley & Associates, is offering five-year leases with five-year options to renew at the original rental amount adjusted for inflation.
Mr. Dooley purchased the building for $800,000 two years ago from Thomas Johnson, the owner of the plumbing supply company. Mr. Johnson had plans in the mid-1990's to renovate the building for mixed uses -- including a restaurant, retail space and rental apartments -- but the plans did not come to fruition because of legal obstacles, said Steven Tinkelman, the principal architect with Tinkelman Architecture here. Mr. Tinkelman designed plans for Mr. Johnson and for Mr. Dooley.
"The building is one of the last remnants of what the waterfront was during its heyday," Mr. Tinkelman said, explaining that the building, currently known as Dooley Square, is made up of five connected buildings -- including the former hotel and an elaborate brick Victorian warehouse -- that were built from 1845 to 1909.
It is one of few older buildings left in the waterfront neighborhood. "The last of what remained from the earlier years was obliterated in the 1960's, when there was a lack of appreciation for what came before," the architect said. "That was a time when new was considered better."
Mr. Dooley's $4.2 million renovation has included gutting the building; exposing the original wide-board wood flooring, brick walls and fireplaces; and installing an energy-saving geothermal heat pump system, which will cool or heat the structure by transferring heat from the earth in winter and discharging heat from the building to the ground in summer through a system of buried plastic pipes. 
Mr. Dooley said he was retaining "the building's nooks and crannies and warts," because they give it character. But at the same time, he said, the building will have amenities like a sprinkler system, air-conditioning, modern wiring and a tie-in to a local security company. 
Because the building is in an Empire Zone, tenants are eligible for a variety of tax benefits, explained Anne N. Conroy, director of the Poughkeepsie-Dutchess Empire Zone, a nonprofit, public-private partnership for economic development in Dutchess County. The office building is one of only four or five in the Poughkeepsie area that can accommodate a tenant requiring more than 10,000 square feet, Ms. Conroy said, adding that she expected demand for space there to be brisk.
No formal figures are maintained for office vacancy rates in the two-square-mile city, which is the county seat, or the surrounding town of Poughkeepsie. But Mr. DiMaso, the commercial real estate broker and chairman of the External Marketing Council, a division of the city's Economic Development Corporation, estimated the vacancy rate at less than 10 percent. Mr. DiMaso owns seven office buildings in the area, and all are 100 percent filled, he said.
Ms. Dolfinger, the real estate agent, said that because Dooley Square is next door to the Metro-North Railroad station, she is marketing the office space to a broad geographic area. Figures from Metro-North show that on weekdays about 1,600 commuters travel from Poughkeepsie to New York City, a trip that takes 90 minutes on the Hudson Line during rush hour.
Ms. Conroy observed that the office space will be accessible to commuters from points as far south as New York City and as far north as Albany, much as the original Railroad Hotel was in the golden age of the city's waterfront 150 years ago. Today, the former hotel and warehouse should attract financial advisers, lawyers, investors and other professional types who can conduct business electronically from relatively remote locations and travel to the larger cities one or two days a week.

HEADLINE: LETTER FROM ASIA; 
In a Contest of Cultures, East Embraces West

BYLINE:  By Seth Mydans 

DATELINE: MANILA, March 11 

 BODY:
Asian values are universal values. European values are European values.
 That was Malaysia's prime minister, Mahathir Muhamad, speaking before the Asian economic meltdown of 1997, when the region still had some swagger and leaders like Dr. Mahathir were resisting Western pressure for more democracy and human rights. 
 Their argument was that the West was trying to impose alien values that favor individual rights on an ancient culture where the highest value is placed on the welfare of society as a whole. In that respect, Asian values became an assertion of regional identity by nations that had begun to flex their economic muscle and to refine their political systems in a post-colonial world.
Asia, it was argued -- and by extension other regions with their own histories -- has different cultural roots, values and assumptions about society than those of the West. Western values like individual rights, justice and fair play could not simply be applied like templates to countries with such different traditions.
There was more than a touch of arrogance in the argument as well, an insinuation that Asian values were not just different from Western values but better -- for society and for economic growth.
The "Asian values" debate was also partly cynical, an excuse for self-assured autocrats like Dr. Mahathir and Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew to play father-knows-best with their people, setting their bedtimes and making them eat their vegetables without complaint.
Happy in their slipstreams were their favored financiers and developers who found a respectable excuse to evade Western standards involving such things as child labor laws, workers' rights and environmental safeguards.
When Asia was riding high in the 1980's and early 90's -- when the region's economies were expanding by 7 or 8 percent a year -- nobody was in a mood to criticize these "Asian values" -- including thrift and hard work.
But with the economic crash in 1997, the underside of these virtues came into view. The snug relationships among the powerful had bred corruption, cronyism, repression and exploitation.
For a while it seemed that the whole idea of Asian values should be consigned to the dustbin of history. But now, in the wake of the Enron bankruptcy and corporate scandals in the United States, the West is also dealing with cronyism and corruption and a debate of sorts has resumed here over which models of society work best: competition versus consensus; the rule of law versus personal relationships; a dynamic, even rowdy society versus stability and order.
America's apparent willingness to go to war in Iraq to impose a Western democracy there has also revived debate here over attempts to impose the cultural values and political structures of one society on another.
Today, there is a slow, daily tug of war between the old-guard traditionalists -- the former Asian values crowd -- and the insurgents of an open society, who are developing a sort of indigenous version of Western values. 
The clans and oligarchs and strongmen and politburos are struggling to hold their ground against the pressures of a more assertive public. Across the region, interest groups are raising their voices with a striking vigor against everything from deforestation to low factory wages.
But the pressures are not coming as they once did from the West. Rather, the new paradigm seems to be the Asian assertion of what Dr. Mahathir called European values.
It is a Thai environmental lobby that is opposing a large dam project. It is an Indonesian group that exposes abuses of political detainees. It is a Singaporean Web site that pushes for free speech. It is a Vietnamese writer -- now in prison -- who demands political openness.
Asian values may indeed be universal values. But it seems that European values are as well.
That is the view of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy leader in Myanmar, formerly called Burma. "Unless they wish to call the people of Burma 'un-Asian,' " she said, "they cannot call our struggle 'un-Asian.' "
Jose Ramos-Horta, the East Timorese leader who also won the Nobel peace prize, was blunt, as always.
"Human rights were not a European invention," he said. "For thousands of years, while Europeans were still living in caves, concepts of human rights and justice were already articulated in the teachings of the major Eastern philosophies and traditions."
It is no surprise that East Timorese believe in human rights and justice, but they apply these principles in their own way.
When United Nations experts came to help found a court system in the newborn nation three years ago, they brought with them an adversarial model in which a verdict emerges from opposing arguments.
It was a strange process, said an American lawyer who took part in the training. Culturally, she said, East Timorese tend to admit the crimes they have committed. To create a Western-style court system, she said, it was necessary to teach defendants to lie.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A billboard promoting social unity in the Burmese city of Yangon underscores Asia's traditional preference for the interests of the group instead of the individual, a cultural value that has long distinguished Asian from European civilization. (Stuart Isett/Polaris)

HEADLINE: Turmoil in the Andes 

 BODY:
The particulars of their individual stories vary, but in recent years all five Andean nations of South America have suffered crippling bouts of political violence and instability. President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada's hasty escape from his presidential palace in Bolivia last month -- he hid in an ambulance to flee a riot -- was only the latest indication of just how tenuous democracy's hold is on the region. 
 Washington policy makers should approach the Andean region as a whole and work alongside other Latin American nations, like Brazil and Mexico, to strengthen democracy in the region. Too often in the past, America's approach has been scattershot. 
 Colombia, the third-largest recipient of American foreign assistance, is a case in point. Under Plan Colombia, the Bush and Clinton administrations have poured billions of dollars into fighting that nation's drug trafficking, which finances violent left-wing guerrilla groups and right-wing paramilitaries. The effort is now starting to reduce coca cultivation, but there are signs that such farming is merely shifting to neighboring countries. 
Meanwhile, Colombia's guerrillas recently killed one American contract employee and kidnapped three others involved in the antidrug effort. The Bush administration has sent in 150 more military personnel to assist in the search for them, raising the alarming possibility that Americans could become directly engaged in the conflict. 
Colombia, a nation where democracy and brutal civil warfare have tenuously coexisted for decades, deserves our support. But Colombians must do their own fighting, and American aid must remained conditioned on the Colombian military's respect for human rights. 
Elsewhere, the region is disillusioned with the last decade's free-market reforms. Too often twisted into a corrosive form of crony capitalism, the "Washington consensus" did little to improve living standards or alleviate poverty. The economic disillusionment has devalued the appeal of democracy as a form of governance and empowered once-marginalized political forces. 
In Venezuela, a country of great strategic importance given its vast oil reserves, a demagogic president, Hugo Chavez, has shown that a populist backlash can be as destructive as corrupt political establishments that pay lip service to free markets. Encouragingly, Presidents Alejandro Toledo of Peru and Lucio Gutierrez of Ecuador appear inclined to follow a more responsible middle course. 
Their challenge is to please international capital markets and internal demands for a more equitable distribution of national wealth, and to do so simultaneously and at a difficult economic moment. America needs to be sympathetic, providing aid and promoting trade, but without being an overbearing pitchman for any one set of economic policies.

HEADLINE: Bank of America Is Scouting Midtown as Site for New Headquarters 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Bank of America is working on tentative plans for a new headquarters in Midtown Manhattan, possibly on 42nd Street, New York's boulevard of dreams. The prospect is causing enthusiasm bordering on giddiness among developers and state and city officials.
 The bank, which has thousands of employees at several Manhattan locations, has been meeting in recent weeks with developers like Douglas Durst of the Durst Organization and Richard Clark of Brookfield Financial Properties, as well as public officials, to discuss its search for a new one-million-square-foot home. 
 But the prospect of a new skyscraper is one of the few bright spots in an otherwise gloomy picture, with companies shedding employees and the vacancy rate more than doubling in the last two years. Analysts say that New York clearly remains an important international capital but that the weak state of the real estate market throws dark shadows over the city's plans for commercial development downtown and on the far west side of Manhattan. 
"They're betting on a demand that just isn't there," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and urban planning at New York University. "It's excessively rosy. We don't want to end up with a bunch of white elephants."
In recent weeks, the city has been stung by news that New York Life, the insurance company, is moving 1,000 employees to Westchester from Madison Avenue, as part of a trend to disperse corporate offices in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center. In a cost-cutting move, Philip Morris USA is relocating its longtime headquarters and 682 jobs from Park Avenue to Richmond, Va. 
AIG, the insurance giant, is moving 800 jobs to Jersey City from Lower Manhattan, where it is one of the largest employers, with a current work force of 6,024.
So it is no surprise, one state official said, that public officials and the real estate industry are excited about Bank of America's plans, even if the bank does not even want to move into a new home until 2007. After all, Bank of America is growing, unlike most of the major commercial and investment banks in the city. Indeed, an analyst at Lehman Brothers estimates that an additional 20,000 commodity and security brokers in the city will lose their jobs over the next year or so.
Peter G. Riguardi, president of Jones Lang LaSalle, a real estate company working for the bank, declined to comment.
But one real estate executive who has met with the bank's real estate team said, "They appear to be very serious about consolidation and going into a new development."
One developer added that the bank was trying to take advantage of a weak real estate market to make a deal. "They want a world-class headquarters at a bargain-basement price," he said.
The bank, which leases space at 9 West 57th Street and several other locations, has talked to Brookfield Financial Properties about the tower Brookfield is building at Madison Avenue and 42nd Street. The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, which was supposed to occupy the entire building, has decided to take only 375,000 square feet and sublease the remaining 765,000.
A more likely candidate for a site, city and state officials said, is at 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas, where Douglas Durst has long wanted to build a skyscraper. The two sides have met several times and Mr. Durst has asked state officials if they would condemn a handful of properties he does not already own on the block.
The bank is paying some of the highest rents in the city, real estate brokers said, and could easily move into a new building at a lower rent. But even at the peak of the city's real estate boom, in 2000, Mr. Durst and other developers found it hard to snare a major tenant. It is unclear, the brokers said, whether Bank of America will make a deal.
Whatever happens, Bank of America has established itself as an exceptional tenant in the current market, where many corporations are cutting payrolls and office space. According to Cushman & Wakefield, vacant office space in Manhattan today totals 47.7 million square feet, the equivalent of more than 20 Empire State Buildings.
Real estate brokers say more space has come on the market than has been leased in the last year. The law firm of Pillsbury Winthrop, for instance, is close to leasing 200,000 square feet at the Bertelsmann Building in Times Square. When it does, it will leave behind a similar-size space downtown, where it had made its home for almost 150 years.
Few analysts expect that downtown space to fill up soon, especially since the financial industry, one of the city's most important economic engines, is shrinking and sending more jobs outside Manhattan. For that reason, David Shulman, a real estate analyst for Lehman Brothers, described plans to build new office towers as "a bit exuberant."
In a speech to the New York City Partnership last week, Larry A. Silverstein, who took the lease on the World Trade Center towers just before they were destroyed by terrorists in September 2001, said he expected to complete the first two-million-square-foot tower at the site in 2008, followed by four more two-million-square-foot office buildings.
And Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff hopes to redevelop the far West Side of Manhattan, with plans calling for another five million square feet of office space in that neighborhood between 2010 and 2014.
City officials and some developers say that when a turnaround comes, they expect the city's economy to rebound as quickly as it did in the 1990's, when according to Insignia ESG, a real estate broker, the amount of vacant space in the city dropped from 51.8 million square feet in 1996 to 17.8 million in 2001 as companies expanded. But during what was arguably the biggest real estate boom in city history, only seven office towers were built.

HEADLINE: 3rd-Quarter Profit Falls 25% at Heinz 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, March 11 

 BODY:
The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 25 percent, reduced by costs for spinning off some underperforming units to the Del Monte Foods Company in December, but its underlying profit beat expectations.
 Heinz posted net income of $151.6 million, or 43 cents a share, compared with $201.7 million, or 57 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
 Excluding deal-related costs, earnings were $191.5 million, or 54 cents a share, compared with $161.2 million, or 46 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. On that basis, the results beat Wall Street estimates by 2 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call.
Sales from continuing operations rose 9.1 percent, to $2.1 billion, helped by better pricing, improved foreign currency rates and acquisitions. But overall shipments fell 1.9 percent, hurt by inflation in some foreign markets and the elimination of some unprofitable product lines. More than half of Heinz's business is outside the United States.
The company told analysts that it was also hurt by weakness in its food service business.
Heinz said it still expected full-year earnings of $2 to $2.05 a share.
In the quarter, Heinz took pretax charges of $81.5 million, primarily for costs related to the Del Monte deal, to reduce overhead in remaining businesses and for a loss on the divestiture of a Canadian fish and frozen vegetable business.
Shares of Heinz, based in Pittsburgh, rose 26 cents, to $29.70.

HEADLINE: Volkswagen Sees Falling Profits And Frail Market 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 11 

 BODY:
In another blow to the staggering German economy, the country's largest automobile maker, Volkswagen, said today that its first-quarter profit would fall significantly below that of last year and that its full-year operating profit might also decline.
 The gloomy outlook by Volkswagen's chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, led to a panicky sell-off of VW shares, which spread to the broader German market and the shares of other carmakers. Volkswagen's stock fell 7.4 percent, to 30.19 euros, or $33.30. Shares of Renault, Peugeot, BMW, DaimlerChrysler, Ford and General Motors also closed lower. 
 "Due to profound changes and considerable uncertainty in the economic and political framework, the result for the first quarter of 2003 will be significantly lower than the previous year," Mr. Pischetsrieder said at Volkswagen's annual financial news conference in Dresden.
Unless the American and West European markets strengthen considerably, he said, VW would not be able to match its 2002 operating profit of 4.76 billion euros, or about $5.25 billion. That result was itself a disappointment, representing a 12 percent decline from 2001.
In addition to weakness in its main markets, Volkswagen said, it had been stung by the rise in the exchange value of the euro against the dollar. The company has hedged about 40 percent of its risk from currency fluctuations, which still leaves much of its dollar-denominated profits vulnerable to the stronger euro.
Volkswagen's comments were the first clear indication that the euro was hurting German industry. Officials at the European Central Bank and the Bundesbank have said that the common currency is not yet biting into exports, despite its rise of more than 25 percent against the dollar in the last year.
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany has warned that a war in Iraq would further hurt his country's economy, which is nearing 11 percent unemployment and is at risk of its second recession in two years.
Moreover, some German auto executives recently raised fears with Mr. Schroder that his unwavering opposition to an American-led war could provoke a reaction among consumers in the United States.
Beyond all these unfavorable trends, Volkswagen's product lineup is about to undergo a major overhaul, with redesigned models of the best-selling Golf and the popular Passat sedan. While customers wait for the new cars, sales of the existing Golf and Passat models are expected to sag.
"Their Golf and Passat lines are getting old," said Lars Ziehn, an automotive analyst with Deutsche Bank. " '04 and '05 should be Volkswagen years, but the market is driven by today's news."
Mr. Ziehn estimates that Volkswagen's pretax profit in 2003 will be 15 percent lower than last year. He said the company's refusal to offer its own profit projections further rattled the market.
Volkswagen has also been struggling with quality problems. It recently agreed to replace ignition coils in potentially more than 500,000 VW and Audi models in North America because some were defective.
The company says it has the problem, which began cropping up last fall, under control. But its response was sluggish, and its image in the United States took a beating. Mr. Ziehn said the cost would be covered by reserves and probably did not play a role in today's poor forecast. 
Volkswagen did manage to eke out a 4.5 percent increase in vehicle deliveries in January and February. But that was chiefly a result of the buoyant Chinese market, in which VW has a strong presence.
The company reported that its net profit slipped 11 percent in 2002, to 2.58 billion euros, or $2.85 billion. Revenue declined 1.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Lobbyists on Both Sides Duel in the Medical Malpractice Debate 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11 

 BODY:
Few people noticed the lobbyist hovering in the background when Mary Rasar came to the Capitol last week to tell the story of her father's death.
 With three Republican senators by her side, and a gaggle of reporters before her, Ms. Rasar recounted how her father was injured in a car accident in Las Vegas the day after high liability premiums forced the local trauma center to close. He died in an emergency room -- "a tragic, tragic story," said Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, vowing to press for caps on jury awards in malpractice cases. 
 Their joint appearance was arranged by the lobbyist, William Nixon, as another salvo in a war of dueling images in the medical malpractice debate. For weeks, trial lawyers and consumer groups fighting against caps have been bringing malpractice victims to the Capitol -- including a 17-year-old girl whose face had been ruined by botched surgeries and a woman whose breasts had been removed unnecessarily after a doctor wrongly diagnosed cancer. So Mr. Nixon, who represents hospitals, fired back with Ms. Rasar. 
"The point," he said, "is to demonstrate that there are legitimate victims on both sides."
With the House expected on Thursday to take up legislation imposing a $250,000 cap on "pain and suffering" awards in malpractice cases, and the Senate planning to tackle medical liability later this month, lobbyists on both sides have been working at a fever pitch. The bill is expected to pass the House, but will probably face difficulty in the Senate, where some prominent Republicans say it must include an exception for egregious cases like that of Jesica Santillan, the 17-year-old who died after receiving a heart and lung of the wrong blood type.
Limiting jury awards has long been a high priority for Republicans and business interests, who believe malpractice legislation could open the door to a broader tort reform agenda. President Bush has been attacking trial lawyers -- and, by extension, the Democrats they support -- for "frivolous lawsuits," and he has invited a dozen House members to the White House on Wednesday to try to increase support for the House measure. With the president's backing and Republicans' running both the House and Senate, proponents say their goal is within reach.
"This is the first time in a decade that there has been an opportunity for real legal reform," said Karen Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, which represents managed care organizations. "All the key actors in the health care system are now united."
Mr. Nixon's client, the Coalition for Affordable and Reliable Health Care, is a perfect example. It was founded last September by the Baylor Health Care System in Texas and several other hospitals with one goal, overhauling malpractice law to bring down insurance premiums. "For the first time," he said, "they feel they are in striking distance."
The debate has also made for new lobbying alliances on Capitol Hill, and shattered some old ones. Last year, the American Medical Association, which represents doctors, was working hand in hand with the Association of Trial Lawyers of America -- and against Ms. Ignagni's group -- to promote legislation enabling patients to sue their health insurers. Now, the A.M.A. has joined with the insurance industry. Lobbyists for the trial lawyers complain they cannot get the doctors to talk to them.
Dr. Donald A. Palmisano, the A.M.A.'s president-elect, says revamping liability laws is the association's No. 1 legislative priority. He recalled meeting President Bush in July in High Point, N.C., on the day the president gave his first speech on the topic.
"He looked right at me and he said, 'We can get medical liability reform now if you will go to the grass roots,' " Dr. Palmisano said.
To that end, the association is trying to raise $15 million for a nationwide media campaign. Doctors around the country have rallied to the cause, waging a series of highly publicized walkouts and protests. Though local chapters have been behind the rallies, Dr. Palmisano has been flying around the country to attend them. The powerful images have not been lost on lawmakers.
"They've demonstrated with their feet," said Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which last week sent the malpractice bill to the full House for a vote.
Mr. Tauzin was among several Republicans, including President Bush, who addressed more than 600 doctors last week at the A.M.A.'s National Advocacy Conference. Over breakfast of eggs, toast, peaches and sausage, the doctor-lobbyists, who later fanned out across Capitol Hill, got some friendly advice from Senator Bill Frist -- the Republican leader and a heart transplant surgeon.
Do not be satisfied with seeing Congressional staffs, Dr. Frist advised, adding, "Say, 'I just want to see the senator for two minutes.' "
In addition to the war of images, there has been a war of words and numbers, with proponents trying to link high liability premiums to high jury awards, and opponents trying to disprove a link, in part by citing studies showing the influence of larger economic trends on insurance costs. Last week, Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, announced a new study that found "the main factor causing the crisis is the rise in mega-awards and settlements," including jury awards that can exceed $1 million. Opponents responded with their own statistics, from the government's National Practitioner Data Bank, showing the average jury verdict, far from being in the millions, is roughly $400,000 and the average settlement about $200,000.
"It's like an escalating arms race, but with disinformation," said Jamie Court, executive director of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, the advocacy group that put out the lower figures. "There is so much floating information around that no one knows what to believe, and almost every statistic becomes useless."
Also floating around, this being Washington, is money. Proponents of malpractice change include some of Washington's most powerful and well-financed lobbies. According to the Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks campaign spending, the A.M.A. contributed $2.7 million to candidates in the 2002 election cycle, with 60 percent going to Republicans. The American Hospital Association, which strongly backs malpractice law changes, gave $1.9 million, 53 percent of it to Republicans.
But the opponents are also well financed. The trial lawyers contributed $3.7 million in the 2002 election cycle, 89 percent of it to Democrats.
"I've been working this for 20 years, and it has often seemed very close," said Linda Lipsen, who is running the trial lawyers' lobbying effort. Recently, the group brought 120 members to Washington to knock on lawmakers' doors. "It's very arduous," Ms. Lipsen said, "but we feel like if we can tell the story of the patients that our lawyers represent, the justice system should prevail." 
And so, almost daily, those stories are being told. Last month, the Center for Justice and Democracy, a consumer group, brought 30 victims of medical malpractice to Washington, and staged a "rump hearing" before Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee. The patients ran the gamut, from a man whose right lung was removed after doctors discovered a tumor in the left lung to Linda McDougal, the woman who underwent an unnecessary double mastectomy after pathologists erroneously diagnosed breast cancer.
On Wednesday, the day before the House is scheduled to vote, the trial lawyers will be bringing Ms. McDougal back to the Capitol, for an appearance with the minority leader of the Senate, Tom Daschle, and his counterpart in the House, Nancy Pelosi. But Mr. Nixon, the hospital lobbyist, is ready. He is bringing back Ms. Rasar, for an appearance with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Linda McDougal on her way to testify before Congress. (Craig Lassig for The New York Times)
