HEADLINE: U.S. Investigates Another Ex-Aide to Rowland 

BYLINE:  By PAUL von ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 11 

 BODY:
Federal prosecutors are investigating whether Gov. John G. Rowland's former co-chief of staff, Peter N. Ellef, orchestrated a bribery scheme to steer state construction projects to a contractor, federal and state officials said today.
 On Monday, Lawrence E. Alibozek, Governor Rowland's deputy chief of staff from October 1997 to July 1999, admitted in Federal District Court here that he took an unspecified amount of cash and gold for steering state building projects worth tens of millions of dollars to a company that the government did not identify. 
 In an interview today, Mr. Rowland said that in November and December, a federal grand jury issued two subpoenas to his office seeking information about Mr. Alibozek and Mr. Ellef. The subpoenas also asked for any documents pertaining to several construction and management companies owned by William Tomasso, Mr. Rowland said. Mr. Tomasso, of New Britain, is a close friend of Mr. Rowland's and a major contributor to his political campaigns. 
Officials close to the investigation of Mr. Alibozek said the government was now trying to determine whether Mr. Ellef, who was known as an influential adviser and an aggressive political enforcer for the governor, knew about or participated in the bribery scheme.
The guilty plea and the revelations of the corruption investigation are the latest in a series of scandals in Mr. Rowland's eight years in office, but they have had little effect on his popularity. Last November, Mr. Rowland, a Republican, was re-elected to a third term by a wide margin.
In 1999, his state treasurer, Paul J. Silvester, a rising star in the administration, pleaded guilty to investing Connecticut's pension fund with companies that paid kickbacks to Mr. Silvester's friends and family. Several months later, Ben F. Andrews, who ran unsuccessfully for secretary of the state on Mr. Rowland's 1998 ticket, was indicted on charges that he had a role in Mr. Silvester's "pay-to-play" scheme.
Last year, after the state's trash authority revealed it had lost nearly $200 million in public money in a complex deal with Enron, federal investigators began looking into whether the authority's lobbyist, Linda Kowalski, improperly paid for meals and entertainment for Mr. Rowland and his staff.
As public scrutiny of the Enron deal intensified, Mr. Rowland last year dismissed Mr. Ellef, who was the chairman of the trash authority as well Mr. Rowland's co-chief of staff.
This week, the United States attorney's office in Connecticut asked six state agencies, including the Departments of Transportation, Children and Family Services, Public Works and Economic and Community Development, to turn over any documents relating to Mr. Ellef's daily schedule, phone records and appointments, Mr. Rowland said.
In a departure from his normal procedure, Mr. Rowland spoke to a dozen reporters today in individual 15-minute interviews in his office, instead of addressing them collectively in a news conference and facing a barrage of quesitons.
In his interview with The New York Times, Mr. Rowland said that he knew nothing of Mr. Alibozek's bribe-taking and that government lawyers had told him that he was not a subject of their corruption investigation.
"I'm very disappointed and surprised at the reports and the plea," Mr. Rowland said today. He dismissed any suggestion that he should have known that Mr. Alibozek was involved in wrongdoing or that the two men's friendship with Mr. Tomasso played a role in Mr. Alibozek's crime.
"Both of these gentlemen have stellar recommendations and credentials," Mr. Rowland said. Appearing uncharacteristically confused, he then said: "They're not political people. It's not like they are political appointees," though Mr. Ellef and Mr. Alibozek each served at the pleasure of the governor.
Calls to Mr. Tomasso's offices in New Britain were not returned today.
Mr. Ellef's lawyer, Hugh F. Keefe, said today that he was not aware of any evidence that his client had committed a crime or was involved in wrongdoing.
"I have no reason to believe, at this point, that Ellef is a target," Mr. Keefe said. 
Mr. Ellef and Mr. Alibozek were known to be close, having met while both worked at Cigna, an employee benefits company. When Mr. Rowland appointed Mr. Ellef state economic development commissioner in 1995, Mr. Alibozek became deputy commissioner. When the governor named Mr. Ellef his co-chief of staff, Mr. Alibozek again moved with him, becoming his deputy.
Three years ago, Mr. Alibozek left state government briefly. He started a tree nursery that failed about five months later, and he returned to state government in January 2000 as the head of the state agency for the blind. In March 2001, he left to become deputy commissioner of the Military Department.
Under his plea agreement, Mr. Alibozek, 58, of New Hartford, could be imprisoned for 24 to 30 months and fined as much as $50,000, terms that could be reduced if he continues cooperating with prosecutors, federal officials said.
William T. Gerace, Mr. Alibozek's lawyer, said today that his client was devastated by his felony conviction. 
"He's a very proud man," Mr. Gerace said. "He's been a responsible and diligent public official for most of his career. This is just a lapse in judgment. He can't explain it himself."

HEADLINE: THE THEATER SETTLEMENT: ASSESSMENT; 
Theaters Tally Their Financial Losses as Unions Contemplate Act II

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
In a business in which a couple of bad weeks can mean the end of the run, Tuesdays on Broadway are traditionally when productions take stock, review the previous week's box-office receipts and decide how -- and whether -- to proceed. 
 This particular Tuesday was especially grim. According to statistics compiled by the League of American Theaters and Producers, every musical on Broadway -- except one, "Cabaret," which played a normal schedule because of a different contract -- lost substantial amounts of money over the weekend as shows were canceled because of the musicians' strike. 
 As a whole, the industry brought in a measly $5.2 million last week, compared with the $12.2 million it earned the week ending on March 2. 
The week's losses ran into the hundreds of thousands of dollars each for nearly a dozen shows, including "42nd Street," "Aida," "Beauty and the Beast," "Chicago," "Flower Drum Song," "La Boheme," "Thoroughly Modern Millie," "Les Miserables" and "The Phantom of the Opera." 
Even Broadway's biggest hits -- like "Mamma Mia!," "Hairspray" and "The Producers" -- suffered losses, while some of its new, lesser-known shows simply bled red ink; "Urban Cowboy," for example, a musical in previews, brought in only $39,937 in five performances, representing a loss of about $400,000.
"Had it gone beyond Thursday," Leonard Soloway, a producer of "Urban Cowboy," said of the strike, "I don't know if we would have made the opening."
That seemed to be the consensus: a quick end to the strike prevented a quick end to many shows. Delays notwithstanding, Mr. Soloway promised that his show would open as scheduled on March 27 at the Broadhurst Theater. Even the producers of "Flower Drum Song," who said they would close early because of the strike, said yesterday that the show would play its final week and close as scheduled on Sunday.
Still, while Mr. Soloway and other producers assessed the strike's economic impact on their individual shows, others on Broadway mulled over how the four-day strike might affect future labor negotiations, including talks next year between the league and Actors' Equity Association, the union for actors and stage managers.
Actors' Equity stood by the musicians' union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, by honoring its picket lines, as did the stagehands' union, Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees. (Local 1's contract expires in 2005.) That solidarity assured that Local 802 would back Actors' Equity in its negotiations, said many in the industry.
Bill Dennison, assistant to the president of Local 802, called the support from the actors and stagehands a "historic achievement."
"This has never happened before on Broadway or in the entertainment industry," Mr. Dennison said yesterday. "In previous strikes involving multicraft union situations, I don't know of any circumstances where the unions honored a single union's picket line." 
The walkout by all three major unions sets "exactly the right tone for the actors' negotiations," he said. "Unions are not going to buckle under."
The assistance of the musicians' union is considered particularly important for the actors' union because one of its major issues is the increase of nonunion national tours. In the past union musicians have failed to honor actors' requests to not play these nonunion tours; now rank-and-file actors expect musicians to repay their loyalty. 
Alan Eisenberg, the executive director of Actor's Equity, denied that there was any quid-pro-quo discussion before actors decided to honor the picket lines, but conceded that his membership now expected support from the musicians' union.
"That seems to be the consensus," Mr. Eisenberg said. Actors' Equity "went out for the principle of live music; the membership was uniform in that," he said.
Still, Mr. Eisenberg also suggested that his union's decision to stand by the musicians might have angered producers enough to complicate the coming negotiations. 
Jed Bernstein, the president of the theater league, had no comment on that suggestion, but did say that the unions were not the only party to stick together.
"I think that both sides showed strong solidarity," Mr. Bernstein said. "Certainly the unions, in standing up for each other, but management also, by supporting each other's position through several difficult weeks."
While the sight of actors carrying union picket signs may be one of the strike's indelible images, does it truly signal a new age of unity among Broadway unions, which have not always seen eye to eye? 
Labor leaders said they were hopeful. James Claffey Jr., the business manager for Local 1, the stagehand's union, said that the crisis on Broadway after Sept. 11, 2001 -- when the entire industry shut down for two days -- has led to greater communication between the 13 unions that represent all segments of Broadway workers. That new cooperation, which includes monthly meetings among representatives from every union, is being felt in negotiations, he said. 
"I think we've found out that's the only way to move forward," Mr. Claffey said. "And I think our membership expects it now."
Future negotiations were far from the minds of most producers yesterday; they concentrated on getting the curtains back up and on bringing the money back in.
Mr. Soloway, for example, was still figuring out how much four days off the job had cost him. 
Before the strike, he had spent $100,000 on extra rehearsals for his cast members with the so-called virtual orchestra, which the producers had planned to use instead of striking musicians. Now he is spending extra money on stagehands to make up for lost time. 
"Work that we would have done in the afternoons we now have to do in the mornings before rehearsal," Mr. Soloway said. "But, listen, let's just say: I'm glad it's over."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY; 
Rangers Obtain Oilers' Carter On Day of Trades

BYLINE:  By JASON DIAMOS 

DATELINE: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 11 

 BODY:
The National Hockey League trading deadline passed today with a record 24 trades involving 46 players as some teams tried to make a final push to qualify for the Stanley Cup playoffs while others bolstered their rosters with veterans they believe will help them win the Cup.
 The Rangers, in danger of missing the playoffs for a sixth consecutive season, made perhaps the biggest splash by acquiring the high-scoring forward Anson Carter from the Edmonton Oilers. In exchange, the Oilers, who are clinging to the final Western Conference playoff berth, received right wing Radek Dvorak, who has scored six goals in 63 games, and defenseman Cory Cross. The Rangers also acquired Ales Pisa, a 26-year-old defenseman, in the deal. "I think we got one of the best forwards out there today, maybe the best forward," Glen Sather, the Rangers' president, general manager and coach, said. 
 The 6-foot-1, 200-pound Carter, who led the Oilers with 25 goals and 55 assists, becomes the franchise's most prominent black player since Tony McKegney, who was at the end of his career when he joined the Rangers in 1986.
The Detroit Red Wings, the defending Stanley Cup champions, paid a high price to acquire the veteran defenseman Mathieu Schneider from Los Angeles, shipping defenseman Maxim Kuznetsov, center Sean Avery, a first-round pick in the 2003 draft and a second-round pick in the 2004 draft to the Kings.
Toronto obtained the veteran center Doug Gilmour from Montreal and the veteran defenseman Phil Housley from Chicago to supplement its earlier acquisitions of forward Owen Nolan from San Jose and defenseman Glen Wesley from Carolina.
The Islanders shipped goaltender Chris Osgood to St. Louis, while shoring up their defense with the acquisition of Janne Niinimaa from Edmonton, along with a second-round pick, for forwards Brad Isbister and Raffi Torres.
Sather, who had several conversations with Oilers General Manager Kevin Lowe, said he had inquired about Niinimaa, but it was only this morning that he learned that Lowe was willing to trade Carter, who can become a restricted free agent.
"And I don't think you can pass on these kind of guys," said Sather, who engineered one of the biggest trades of the season on Jan. 10, when he obtained Aleksei Kovalev from Pittsburgh in an eight-player deal that also included a payment of nearly $4 million to the Penguins.
"He's a hockey player," Sather said of Carter, who was born in Toronto and starred at Michigan State. "When you make a deal like this, the only thing I'm concerned about is whether he's a good player and a good person. And he's both."
Carter is scheduled to join the Rangers on Wednesday and be in the lineup Thursday against the Senators.
Dvorak, 25, was called off the ice as the Rangers gathered for practice at noon and then quickly departed for home to pack. His departure leaves Petr Nedved as the only remaining member of the Rangers' Czech line.
"With all these rumors and always my name was mentioned, I was expecting something," Dvorak, who was acquired by the Rangers from Florida on Dec. 30, 1999, said in a telephone interview. "I'm going to a young team that's in the playoffs right now, and I went for a good player. That's nice. I know I can help Edmonton."
In a televised news conference, Lowe, who succeeded Sather as the general manager in Edmonton, defended his decision to trade his leading scorer for a player who had struggled with his confidence until recently.
"Time will tell," Lowe said of Dvorak, who scored a career-best 31 goals two seasons ago, then slumped to 17 last season before undergoing season-ending reconstructive knee surgery. "It's taken him some time, like a lot of players who have had knee operations, to get back their stride. But he has been, and will be, a goal scorer in this league."
Sather was not so sure.
"I thought in the last 10 days he had really started to turn it around," Sather said of Dvorak. "But I never thought he was a pure goal scorer. Even in practice, he had trouble scoring goals. He was getting his confidence back. But this guy is a different player altogether."
Sather was referring to Carter, who is earning $2.4 million this season and will be eligible for arbitration in the summer. Dvorak, meanwhile, is making $1.575 million this season and will make $2 million next season.
Lowe insisted that financial considerations were not the primary factor in his decisions to trade Carter and Niinimaa.
"But when you play in a small market like Edmonton, economics are always a factor," Carter said.

SLAP SHOTS
Defenseman JANNE LAUKKANEN, who had not played for the Rangers since being obtained on Jan. 10 from Pittsburgh in the deal for ALEKSEI KOVALEV, was claimed off waivers by Tampa Bay. . . . No one was sorrier than DARIUS KASPARAITIS to see CORY CROSS be traded. Kasparaitis, who had a plus-minus rating of minus-17, the worst among defensemen in the league, on Dec. 26, is plus-18 since Dec. 28, and is now plus-1 for the season. "He got me to plus, now he's gone," Kasparaitis said of his defensive partner. . . . ALES PISA's plus-minus rating of plus-11 was tied for the Edmonton team lead. In 48 games this season, Pisa has a goal and three assists for 4 points. . . . In a swap of minor leaguers, the Rangers obtained defenseman LAWRENCE NYCHOLAT from Minnesota for goaltender JOHAN HOLMQVIST. Nycholat has 155 penalty minutes at Houston of the American Hockey League this season.

HEADLINE: National Briefing New England: Maine: Brain Drain 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 College graduates tend to leave the state because they believe that employment opportunities are better elsewhere, a state report has found. The study, by the Finance Authority of Maine and the University of Southern Maine, found that more than half of the state's college graduates in 1998 wanted to live and work in Maine, but three of four ultimately left.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Doorman Union Begins Contract Talks 

BYLINE:  By Steven Greenhouse (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 With a contract deadline six weeks away, the union representing 28,000 doormen, janitors and elevator operators at 3,000 New York City apartment buildings began negotiations yesterday. 
A settlement is likely to be difficult because of hard times for the city's economy and real estate industry. The union and building owners and managers agree that raises are likely to be the toughest issue because management is proposing a wage freeze with a lump sum in several years, while the union wants annual raises to keep up with inflation. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

HEADLINE: Tough Times For the City Are Lingering 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
New York City's recession has now lasted two full years, according to a report on the last quarter of 2002 issued yesterday by the city's comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr. 
 Jobs and tax collections fell during the last three months of 2002, as the rate of inflation and office vacancies increased. And the city's economy continued to shrink, even as the nation's grew. "It is imperative that we work to quickly decrease the burden this recession has placed on our budget," Mr. Thompson said in a statement. 
 The report found that the city lost 29,000 jobs in the fourth quarter -- which was its worst quarterly drop in a decade, with the exception of the quarter that immediately followed the World Trade Center attack. The city's unemployment rate rose to 8.1 percent in the fourth quarter of the year, well above the nation's 5.9 percent unemployment rate. During all of 2002, it said, the private sector lost 88,300 jobs. 
The inflation rate in the metropolitan region rose to 3.1 percent in the fourth quarter on an annual basis, up from 2.6 percent in the third quarter. The report said that it gave New York the fourth-highest inflation rate of the nation's 14 largest metropolitan areas. The report also said that the gross city product, a measure of economic activity, fell by 2.2 percent in 2002, which is significantly worse than the 0.3 percent drop in 2001. While the city's economy declined in the fourth quarter, the nation's grew moderately.
The lingering recession is bad news for the city's budget makers, who several times have had to scale back their estimates of how much the cash-starved city would collect in taxes this year. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council are grappling with how to close a deficit of roughly $3.5 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1. 
With few signs that the economy will take off in time to fill the city's coffers, Mayor Bloomberg is increasingly looking to Albany and the city's labor unions for help. City agencies are due to report back to the mayor today with their plans for cutting $600 million in case the unions do not come through.

HEADLINE: The Hours of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Eighteen hours, three news conferences and several cups of coffee. That is often the life of the person in charge of New York City. 
 It was that way Monday evening and on into Tuesday, a time that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hinted during the campaign he might shy away from. But it is the sort that ultimately defines him in the collective eyes of the city he runs. 
 In that span, Mr. Bloomberg experienced the mayoral lifestyle that has drawn some men to the job but has kept others from taking it on. 
"Being mayor means facing our city at its best and worst moments," said Edward Skyler, the mayor's press secretary, who was with him most of Monday night into Tuesday morning. "But no night reflected that better than Monday night."
The mayor began Monday evening the way he often ends it, at a gala event, this time for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. The evening quickly evolved into a marathon of diverse and difficult tasks, as he sprinted from a meeting at Gracie Mansion, where he intervened in the Broadway musicians' strike, to a hospital in Staten Island, where he met families of two slain police officers. 
At 5:30 p.m., Mr. Bloomberg was swearing in Robert B. Tierney as chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission at Gracie Mansion. He then made his way to the Waldorf-Astoria for the Hall of Fame induction. So far, it was standard mayoral stuff. 
Then aides traveling with him got a call with one of the most dreaded messages in government -- 10-13, officer down. The mayor decided to go on with his schedule, until he had more information. 
Mr. Bloomberg quickly made his way through his ceremonial duties at the rock induction ceremony. Around 8:40 p.m., he went back to Gracie Mansion, and at 9:15 he made his pitch to Broadway producers and musicians -- who had been on strike all weekend -- to end their differences immediately. 
"He was impressing upon them that there were far-reaching and damaging effects that the strike was having on the economy," Mr. Skyler said. "He said to them as a group that there were ramifications beyond their immediate industries, and that he had been involved in many deals, and that you never get everything you want." 
Asked outside Gracie Mansion by reporters if he had pressured the parties, Mr. Bloomberg said: "I didn't threaten them at all. I pointed out that 38,000 uniformed members of the N.Y.P.D. were standing around the building."
The mayor soon departed, leaving the theater people and musicians to resume talks over endless supplies of roast beef and turkey sandwiches, popcorn and warm chocolate chip cookies. 
"Sugar at 2 in the morning," said Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers. "Yes, it was a highlight."
Mr. Bloomberg and his aides were whisked from Gracie Mansion to the heliport on East 34th Street, where they took a helicopter to Staten Island. Grim details were beginning to emerge about the two officers. 
After a police shooting, several small dramas play out in various rooms of the hospital. There is the scene with visiting elected officials, another with uniformed officers, and sometimes there is the scene with members of a victim's unit, this time elite undercover officers dressed as thugs, down to gang tattoos. Many were sobbing.
Then there are the families. Mr. Bloomberg met with members from both men's families, who arrived in various stages of panic and despair. There was little to say at times, so the mayor just held some people's hands. 
"It was an extremely difficult and emotional time," said Vincent LaPadula, the senior adviser to the mayor.
One wife was so grief-stricken that she collapsed and had to be placed in a wheelchair. So Mr. Bloomberg squatted on the floor to be near her, Mr. LaPadula said. 
When she asked him over and over what she ought to tell her children, Mr. Bloomberg said, "Tell them he was a hero." 
At a news conference at 1:30 a.m. at the hospital, a furious and doleful mayor held his first middle-of-the-night briefing since he took office. The night was still young.
By 2:15 a.m., Mr. Bloomberg was back in his S.U.V. and on the way to Gracie Mansion, where he found negotiators making progress. He briefly told the group about where he had just been, then left at 3 a.m. for some sleep at his nearby town house.
By 6 a.m., he was up, reading the newspapers. At 7:45, he got the call that a Broadway deal had been struck, but he had committed himself to an event celebrating women's history month at Barnard College.
By 9:15 a.m., he was back at Gracie Mansion, where he was greeted with a round of applause. After a news conference there, it was off to City Hall for the day, where he held a quick briefing with officials from around the state who had planned for days to attend a joint news conference on Medicaid costs. 
By 11:15 a.m., his third news conference of the morning was in progress. It lasted half an hour and involved Medicaid costs and the city budget, a topic that remains with New York's mayor, 24 hours a day every day.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during the strike talks at Gracie Mansion, on a multiple-coffee kind of day. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Lays Siege to Mexico's Chief, and So Do Many Others 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 11 

 BODY:
It is now open season on President Vicente Fox.
 A verbal volley demanding his support at the United Nations for military action on Iraq is coming from American officials. Poison darts are flying from Mr. Fox's political opponents as midterm elections approach. Even the president's wife is under pointed personal attack. 
 Mr. Fox has sought to float above the fray, keeping to a grueling schedule of speeches and political rallies across the country. But today he went into an unusual political retreat at the presidential palace, canceling his public schedule, huddling with a few advisers, and contemplating his next move vis-a-vis Washington.
By day's end, Mr. Fox announced that he would undergo spinal surgery on Wednesday and remain out of public view until the weekend. While on the operating table, he will temporarily transfer presidential power to his interior minister, Santiago Creel. The unexpected surgery is likely only to prolong the diplomatic agony.
The new United States ambassador here, Tony Garza, a Texas friend of President Bush, has come very close to publicly demanding a yes vote from Mexico in support of the United States at the Security Council, where Mexico holds a swing vote among the 15 members. A maybe or an abstention is not good enough, Mr. Garza said Monday. 
"Will American attitudes be placated by half-steps or three-quarter-steps?" he said. "I kind of doubt it."
Supporting the United States could be political suicide at home, where an overwhelming majority of people oppose military action against Iraq. But being perceived in Washington as a traitor carries dangers too -- or so many Mexicans believe. 
In Mexico, therefore, Mr. Fox's decision is being seen as the defining moment for his presidency -- and for the country's complex relationship with its powerful neighbor.
"Are we going to be defined by our relationship by the United States or not?" asked Rossana Fuentes, a leading political analyst and managing editor of the foreign language edition of Foreign Affairs magazine. "There are some people in Mexico who'd like to turn the Rio Grande into the Atlantic Ocean, you know. We are still trying to sort out this fundamental question."
Mexico's economy, so dependent on the United States, is as flat as a desert landscape. When he took office, Mr. Fox promised 7 percent annual economic growth; he has produced almost none. In the capital, opposition politicians have charged, without proof, that Mr. Fox has taken illegal campaign contributions from the United States through a group called Friends of Fox; the president and his aides fiercely deny that.
Political life was sublime for Mr. Fox after July 2, 2000, the day he swept the old regime, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, from power after seven unbroken decades. 
For a year, he seemed above criticism. A year to the day after his election, on July 2, 2001, Mr. Fox surprised the nation by marrying his press spokeswoman, now Mrs. Marta de Fox. They went to Washington together for Mr. Bush's first state dinner, a week before the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States.
That summer well may have been the high-water mark of his presidency. Today Mr. Fox still radiates confidence, but his optimism is starting to ring hollow.
The political friction is affecting the prospects for congressional elections in July. Those midterm elections will determine whether Mr. Fox spends the next three years as a lame-duck president confronting a fiercely hostile Congress. Polls suggest that is a real possibility.
Mr. Fox's National Action Party, known as the PAN, is desperately seeking a plurality in the legislature, so as to pass some of his proposed legislation for changing Mexico.
But the old governing party, universally known as the PRI, now narrowly holds sway in Congress. If the PRI keeps that edge, Mr. Fox's unrealized agenda of economic, social and fiscal change for Mexico will be all but dead for the rest of the three years of his presidency.
Winning Congress "is the only way that the country can realize the change promised by President Fox and do away with the roadblocks to development," said the PAN's national leader, Luis Felipe Bravo Mena. "We can no longer postpone our future."
The leader of the PRI, Roberto Madrazo, believes the future belongs to him and his party.
"The president cannot hide his enormous failures, his lack of results," Mr. Madrazo said. "The president has lost the opportunity to head a transition government. His presidency is a government of words."
To wound President Fox, the PRI and its supporters are aiming pointed, personal attacks against Mrs. Fox. They paint her as a latter-day Eva Peron, a woman who has married her way to power. 
They accuse her of abusing that power for personal pleasure through the largesse of a private foundation she runs, called Let's Go, Mexico! The foundation is financed by Mrs. Fox's friends, both political and personal. 
President Fox may not have helped matters a few days ago by calling himself and his wife "the presidential couple."
"No, no, no!" said Rosario Robles, the leader of the Democratic Revolutionary Party, another opposition group, and a former mayor of Mexico City. "In Mexico there are no presidential couples. No more empires."
"If Vicente and Marta think they are Maximiliano and Carlota, that's a problem," she said, referring to the tragically inept emperor and empress of 19th-century Mexico.
Mrs. Fox has deflected the criticism by trying to turn the other cheek. "We have to forgive these people," she said. "They'd like a chance to serve their country, too."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Vicente Fox, center foreground, at a ride for peace this month. The United States is pressing him to support military action against Iraq. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Angels Were Mentioned in Contraction Talks Before Winning World Series

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
During much of 2001, before Major League Baseball announced and then backed off from eliminating two teams, one option was to buy out the Anaheim Angels and replace or merge them with the Oakland Athletics, according to informal notes and memos by high-level baseball officials.
 "That one was floated out there, but it was one of dozens and dozens of scenarios," Bob DuPuy, the president of Major League Baseball, said. "We were trying to be very, very thorough and looked at every possible contraction, realignment and relocation scenario." 
 If the Anaheim-Oakland option had been adopted when Commissioner Bud Selig and the baseball owners wanted to last season, the Angels would not have existed to win the World Series last year. 
As contraction targets, Anaheim and Oakland never rose to the level of serious candidates, as did Minnesota and Montreal. Anaheim is not a small-market team, but the Angels, even under the ownership of the Walt Disney Company, were in the Dodgers' shadow in Southern California until their World Series victory.
Oakland shares the Bay Area market with the San Francisco Giants, but by 2001 had become a strong team with a modest payroll, yet in need of a new stadium.
But baseball's due diligence in trying to improve its economics included analyzing all possible options, a process that started with examining 18 teams as possible contraction candidates, DuPuy said.
Steve Schott, co-owner of the A's, said his discussions with DuPuy and Paul Beeston, the former president of baseball, were "very general."
"I wouldn't call it a plan," he said. "It was an idea, and it was not detailed. We never got to escrow."
There had been a few newspaper reports about the Anaheim-Oakland concept, but baseball officials refused to confirm which teams were contraction targets. 
According to the documents, which were obtained by The New York Times, baseball officials divided eight contraction candidates into two tiers. The first four, presumably the ones with the most serious financial problems, were Montreal, Minnesota, Tampa Bay and San Diego.
On the second level were Arizona (because of its heavy debt load), Florida, Kansas City and Oakland.
To guide their work, baseball's lawyers provided a document for Beeston and DuPuy on Dec. 11, 2000, which detailed financial, media, legal and stadium issues facing some contraction targets, with a specific eye toward when leases and television contracts ended. It also briefly assessed political fallout.
For example, Oakland's lease at Network Associates Coliseum was then to expire at the end of 2001 and it had the right to terminate its cable television deal if it moved.
The document said that eliminating the Tampa Devil Rays was complicated by a dispute between its managing general partner and limited partners, "lender issues, including bankruptcy and liability to lenders" and "ticket holder or similar class action."
In July 2001, a new document listed the Oakland-Anaheim option.
"Angels want to 'sell,' " the document said. "Athletics want to move." The document said the plan would be "complicated by public ownership of Angels" by Disney and "complicated by offers to buy Angels."
Schott said, "They talked to us about moving the A's to Anaheim, but then you would have a team with two rosters, and they didn't describe how they would consolidate the teams."
He was also told that John Henry, then the owner of the Florida Marlins, would be his partner in a proposed Anaheim-Oakland consolidation. Henry had also been rumored on his own to be pursuing a purchase of the Angels. The team has been for sale for a couple of years.
"We talked a little and pursued it a little further," he said.
It never advanced. In early 2002 Henry sold the Marlins to Jeffrey Loria for $158 million; Loria sold the Expos to Major League Baseball for $120 million, and a group led by Henry acquired the Boston Red Sox for $660 million.
Soon after, Selig delayed contraction until 2003, then deferred considering it until 2007 as part of the new labor deal with the players' union.
A spokesman for the Angels did not return a call asking comment, as did Tony Tavares, the president of the Montreal Expos, who was in charge of Anaheim Sports, the Disney division that oversaw the Angels and the Anaheim Mighty Ducks.
One document showed a sensitivity toward negative coverage of Selig's initial contraction announcement in 2001. A 10-point analysis criticized baseball for not selling the contraction concept sufficiently to "national baseball opinion leaders in advance of the announcement."
The report said the failure to presell the concept had forced the news media to rely "solely on the cogency of the Commissioner's oral presentation," and that lacking a "firm understanding of the concept, the media veered to writing about his performance at the press conference."
It cited how writers "indulged in the pathos of contracting the Twins." It also criticized Jesse Ventura, then the Minnesota governor and an opponent of eliminating the Twins, "who, hungry for pithy comments, gulped his media-friendly responses."

HEADLINE: THE THEATER SETTLEMENT: OVERVIEW; 
Broadway's Lights Go Back On As Musicians Reach an Accord

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN and STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The curtains went up on Broadway musicals last night for the first time since Thursday, after producers and musicians reached a settlement during round-the-clock talks at Gracie Mansion.
 Both sides said that the tentative agreement would not have happened without the intervention of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who invited them to the mayoral mansion on Monday night. The mayor, who had no official role in the dispute, was concerned that the strike was causing heavy economic losses, estimated at $7 million a day. 
 "Broadway is no longer dark," Mr. Bloomberg said in announcing the settlement yesterday morning. "It's a happy ending." 
When the negotiators emerged, bleary-eyed, from the talks, neither side claimed victory, and both called the deal a difficult compromise. The main conflict had been over the minimum number of musicians required -- currently 24 to 26 -- in the orchestra pits of Broadway's 13 largest theaters.
Under the new contract, those minimums were lowered for the next decade to 18 or 19, depending on the theater. The shows currently running are unaffected. While the musicians preserved the idea of minimums, the deal cut the number of such positions by about 25 percent per show in the future. For musicals that run in the largest theaters -- many of which cost $10 million to $12 million to stage -- the change is expected to save producers at least $600,000 a year.
At Gracie Mansion, Mr. Bloomberg had greeted the two negotiators with a pep talk. They said his words made a strong impression -- as did the knowledge that the mayor was simultaneously facing another crisis, the fatal shooting of two police officers in Staten Island.
"He used an expression, 'At the end of the day, we're all buried in the same ground, and we have to find a way to live together,' " said Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers.
Bill Dennison, assistant to the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said: "As typical with compromises, nobody's happy. It's a very difficult concession that we've made on orchestra sizes. At the same time, we've protected live music on Broadway for the next 10 years, and that is not an insignificant achievement."
The negotiations were mediated by Frank J. Macchiarola, a former chancellor of New York City's schools, who was asked by Mr. Bloomberg to help settle the strike that had left 18 musicals dark, ticketholders disappointed, the tourism industry at risk and hundreds of Broadway employees out of work since Friday.
Before the strike, the producers said they wanted to eliminate minimums altogether, calling them an archaic employment guarantee that had become increasingly onerous in an age of escalating production costs. They succeeded in reducing the minimums for the largest theaters by seven musicians. The base wage for Broadway musicians is $70,000 a year; with benefits included, their overall compensation comes to more than $90,000. Reducing a pit orchestra by seven players, therefore, can save more than $630,000 a year.
A 25-member orchestra generally accounts for 8 to 10 percent of a musical's costs, and the new minimums could reduce that to between 5.5 and 7.5 percent, industry and union officials say.
Throughout the negotiations the musicians insisted that, without at least 24 players, the quality of Broadway orchestras would be compromised. They also frequently invoked the specter of Broadway without live music. The producers had prepared to go on without musicians Friday night, presenting their shows with digitally produced music.
Producers lost that option when the unions representing actors and stagehands decided to honor the musicians' picket lines, a move that effectively shut down musical Broadway and created a sense of economic emergency, given the strike's impact on restaurants, hotels, taxis and other theater-related businesses.
City Hall officials said the potential economic damage led the mayor to call each side to the table. Mr. Bloomberg kicked off the evening by welcoming them to Gracie Mansion at 9 p.m. "I did try to explain to them how important this industry is to New York City," the mayor said. "I tried to explain that you can't always get everything you want, but if people work together, there is some way to find a common ground."
Mr. Dennison said: "He made clear there was a great deal at stake for the city. It came not as an order, but as an honest plea to the parties."
The negotiators were also affected by the deaths of the officers in Staten Island. "Without being overly dramatic, it does put things immediately into perspective," Mr. Bernstein said. "We're fighting about chairs in an orchestra and these two guys just gave up everything. It was a sobering beginning."
After spending six hours in Staten Island, the mayor returned to the mansion before 3 a.m. to check on the talks. The two sides came to terms around dawn, but they had to wait until the mayor returned from a speech at Barnard College to announce a deal around 9:30 a.m.
Many of those involved said the presence of Dr. Macchiarola, the president of St. Francis College in Brooklyn, gave the talks an aura of the end game. Mr. Bloomberg went so far as to call him "the savior."
"Without his assistance in this, it couldn't have been done," said Bill Moriarity, president of the musicians' union.
Dr. Macchiarola said that when he arrived at the talks he had a line from St. Francis in mind: "It is in giving that we receive."
"That's what happened in these negotiations," he said. "Both parties gave. They made considerable concessions. They made giant steps."
He shuttled back and forth between the two sides, who were in separate rooms. "I have no interest in where this ends," he said he told them. "I only have an interest in it ending."
The mediator would not let the two sides have breakfast until a deal was reached; when they finally ate, it was scrambled eggs, bagels and fruit.
The settlement requires sacrifices of both sides. The producers still have to apply for exceptions if they want to employ fewer than the minimum number of musicians. But the contract's clause that handles those appeals was made considerably more flexible.
The provisions on minimums are good for 10 years, but the main contract would last four years and provide for annual raises of 2.5 percent. The union's members have 10 days to ratify the deal. 
"We could have gotten much closer to what we wanted, but that would have taken a long and possibly very bitter strike," said the producer Rocco Landesman. "There wasn't a lot of stomach for that, particularly at this economic time."
The producers say the union again succeeded in guaranteeing employment for some of its members. But the musicians note that they have essentially seen a quarter of their jobs eliminated. "I'm very disappointed," said Lisa Pike, a French horn player who substitutes in about 10 different Broadway shows and is about to start in the pit of "42nd Street."
"In the last negotiations we lost eight chairs over all of Broadway," Ms. Pike added. "Now in some cases we're losing eight chairs a show."
Among the many unions representing Broadway employees, there was a strong sense that the producers had miscalculated when they predicted that actors and stagehands would not honor the musicians' picket lines. Had the musicals remained open, management's hand would have been greatly strengthened.
"The league never seemed to understand us when we said the actors would not cross because they didn't like to perform before virtual orchestras," said Alan Eisenberg, executive director of Actors' Equity Association. "Their strategy went awry."
Officials with the musicians' union said that the united front grew out of the unusually close cooperation among the unions in reopening shows after the 9/11 attack closed Broadway for two days. "The settlement would have been far worse for us if the other unions had crossed our picket line," Mr. Dennison said.
Mr. Landesman, the producer, said he was frustrated that the contract mandated a minimum number of musicians. "There are no economies of scale or technology," he said. "We are handmade and labor-intensive. This is an attempt to come to terms with that and to try to keep our product priced reasonably."
But some music professionals say that orchestras will forever be diminished. "The reality is, if you say, 'We could really use two more for the brass section,' it's going to be, 'Too bad, 18 is the number, figure it out,' " said Paul Gemignani, a prominent music director.
"You won't be able to bring all the color," he added. "It's like saying to Van Gogh, 'Sorry, no orange.' "

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: LONDON; 
British Dissent Over an Iraq War Imperils Blair's Political Future

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 11 

 BODY:
For weeks and months, a seemingly unruffled Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has weathered a gathering storm of discontent among members of his Labor Party who are incensed -- or at least unsettled -- by his lock-step alliance with President Bush.
 But recently, as Mr. Blair has acknowledged that he might join a war in Iraq without a new authorization from the United Nations, that unease has crystallized into something more ominous. 
 Now, in by far the worst crisis for Mr. Blair since he took office in 1997, the dissent has given rise to a startlingly open debate about his political future. 
"I don't think it is possible to exaggerate the degree of concern about the illegality of what is proposed," said Tam Dalyell, a longtime and often maverick legislator from the Labor Party. "If there is no U.N. mandate and there is not a vote in the Commons before the commitment of British troops, then we ask the prime minister to consider his position as leader of the party."
The clearest sign of the severity of Mr. Blair's predicament came late Sunday when Clare Short, the influential and often outspoken cabinet minister, blind-sided the prime minister and his followers by threatening to resign if Britain joined the United States in a war in Iraq without a second United Nations Security Council resolution. Not only that, Ms. Short, the international development secretary, called his stewardship in the Iraq crisis "deeply reckless."
It is a seeming token of Mr. Blair's current political weakness -- or at least of his desire to avoid the perils of Ms. Short's being cast as a martyr to peace -- that he has responded with public silence, neither castigating nor dismissing her.
Mr. Blair's destiny seems entwined with developments at the Security Council, where France and Russia have threatened to veto Britain's proposals for a new resolution authorizing the use of force in Iraq, and with the nature of any military campaign to oust Saddam Hussein.
In essence, the prime minister is fighting a two-front campaign, one at at the Security Council and the other at home. 
"If there's no second resolution and the war is anything other than short, sharp and bloodless, he'll be in serious trouble," said Charles Grant of the Center for European Reform, an independent policy organization.
The latest opinion survey suggests growing disillusion with the allies' justification for war. The survey, published in The Times of London, said 62 percent of respondents did not believe that Britain and the United States had put forward a convincing case for war, compared with 57 percent a month ago. There appears to be a growing sense here that the weapons inspections are forcing Mr. Hussein to disarm, however falteringly, and should be given more time.
The survey showed that antiwar sentiment was building among Labor voters, while followers of the opposition Conservative Party had become more supportive of a war.
Other surveys suggest that a second United Nations resolution would swing public opinion behind Mr. Blair, giving developments at the Security Council with potentially more political consequences for Mr. Blair than they seem to portend for the White House.
The political crisis here has profound implications for Mr. Bush's "coalition of the willing," apparently raising doubts among some senior American officials about the likely impact of Labor Party dissent on Britain's ability to fight.
While Mr. Blair has given no indication that his resolve is weakening, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld seemed to hint today that Washington might even contemplate an initial campaign without Britain.
"What will ultimately be decided is unclear as to their role -- that is to say, their role in the event that a decision is made to use force," Mr. Rumsfeld said of the British, who have committed some 40,000 troops to join the 200,000-plus Americans in the Persian Gulf region. 
Mr. Rumsfeld later modified those remarks, saying he had "no doubt" about Britain's "full support" in the effort to disarm Iraq.
Mr. Blair had earlier castigated France and Russia for their readiness to ease the pressure on Mr. Hussein by rejecting a new United Nations authorization to invade Iraq.
"The only reason we made any progress at all in the past few weeks has been because of the threat of force," the prime minister said today after meeting here with the Portuguese prime minister, Jose Manuel Durao Barroso. "And my concern is that if countries talk about using a veto in all sets of circumstances, the message that sends to Saddam Hussein is, 'You are off the hook.' "
Mr. Blair has sent a senior foreign office official, Baroness Amos, to the impoverished African countries of Cameroon, Angola and Guinea, which are current members of the Security Council. That trip follows that of the French foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin. Both envoys have sought to swing the undecided African nations in their favor.
"In going to war without the sanction of the United Nations, we will see the prospects for another fine Labor government disappear," said Hilton Dawson, a legislator who was one of 122 Laborites to challenge Mr. Blair in Parliament last month on the need to go to war. "We will see the distinct possibility of this Labor Party being brought to its knees." 
John McDonnell, another Labor rebel, declared, "We are asking Tony Blair to consider his position."
That same discontent has been drummed home to Mr. Blair in televised meetings in the last week with audiences as disparate as young rock fans in an MTV studio to women in a television debate on Monday night. Some of the women were mothers of people who died in the attacks on New York on Sept. 11, 2001, or in the first Persian Gulf war a decade earlier. Some harangued Mr. Blair. Many urged him not to go to war.
The misgivings have been echoed by student leaders as well as a former Labor defense minister, Denis Healey, who said Mr. Blair's unequivocal support for Washington was "a disastrous error."
Mr. Blair stands accused of losing touch with the traditional, pacifist grass roots of the Labor Party, but draws strong backing from the Conservatives. The impact on parliamentary arithmetic is clear and not necessarily threatening to Mr. Blair. Even if more than 120 Labor legislators vote to oppose him, as happened last month, he can still count on the support of most of the 165 Conservatives. In addition, Labor has a huge majority, with 411 of the 659 seats. But if Mr. Blair was seen to be depending on the Conservatives for his political survival while his own party revolts, his position could be weakened still further.
The Labor Party's mainstream heavyweights have moved to squelch rebellious talk.
John Reid, the party chairman, today dismissed the mavericks like Mr. Dalyell as "the usual suspects." On Monday, Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, who is often depicted as the person most likely to succeed Mr. Blair, declared that "the whole country should support Tony Blair in his determination to secure international agreement for a second resolution."
That was significant, said Mr. Grant at the Center for European Reform. "The only person who matters is Gordon Brown, and he was being very supportive," he said.

HEADLINE: House Budget Chairman Vows Tax Cuts and Balanced Budget 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11 

 BODY:
The chairman of the House Budget Committee promised today to produce a budget this week that would include all the tax cuts President Bush wanted and still show a balanced budget in seven years because of spending cuts far deeper than Mr. Bush was proposing.
 In the Senate, opposition to the tax reductions mounted. A bipartisan group of senators who characterize themselves as moderates and who hold the balance of power in the Senate said today that they were close to agreement on a plan that was a fraction of the cuts the president wants. 
 The House and Senate budget committees are to vote on Wednesday on a budget resolution. That measure is supposed to establish the framework for all the tax and spending legislation that will become law this year and that will set the procedures for debating those measures.
The House budget chairman, Representative Jim Nussle, Republican of Iowa, told reporters he had drafted a plan for his committee that would include all $1.5 trillion in tax cuts over 10 years that Mr. Bush sought, the $400 billion he wants to allow some prescription drug coverage under Medicare and a spending increase in the next fiscal year for Medicaid, the mushrooming federal-state health program for the poor.
Mr. Nussle said his plan, unlike the president's budget, would lead to a balanced budget in seven years. He would accomplish that, he said, with deep spending cuts that could involve all programs except Social Security, unemployment insurance, domestic security and the military.
Under his plan, he said, government spending would rise 3 percent in the fiscal year 2004, which begins on Oct. 1. But Mr. Nussle said total spending for all the programs except the military and domestic security that require annual Congressional appropriations would be reduced in actual dollars.
The Congressional Budget Office, the nonpartisan staff that advises Congress on fiscal and economics issues, reported last week that under the budget Mr. Bush sent to Congress last month, the budget would not be in balance in any of the next 10 years and that over that period, the cumulative deficit would be $1.8 trillion.
Mr. Nussle said his budget, which begins with the fiscal year 2004, would not allocate any money for a possible war against Iraq. If there is a war, Mr. Nussle said, he hoped that its cost would fall in this fiscal year and that allies would help bear the postwar costs.
Democrats plan to offer an alternative that would allow a much more generous drug measure than the Republican plan. But the Democrats are sure to be outvoted.
Party discipline in the House is so strong that Mr. Nussle's plan is almost certain to be approved intact by his committee this week and by the full House next week.
The Senate is another matter. There, almost all Republicans favor the president's tax package and almost all Democrats oppose further cuts. A group of about 12 senators, about half Republicans and half Democrats, have been meeting for weeks to develop a compromise.
Today, several of those senators said they planned to send a letter to the leadership specifying that they would not vote for tax reductions above a certain figure. One senator, Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, said that the figure would be in the range of $350 billion over 10 years, about half of what Mr. Bush proposed.
Democratic leaders said budget decisions should be set aside until the Iraq problem had been clarified. 
"What meaningful purpose does the budget have if we can't stay within several hundred billion dollars of what the budget will be?" the Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, asked. 
Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, a leader of the moderates who favor compromise, agreed, saying, "There are too many uncertainties out there." 
But Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee and who is the most influential voice in the Senate on taxes, said: "I don't know if there's going to be a war. But we've got an economy that is fragile now, and tax reductions are the key."

HEADLINE: I Vant to Be Alone 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD; E-mail: liberties@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
It will go down as a great mystery of history how Mr. Popularity at Yale metamorphosed into President Persona Non Grata of the world.
 The genial cheerleader and stickball commissioner with the gregarious parents, the frat president who had little nicknames and jokes for everyone, fell in with a rough crowd. 
 Just when you thought it couldn't get more Strangelovian, it does. The Bush bullies, having driven off all the other kids in the international schoolyard, are now resorting to imaginary friends. 
Paul Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense, spoke to the Veterans of Foreign Wars here yesterday and reassured the group that America would have "a formidable coalition" to attack Iraq. "The number of countries involved will be in the substantial double digits," he boasted. Unfortunately, he could not actually name one of the supposed allies. "Some of them would prefer not to be named now," he said coyly, "but they will be known with pride in due time."
Perhaps the hawks' fixation on being the messiahs of the Middle East has unhinged them. I could just picture Wolfy sauntering down the road to Baghdad with our new ally Harvey, his very own pooka, a six-foot-tall invisible rabbit that the U.S. wants to put on the U.N. Security Council.
Ari Fleischer upped the ante, conjuring up an entire international forum filled with imaginary allies.
He suggested that if the U.N. remained recalcitrant, we would replace it with "another international body" to disarm Saddam Hussein. It wasn't clear what he was talking about. What other international body? Salma Hayek? The World Bank? The Hollywood Foreign Press Association?
The not-so-splendid isolation of the White House got worse this afternoon when Donald Rumsfeld suggested the unthinkable at his Pentagon briefing: we might have to go to war without Britain.
Even though Tony Blair said he was working "night and day" to get us international support (and beating back a revolt in his own party), Mr. Rumsfeld dismissively remarked that it was "unclear" just what the British role would be in a war.
Asked whether the U.S. would go to war without "our closest ally," he replied, "That is an issue that the president will be addressing in the days ahead, one would assume."
The Brits covered up their fury with typical understatement, calling Rummy's comment "curious." But behind the scene, Downing Street went nuts and began ringing Pennsylvania Avenue, demanding an explanation. How could Rummy be so callous about "the special relationship" after Mr. Blair had stuck his neck out for President Bush and courageously put his career on the line, and after he had sent one-quarter of the British military to the Persian Gulf?
Even though Mr. Rumsfeld scrambled later to mollify the British, one BBC commentator drily said that perhaps he was trying to be sensitive, but "as we all know, Donald Rumsfeld doesn't do sensitive very well."
Now we've managed to alienate our last best friend. We are making the rest of the world recoil. But that may be part of the Bush hawks' master plan. Maybe they have really always wanted to go it alone.
Maybe it has been their strategy all along to sideline the U.N., deflate Colin Powell and cut the restraining cords of traditional coalitions. Their decision last summer to get rid of Saddam was driven by their desire to display raw, naked American power. This time, they don't want Colin Powell or pesky allies counseling restraint in Baghdad.
Rummy was unfazed by Turkey's decision not to let our troops in, and he seemed just as unruffled about the prospect of the Brits' falling out of the war effort. And in a well-timed display of American military might, the Air Force tested a huge new bomb called MOAB in Florida. Tremors traveled through the ground, and the scary dust cloud could be seen for miles. 
"These guys at the Pentagon -- Wolfowitz, Perle, Doug Feith -- when they lie in bed at night, they imagine a new book written by one of them or about them called, 'Present at the Recreation,' " an American diplomat said. "They want to banish the wimpy Europeanist traditional balance of power, and use the Iraq seedbed of democracy to impose America's will on the world."
The more America goes it alone, the more "robust," as the Pentagon likes to say, the win will be.

HEADLINE: Natalie Merchant, No Strings Attached 

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Natalie Merchant has stepped off the pop treadmill. After 17 years with Elektra Records, first as the main songwriter and singer of 10,000 Maniacs and then with million-selling solo albums of her reflective folk-rock, Ms. Merchant decided to go it alone. 
 When her Elektra contract expired in August 2002, she chose not to renew it or to seek a deal with another major label. "I would make a big-budget pop album, followed by a year of touring and promotion and then some downtime for recovery," she said. "I don't even know if I was writing music that was appropriate for that mold." Instead she will release her next album, a collection of traditional songs called "The House Carpenter's Daughter," on her own label, Myth America Records. It is to be released June 1 through Ms. Merchant's Web site, nataliemerchant .com, and July 1 in stores.
 Recorded on a modest budget, marketed primarily to existing fans and not relying on radio exposure, "The House Carpenter's Daughter" breaks free of the commercial pressures that have turned major-label releases into risky gambles that can cost a million dollars in promotion alone. In contrast, Ms. Merchant's transition suggests the model of a sustainable career for a musician who is no longer eager to chase hits. 
"The business is going one way, and Natalie's going another," said her manager, Gary Smith, also the general manager of Myth America. 
Ms. Merchant has little to lose. "I'm in a privileged position," she said by telephone from Hawaii, where she lives part of the year; she also has a home in upstate New York. "I'm beyond financially independent. I had a lot of success, and I gathered together a very large audience. And I was in a rare position, because my material was unorthodox as the pop-hit mold went, but I was able to sell multiplatinum albums and have relatively large hits." 
When a musician is signed to a label, the company pays for recording and promotion, then recoups expenses from the musician's royalties while retaining ownership of the finished recordings. (Elektra still owns Ms. Merchant's catalog; Rhino Records, distributed by the AOL Time Warner conglomerate that includes Elektra, is releasing a 10,000 Maniacs retrospective this summer.) A label also uses its expertise and clout to market and distribute an album. 
Ms. Merchant paid for recording and packaging "The House Carpenter's Daughter," including the $3.50 manufacturing cost of an elaborate box for the first 30,000 copies. (The CD will sell for $16.95.) The special package "was printed in America for three times the price in Hong Kong," Ms. Merchant said.
"It's just not in keeping with American business practice right now," she added.
Even so, "The House Carpenter's Daughter" needs to sell only 50,000 copies to break even, less than 15 percent of what "Motherland," her last album for Elektra, sold.
"We're not trying to recoup some enormous debt," Mr. Smith said. "The economics of making this record are very prudent. When we sell 200,000 copies, we'll be standing on our chairs, hollering. If we released this record with these kinds of goals on a major label, we would look like a failure. At Elektra, if you just sell 1.5 million, everyone goes around with their heads down." 
Ms. Merchant is not the first well-known musician to become independent. Prince, after battling Warner Records over his desire to release more music in a year than the label thought it could market, started his own company, NPG, and has since released double- and triple-CD sets at whim. Todd Rundgren markets his music directly to subscribers to his Web site, patronet.com.
"For those already through the door, doing it on your own is incredibly viable," said Jay Rosenthal, a music-business lawyer who represents the Recording Artists' Coalition. "It's going to be very attractive, and it's going to be a viable alternative even for bands who are doing well. The only reason to go to the major labels is to get your songs on the radio, to go for the promo money. If you don't need to get on the radio, and you've got a name, go out there and go for yourself. If there's any moment that artists should do it, it's now, before things get worse." 
He added that some musicians would have no choice, as he expected major labels to cut their rosters by 30 to 50 percent in the next year. 
Ms. Merchant's album "Motherland" was made before Sept. 11, 2001, and released shortly after. Her concert fans welcomed its somber songs. But Soundscan, which tabulates retail sales in the United States, shows that "Motherland" has sold about 398,000 copies, far fewer than "Tiger Lily," released in 1995, which has sold nearly 3.6 million, and "Ophelia," released in 1998, which has sold 1.2 million. 
" 'Motherland' was the best material I ever wrote, and I was really happy with the record," Ms. Merchant said. "I don't know if it was timing or the way the industry is today, but it just didn't seem to interest the label so much. And I thought, why fight an uphill battle for attention?"
Elektra, Mr. Smith said, "offered her a sizable amount of money to stay, at a juncture when she felt like she was ready to go."
The label does not comment on musicians who have left its roster, an Elektra spokeswoman said.
"The House Carpenter's Daughter" is a collection of other people's songs. Ms. Merchant began delving into them in 1999, before the film "O Brother, Where Art Thou" put traditional music back in the Top 10 in 2001. ("Motherland" was produced by T Bone Burnett, who also produced the "O Brother" soundtrack.) She researched books of folk songs and listened to field recordings collected by Alan Lomax; she also took courses in the history of American folk music at Bard College.
A few selections on the new album are well known, like the English ballad "House Carpenter" and the labor movement song "Which Side Are You On?"; others are rescued from archives. Ms. Merchant found one, "Weeping Pilgrim," in an 18th-century hymnal at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. "I really appreciate the songs as social documents," Ms. Merchant said. 
She performed them during a summer tour in 2000; since then, live versions have been circulating on the Internet. When the tour ended, she decided to take the band into the studio simply to document the songs. The road-tested band mixed banjo and fiddle with drums and electric guitar, like a bluesier and bluegrass-loving American cousin of the English trad-rock band Fairport Convention. Four days of sessions, recorded live and barely overdubbed, yielded the makings of the album. 
Ms. Merchant and Mr. Smith are now learning about marketing and distribution. "This is the first time that we don't have somebody watching over us," Mr. Smith said, "telling us that we can't do this, or it's going to cost too much money, or it's not going to work."
They expect fans to learn about the album from Ms. Merchant's Web site and through publicity and a small advertising campaign. To gauge demand, they may offer fans who order the CD in advance a downloadable file of a song from the sessions that is not included on the album. In an increasingly consolidated retail business, a handful of chain stores, like Borders and Barnes & Noble, have accounted for a large percentage of Ms. Merchant's sales in the past; now her label is approaching them directly.
"I don't know that every artist has the capability to go directly to these chains, but Natalie has a history," Mr. Smith said.
He doesn't rule out the possibility of more major-label efforts. But for the moment, Ms. Merchant sees them as unlikely. She says she may go live in Europe for a time; she's considering setting medieval Latin liturgical texts to music or making a children's album. Million-selling albums and loyal fans have given her the freedom to experiment.
"This is the kind of record I want to make, going forward," Ms. Merchant said. "I've been writing things that are much more obscure and sort of shelving them, thinking I can't getthis past a corporate boardroom and I won't even try." 
"I understand that the larger labels are just interested in the projects that can generate the most capital for their quarter," she continued. "But I didn't want to subject the music to that kind of corporate boardroom and radio censorship. Why subject myself and the work that I do to that kind of environment when it really doesn't matter any more?" 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Natalie Merchant will soon release an album on her own record label. (Associated Press)(pg. E1); Natalie Merchant, onstage in 2000. She says she wants to record free of marketing pressure: "Why fight an uphill battle for attention?" (Associated Press)(pg. E5)
