HEADLINE: High Design in Las Vegas? Viva! 

BYLINE:  By KARRIE JACOBS 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
HUGH FOGEL is not the first person to see Las Vegas as the most vital design city in America. Four years ago the magician Penn Jillette, a resident, called it the "design capital of the universe." And back in 1977, in their landmark book, "Learning From Las Vegas," Robert Venturi, Denise Scott Brown and Steven Izenour argued that the city was a more significant architectural influence than Rome. 
 But Mr. Fogel, 36, the owner with his wife, Bonnie, 42, of a design store called Unica Home, may be the first to embrace Las Vegas design not just for the uncontrollably exuberant thing that it is, but for what he believes it will someday be: a place where sexy, high-technology modernism will be developed not just for the cognoscenti but for the masses, a hybrid of Milan and Hollywood. 
 "I kept on saying: 'Hugh, there's a reason there's not a design store here. No one wants one here,' " Ms. Fogel recalled saying before the couple moved here from Detroit last year. But Mr. Fogel already smelled what draws gamblers and all manner of dreamers to Las Vegas. "There's so much possibility here," he said. 
Maybe so. But at some point the Fogels' experiment will have to confront the fact that Las Vegas is still a vast economic engine devoted to the production of novelty, not high culture. "It's largely spectacle that can be absorbed in one day," said David Rockwell, the New York architect who designed a Nobu restaurant in Las Vegas. "What it hasn't developed is a richness or depth, any reason to stick around. It's generally a one-night stopover for me." 
Las Vegas may still be more promising than Detroit, which the Fogels found too culturally leaden to welcome new design. By comparison, Las Vegas is America's fastest-growing city, with 6,000 people arriving every month. Many of them are, in Mr. Fogel's view, "looking to buy stuff."
Beyond the screaming lights of the Strip and the Seven Wonders of the World architecture, the Fogels detected a genuine, emerging design culture. Granted, the Rem Koolhaas-designed Guggenheim Las Vegas has closed its doors, but well-known designers are seemingly at work everywhere. At the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, there's a conspicuously understated branch of the restaurant Aureole by the noted New York designer Adam Tihany. Deep inside the Venetian, there's a bar called Tsunami with that disorienting made-in-cyberspace feel, crafted by the pioneering Los Angeles architecture firm Morphosis. Most casinos now feature at least one Modernist bar, an environment a little whiter, cooler and more restrained than everything around it.
"The last time we visited, I was smiling the entire time," Mr. Fogel said, referring to a reconnaissance trip he and his wife made. "It wasn't just because it was warm here and cold in Michigan. It was really because when you walk around here, you started to see snippets of design incorporated."
Last year, the Fogels bought a small, unassuming house in Las Vegas. A month and a half later, they packed up their suburban Detroit version of Unica, a 1,200-square-foot shop stuffed to the rafters with high modern design, mostly accessories and tabletop items, and moved it to an airy 8,000-square-foot shed in an industrial park a few miles southwest of the Las Vegas Strip. Their neighbors include a garage door wholesaler and a vitamin factory that has somehow positioned itself as an official stop on the Grand Canyon bus tours that depart from the Strip.
While the Fogels appreciate the city's native visual cacophony (the florid pink and purple decor of Circus Circus, the giant visages of Siegfried and Roy lording over the Strip like heads of state) they see it as a place where their brand of good design (floor-hugging Zanotta coffee tables, acrylic chairs by Gaetano Pesce, oddly dimpled white dinnerware by the Italian company Covo) could really take off, or at least sell better than it did in Detroit. Mr. Fogel refused to share sales figures, but said that the Las Vegas store, half a year out, is selling at about the same pace as the Detroit store after four years. While the store itself is not turning a profit, the couple's business is sustained by steady orders on their Web site (www.unicahome.com.)
The Fogels, whose monochromatic outfits and frameless glasses make them look out of place in this garish town, have embraced some aspects of Las Vegas life, like free valet parking and all-you-can-eat buffets. They visit the casinos a few times a month, mostly to look for connections between the Las Vegas of the Strip and the ultra-Modernist Las Vegas of their dreams.
"Hugh and I were in the Palms Hotel," Ms. Fogel said, "and they have a little cubicle that has a palm reader. And she says, 'Can I read your palms?' And I said, 'No, we want to buy those two lamps,' because they were Gaetano Pesce lamps. And she said, 'No, those aren't for sale.' "
WHAT the Fogels have created out in the desert fringe of the city, is an impressive design store, and not just by Las Vegas standards. It's a true-believer store, of roughly the same caliber as Moss in New York or Limn in San Francisco. It is one of about 50 high-end contemporary design stores in the country. Those stores are part of a growing trend of selling designer furniture directly to consumers, instead of selling just to the trade -- interior designers and architects -- who would pass them along to their clients at a markup of up to 40 percent. Ivan Luini, president of Kartell US, an Italian manufacturer of high-end plastic furniture, said the Fogels have made "a clever business and life move." And soon the Fogels will have plenty of company. The World Market Center, with 1.3 million square feet, is billing itself as "the largest and most comprehensive home furnishings showroom and convention complex in the West." It will open in downtown Las Vegas next year. The aim is to lure the furniture industry en masse to Las Vegas for trade shows and events.
Unica stocks design's greatest hits, the full range of tabletop items manufactured by Alessi, Michael Graves teapots, and plastic Bubu Stools by Philippe Starck. But the store specializes in rarer pieces that reflect the Fogels' own passions: a dining table in multicolored acrylics by Gaetano Pesce, a low white leather glide sofa by the brothers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec for Cappellini and a dazzling wall of dinnerware, the centerpiece of the store's bridal registry. A glance at the their wares suggests that what constitutes "good design" these days is almost as colorful, almost as variegated and weird as the design that draws the tourists to the Strip.
The locals, however, are not quite ready to make the leap. "When people come in, they think we're aliens," Mr. Fogel said. "They say stuff like, 'Cute.' " Experience has taught Mr. Fogel that the word "cute" is the kiss of death, code language for "no sale."
Nobody understands the code language of Las Vegas decor better than Roger Thomas, head of design for Steve Wynn, the casino mogul who built the Mirage, Treasure Island and the Bellagio. Mr. Thomas is now working on the look of La Reve, a casino named after a Picasso in Mr. Wynn's collection. Mr. Thomas, whose designs might be characterized as Las Vegas rococo -- no surface is left undecorated -- has consciously separated his personal style from his professional style. "I don't live with the same aesthetic I design," he said.
He lives in an angular concrete house designed by a Los Angeles architect, Mark Mack. Situated in Summerlin, a gated community west of the city, Mr. Thomas's house is arranged around an interior courtyard so he doesn't have to look at the neighboring mini-chateaus. He said he is pleased that Unica provides a good local source for the kind of furniture he buys for himself --though he's hasn't shopped there yet -- but he questions whether the locals will be flocking to the conspicuously understated store.
"I think Las Vegas is about buying into romantic images," he said. "I don't think you sell a sofa; you sell the romance of the sofa." Mr. Thomas suggested that Las Vegans are hooked on vignettes, "preassembled, ready for consumption, layer upon layer." These vignettes are exactly the kinds of environments Mr. Thomas designs, the sort that never give the eye a moment's rest. One would think that Las Vegas residents, unlike the tourists, would develop an allergy to prepackaged environments and, like Mr. Thomas, seek something different.
The Fogels' premise, that Las Vegas taste will eventually evolve upward, strikes some locals as fundamentally mistaken, as misguided as efforts to import opera and other forms of high culture. "What they fail to realize is that we have culture," said Daniel A. Greenspun, who once ran a highbrow local bookstore and is now president of the company that publishes Las Vegas Life magazine. "It's our culture. To me, its all about seeing what Vegas is and adapting." 
While the Fogels dream of someday having an outlet on the Strip, their goal now is to become a focal point for the small but growing art and design circle. One night last month, they threw a party in honor of two Los Angeles-based designers, Roz Hayes and Dani Stoller, whose company, Lush Life, designs and manufactures big, multiseat lounges shaped like abstract sculpture.
While the turnout for the party was relatively modest -- a heavy rainstorm practically shut the city down -- the crowd of more than 100 that braved the weather was rich in design professionals, developers and local businesspeople. One guest, John Gilmer, is exactly the kind of customer the Fogels were hoping to draw. Mr. Gilmer, an architect, had worked in New York for Robert A. M. Stern, but moved to Las Vegas last year to join Avery Brooks & Associates, a large design firm with an endless stream of work on homes, casinos and hotels.
"In New York, you may be hampered by the tradition that's there," he said. "Here it's free. It's like the Wild, Wild West in the 21st century."
Mr. Gilmer has used furniture from Unica in a series of model homes he has designed for Lake Las Vegas, a resort community in Henderson, 17 miles west of the Strip. The homes can be purchased, for $1 million or more, fully furnished, a common marketing strategy in the region. Las Vegans, after all, love their vignettes.
The Fogels like to take visitors to the places that give them confidence that they have made a a good move. Their tour of emerging Las Vegas modernism includes the Palms hotel and casino west of the Strip. The hotel tower, which glows like a mood ring at night , is topped by the Ghostbar, an exemplar of Wallpaper-magazine-inspired chic. The current season of MTV's "Real World was filmed in a suite on the 28th floor.
The place the Fogels are most excited about is Green Valley Ranch, a new casino in Henderson that features two bars designed by Architropolis, a firm based in Portland, Ore. Whiskey Sky is seamlessly chic with its dark swirly wood paneling and its white upholstered surfaces. Even a mural-size wall-mounted fireplace is framed in shiny white. Cooler still is the Drop Bar, a circular oasis separated from the gaming floor by scrim curtains. 
Mr. Fogel, for the first time in days, maybe for the first time since arriving in Las Vegas, offered a critical word. "It's too smooth, you know," he said while leaving the Drop Bar for the hectic casino floor. "It's too cool."
He may have just realized something: that Las Vegas is capable of digesting almost anything, whether it's Steve Wynn's Picassos, an artificial volcano, the Eiffel Tower, or a bar inspired by James Bond. Modernism has become the latest theme in a city that has excelled in transforming every movement in history into a theme. 
After the tour, Mr. Fogel backpedaled just a bit. "I've been talking with Bonnie about this," he said. "Just say Las Vegas is a design laboratory, O.K.?"

HEADLINE: Son of the Project Breaks Free; 
From Dealing and Getting Shot to Writing Books

BYLINE:  By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 8 

 BODY:
Yanier Moore walked up the concrete steps of one of the hulking brick buildings of the Ida B. Wells housing project, the same steps where he was critically wounded in a drug-related shooting five years ago. The bullet that ripped through his groin, severing an artery, is still lodged in his right leg. He was hustling drugs in the project back then, resigned to the idea that he had no other prospects.
 Now, making one of his regular visits to his old neighborhood on a gray, wintry afternoon, he was giving away copies of his book, "Triple Take," the ghetto crime novel he says he wrote between drug sales on a Brother word processor he traded for four bags of crack. His buddies began approaching, climbing out of cars and appearing from around corners and out of doorways. 
 "Hey, Random House!" one of his old friends, Mario Bennett, called out. He wanted a book. Everyone wanted books. 
Mr. Moore, who is 31 and calls himself Blak (pronounced like black), is a hero at this project on the South Side. He is no longer a drug dealer or a crack-smoking gang member or jail inmate but a social worker, a poet and an author. As so many people here know, his novel is being published by Random House this month. He will be the subject of an autobiographical documentary on National Public Radio's "All Things Considered" on Thursday and also leave for a book tour to Washington, Baltimore and Philadelphia. Against all odds, a son of the project is about to make his mark on the world not as a criminal or a victim or another sad statistic involving lost black men -- and not as a basketball player, either -- but as a writer.
"I pick up 'Triple Take' and flip through a couple pages and think, 'This is really something I wrote,' " Mr. Moore said. "It's a mixture of emotions: happy, sad, wonderment. Just getting to this point took so much."
To understand how astonishing Mr. Moore's journey has been, consider what the Ida B. Wells project is best known for by the outside world. This is the place where eight years ago a 5-year-old boy named Eric Morse was dropped to his death from the 14th floor of a building by two other boys, ages 10 and 11. His death became the defining symbol of Ida B. Wells. The gang killings and drug trafficking that had become routine by the 1980's stopped making headlines. So did articles about the children trapped in poverty and about adults unable to find their way into the legal economy.
Mr. Moore looked across the snow-covered vacant field to the spot where Eric died. The building was deemed so dangerous that the city eventually knocked it down. Mr. Moore has since moved to an apartment a few miles south, but his two young daughters are growing up in the project with their mother. Some of his closest friends are still here. He talks about the friend who is an artist, the one who can do complicated math problems in his head, the one who might have made it to the N.B.A.: all of them dealing drugs to survive. This is the Chicago that made Mr. Moore a drug dealer, a gang member and finally, a writer.
"As the man next to the man," he writes in the work in progress that is his memoir, using a street term for the inside expert, "I feel that fate has dealt me the cruel hand of watching these beautiful, talented, gifted, athletic, brilliant people waste away in the slums of the city. It's a hurting feeling, knowing that I know the truth about these people and that nobody else does or seems to care."
Even by the standards of Chicago's housing projects, Mr. Moore's childhood was bleak. When he was 2, he says, his father, Franklin Moore, a heroin addict, was shot to death while breaking into someone's house. Three years later, his mother, Betty Moore, a nurse's aide, died after being stabbed in the chest by her drunken boyfriend.
"I was sleeping with my mother atthe time," Mr. Moore recalled. "When she got up to open the door, I followed her. I was standing in the screen door when it happened."
He watched her die, he said. "It just seemed like she was embarrassed to die, like she disappointed me," he said. "It was just the look on her face."
He and his sister, Ytteb, who is a year older, began shuttling from one relative's apartment to the next. There were relatives who doled out beatings, Mr. Moore recalled. "I was a burden," he said. "It was, 'We poor, you another mouth to feed.' " By the time he was 7 or 8, he said, he had learned to steal food.
A big man who wears his hair in dreadlocks and has an easy gap-toothed smile, Mr. Moore was talking in his two-room apartment, sitting at the foot of the bed. A portrait of Malcolm X hung above the bed. His word processor was on his desk in the corner with pictures of his friends and his two daughters and toddler son on the wall above it.
As a small boy, he found one escape: books. "Ever since I was a child, I learned to lose myself in books," Mr. Moore writes in his memoir. "My favorite place on earth was the libraries of this city."
He became expert at stealing books. "I wanted the books," he said. "I didn't want to take them back."
Fantasy fiction was his favorite. "Once I got my hands on those books, it was over," he writes in his memoir. "You mean to tell me that I could do battle with magical creatures, ride horses, slay treacherous wizards, find unimaginable treasures and get the beautiful princess, all without leaving my filthy pallet on the floor?"
He was about 10, he says, when a tough, older teenager gave him "The Dopefiend," a novel by Donald Goines, now dead, a heroin addict from Detroit who had started writing in prison and has a large following among black readers in the inner city.
"I was sucked in," Mr. Moore said. "I knew dope fiends. It was about a ghetto. Donald Goines was writing about the world I lived in."
By 12 he was falling deeper into that world, living in abandoned apartments with friends and getting high on marijuana. By 15 he was selling dime bags of crack.
"They come looking for you," he said, speaking of the neighborhood dealers who were his first employers. "They say, 'You want some money shorty?' I jumped at it."
At the same time he was plowing through Goines's 16 novels and others by Goines's literary mentor, Robert Beck, a pimp novelist also called Iceberg Slim. He had started writing himself, rap lyrics, which turned into short stories. Meanwhile he went through high school in a drug haze.
He moved up in the drug hierarchy, selling cocaine by weight from an apartment at Ida B. Wells. At 20 he had his first daughter, went into a drug rehabilitation program and got clean, he says. But by 21, he was still in the drug trade.
"You're a predator," he said. "You're living in a predatory society. You start to rationalize it."
At 24 he sat down and started writing "Triple Take," he says. "I just wanted to be able to create something," he said. "I was just sitting there, thinking: 'What would I like to read about?' "
"Triple Take" unfolds on the gritty streets where the author grew up. The main character is released from prison after a 10-year term for armed robbery, determined to exact revenge on the three former friends who betrayed him to the police. He attends college in prison and plans eventually to help children.
Mr. Moore's first critic was his best friend, someone he called Black Jamie, a drug dealer back from prison who was later killed. "He'd say, 'Man, this is the new, improved Donald Goines,'" Mr. Moore said. "That's what made me go on." Jamie helped him get the prison scenes right, he said.
He sent "Triple Take" and a second novel to a publisher and was rejected. He kept dealing drugs.
Recovering from his wound, he made up his mind to get out of the drug business for good. He landed a job as a social worker with the state-financed Child Family Center on the South Side. Mr. Moore kept writing and getting rejection slips.
Three years ago a young man he knew from the Ida B. Wells neighborhood, Lloyd Newman, introduced him to David Isay, the documentary radio producer from New York. In 1993 Mr. Isay helped Mr. Newman and another young man from the project record an audio portrait of their lives that was broadcast on National Public Radio.
"When I first read his stuff, it knocked me off my feet," Mr. Isay said. He began sending Mr. Moore's work around to New York agents and editors. After a year of rejections Random House bought "Triple Take" for $15,000.
Mr. Moore hopes younger readers will pick up on his message, that drug dealers are ultimately held accountable. "Why I want the younger cats to read it," he said. "They're dealing drugs. Getting locked up come with it. Getting killed come with it."
Last summer he spotted a 12-year-old he knew selling drugs at the project. "I know exactly how he lives, with 14 people in a two-bedroom apartment. He's doing what he feels he ought to do. The hopelessness of the situation actually silenced me."
But now, Mr. Moore said, he hopes to run into the boy again, with his book. "It's not just me standing in the hallways speaking hollow words," he said. "It's saying 'You can actually do something.' If you see this book, this is a tangible accomplishment."

HEADLINE: For French, Apprehension About Travel to U.S. 

BYLINE:  BY MARY A. KELLY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 12 

 BODY:
Last week, Vincent Koehl, a senior executive at Walt Disney in Paris and a frequent traveler to the United States, put aside his concerns about anti-French sentiment and his anxieties about a looming war and caught a British Airways flight to Los Angeles.
 Three days later, Mr. Koehl and his co-workers cut their stay short and flew home, even though their departure forced the cancellation of an important meeting of Disney executives from Asia, Europe and Latin America Instead, he said, they will try to finish their business by e-mail messaging and teleconferencing. 
 "We were supposed to be in the States this week," he said, "but after seeing the latest developments on the news, we canceled in the event the war begins this week." The group was concerned about being stranded in America if a war started and the uncertainty surrounding an outbreak of fighting. 
As war talk intensifies, skittish foreign executives are revising their travel plans to the United States. Some are canceling or postponing their trips, others are shortening them or looking for ways to avoid clogged airports. For the French, travel to America can be particularly unsettling. Anti-French hostility, while so far muted, is percolating below the surface, they say. And though it rarely boils over, it is often on their minds.
"I was very apprehensive before my trip to the States in February," said Marie-France Garros, an independent consultant with the Italian publisher De Agostini. "Being French, I wasn't sure what to expect."
Getting stranded or delayed in an airport is a bigger worry, of course. Philippe Messager, the group treasurer for the French utility company Vivendi Environnement and a frequent traveler to the United States, mostly avoided that problem on a recent trip by hiring a private plane for stops in Chattanooga, Tenn.; Columbus, Ohio; Houston; Milwaukee and New York.
But Mr. Messager and his group took a commercial flight on the last leg, to Cincinnati from Columbus, and that is when they received a taste of what so many American travelers have endured in the last year and a half. 
"There were long delays," he said. "And when I passed through the gate, the guy stopped me to look through my bags. I had to remove my shoes and my shirt. It took at least 15 minutes to be checked by this guy; it was a nightmare."
Most French executives say their companies have not yet issued formal policies on travel to the United States. Until they do, probably sometime soon, employees are free to make their own decisions.
The lackluster world economy has also influenced the travel habits of French executives. Jacques Alonso, a director of country sales for American Airlines in Paris, says more French executives are flying coach because they can no longer afford business class. Beginning April 1, he says, American Airlines will cancel first-class service on all its 767's worldwide. 
"We only have 767's flying from Paris, so we'll only do two classes, business and coach," Mr. Alonso said. "We'll add another row in business and about four rows in coach. It is what the customer in the French market is looking for -- they don't need beds."
Once they land in America, one thing they encounter is anti-French sentiment, fueled by France's opposition to a war with Iraq. Most French travelers say the French-bashing is confined to the political arena, talk shows and good-natured ribbings by American colleagues, and is not aimed at them. Still, they are finding themselves being questioned by Americans about French foreign policy. Most are careful not to provoke their hosts by flaunting their nationality or offering political opinions, but occasionally the conversations do become pointed.
"I was asked everywhere about my opinion, even in Asia," said Emmanuelle Mace Driskill, a manager in Paris for the luxury products company Givenchy, who made trips to New York and Guam in late January and to Hong Kong in February. "People are curious to know why France is saying no to the U.S."
"Americans told me: 'France forgot about what we did 60 years ago," Ms. Driskill said. "I'd say: 'When the U.S. was created, France was in favor of giving freedom to the colonies. So how far back do you want to go in history?' People are curious, but there was no gun pointed at my head."
Other executives say they felt frustrated by the anti-French jokes and comments they hear, especially because they do not believe that Americans understand the French position.
"Everybody here has an opinion about the French position, but I have the impression that no one has really heard the French voice," said Olivier Chereau, a banker at Societe Generale's New York office. On the other hand, he said, "my U.S. colleagues don't care what I'm thinking about and everyone is very professional."
"Of course, on television I have the impression of being attacked all the time," Mr. Chereau said. "The television here is very anti-French."
Even so, that sentiment apparently has not spilled over into the economic sphere. Mr. Chereau says the owner of a French restaurant in New York told him only two or three patrons had made an issue of France's diplomatic stand, despite talk in some quarters of a boycott of French products.
And Mr. Messager of Vivendi Environnement, whose principal shareholder is Vivendi Universal, the conglomerate, seemed equally unworried. "We make 20 percent of our revenues in the U.S. and as far as I can see, we don't have a problem," he said. "Assuming there is not a war, if I had to travel there again tomorrow, I'd be very relaxed."
Asked what advice she would give to fellow French travelers to the United States, Ms. Driskill of Givenchy got right to the point. "Don't be too arrogant," she said, "the French have a reputation for this."
Mr. Chereau of Societe Generale urged his compatriots to pack a sense of humor and shrug off anti-French jokes. Just the other day, he said, his American boss showed him a drawing of a meeting in the United Nations. Security Council. "One guy in the drawing had his hand up and underneath it said something like 'Please, France, don't surrender,' " he said. "I didn't say anything. I laughed; it was funny, but I didn't agree with it."

HEADLINE: COMMODITIES; 
Oil Futures Hit 12-Year High On News of Inventory Decline

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil futures closed at a 12-year high yesterday, for the third time in the last two weeks, after the Energy Department reported an unexpected decline in inventories.
 Supplies of crude oil last week fell 1.4 percent, to 269.8 million barrels, the department said. Inventories were 16 percent lower than they were a year earlier and close to a 28-year low. Analysts had expected an increase. The decline came as the United States appears headed for a war in Iraq, which pumps about 3 percent of the world's oil. 
 "This is a big problem," said John Kilduff, senior vice president for energy-risk management at Fimat USA in New York. "You don't want to have low oil inventories when the country is about to go to war."
Crude oil for April delivery rose $1.11, or 3 percent, to $37.83 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, registering the highest closing price since Oct. 16, 1990, when the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait cut off exports from both countries.
Prices reached $39.99 a barrel during trading on Feb. 27, the highest intraday price since October 1990, when futures rose to a record $41.15.
In London, the April Brent crude-oil futures contract rose 62 cents, or 1.9 percent, to $33.91 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange.
Crude oil imports fell 12 percent, to 7.62 million barrels a day in the week ended March 7, the weekly report on petroleum inventories, production and imports said.
"This is as bad as it gets," said Ed Silliere, vice president for risk management at Energy Merchant in New York, which markets gasoline and heating oil to local distributors. "Supplies are very tight."
Analysts had expected that increasing imports from Venezuela and Saudi Arabia would send inventories higher. A strike in Venezuela had been limiting shipments to the United States.
Venezuela pumped about 3 million barrels of oil a day before the strike began in December and now is pumping 2.7 million barrels a day, according to the Venezuelan government. Striking oil workers say production is closer to 1.9 million barrels a day.

HEADLINE: Taxing the Binge 

BYLINE:  By Jim Gogek; Jim Gogek, an editorial writer for The San Diego Union-Tribune, is a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation fellow.

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO 

 BODY:
In the next few months, legislators across the country, struggling with the worst fiscal crisis to hit states since World War II, will cut the financing of social programs. This will probably mean the demise of many alcohol and drug programs that keep adults out of jails and emergency rooms and children out of foster care and juvenile halls.
 There is a solution: raise alcohol taxes to pay for social services. Taxes on alcohol don't even begin to pay the costs of alcohol abuse. Federal estimates put those costs at $185 billion, while federal, state and local alcohol tax revenues total about $18 billion. 
 Alcohol excise taxes used to be a significant slice of federal budget receipts, representing 11 percent in 1941. Today, they're less than 1 percent and dropping. Because of pressure from the alcohol industry, federal liquor taxes have increased only twice since 1951, and beer and wine taxes only once. Meanwhile, a few states have raised taxes a little while others have cut them. With inflation, the real value of state alcohol taxes has fallen by half since 1966.
Increasing state alcohol taxes would not only provide more money to reduce problems caused by alcohol abuse, it would also reduce alcohol abuse itself by raising prices, according to a federal report to Congress. Several studies show higher taxes particularly cut drinking by teenagers, who have less money than adults to buy alcohol.
But probably the most compelling argument for raising alcohol taxes is this: it makes the industry shoulder a more equitable share of responsibility for the problems caused by alcohol abuse. And the fact is that the industry makes most of its profits from that abuse. Binge drinking (five or more drinks at a time) accounts for 83 percent of all alcohol consumed. And sales to under-age drinkers amount to nearly 20 percent of the total market, or about $20 billion in illegally purchased alcohol, according to a study last month in The Journal of the American Medical Association. 
Raising taxes would also make the heaviest drinkers pay more, which is fair because they're the ones associated with the worst alcohol-related problems.
It's worth noting that the alcohol lobby is more powerful than ever, and that it is a significant contributor to political campaigns. Beer wholesalers gave about $160,000 last year to politicians in New York. Gov. George Pataki is pushing a plan to cut beer taxes, despite a $12 billion shortfall over the next two years. The reduction would leave New York with some of the lowest beer taxes in the nation.
In California, the alcohol industry donated $2.4 million in 2002, including nearly $260,000 to Gov. Gray Davis. Mr. Davis has supported raising cigarette taxes to help close the state's $35 billion gap, but not alcohol taxes.
So far this year, 17 states have proposed raising alcohol taxes, but many have retreated in the face of the uproar from the alcohol industry. Tax increase proposals are fading in Ohio, Georgia and New Mexico. The Maryland governor has promised to veto proposed sin taxes. In South Dakota, lobbyists for alcohol retailers and wholesalers just persuaded legislators to kill a bill that would have raised taxes a mere 4 cents per drink. Industry influence is paying off.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Are Modestly Higher With Iraq Still the Subtext

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks finished modestly higher yesterday, lifted by late-session bargain hunting after the Dow Jones industrial average pushed close to a five-year low. The gains came despite market wariness about the deadlock in the United Nations Security Council over Iraq.
 Before rebounding, the Dow fell more than 100 points, led by a brokerage firm's downgrading of oil stocks. But analysts played down the significance of the turnaround, noting that the number of declining issues outpaced those advancing. 
 "A lot of the technicals have been talking about the market being oversold," said Mike Weiner, managing director for equities at Banc One Investment Advisers. "When you start to see things like that, you may see a day or two of rallies."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.01 points, or 0.37 percent, at 7,552.07, after a two-day loss of some 216 points to a five-month low. The Dow is about 265 points above its five-year closing low of 7,286.27, reached on Oct. 9.
Broader indexes also finished higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.46 points, or 0.43 percent, to 804.19. The Nasdaq composite index gained 7.77 points, or 0.61 percent, to 1,279.24.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers on the New York Stock Exchange about 4 to 3. Volume was 1.63 billion shares, up from 1.44 billion on Tuesday. There were 36 new highs and 316 new lows.
Wall Street has experienced choppy, if largely negative, trading in recent weeks as investors make short-term bets on how soon a war with Iraq might begin and how costly it would be. Analysts said that until there is some resolution, businesses will refrain from the capital spending sorely needed to revive the economy.
The United States and Britain have been trying to win Security Council approval for giving Iraq a March 17 deadline to disarm or face war. They face stiff resistance, and yesterday, Britain set out a list of conditions for Iraqi disarmament, hoping to gain support. 
Scott Wren, equity strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons, suggested setting "a deadline for war or peace, so we can turn to concerns that are more economically oriented."
Mixed news on the nation's trade deficit did little to inspire investors. The Commerce Department reported that the trade gap narrowed n January, to $41.1 billion, from December's deficit of $44.9 billion.
Gainers included Ford, which climbed 48 cents, to $7.08, after UBS Warburg upgraded its stock to neutral from reduce. General Motors rose 71 cents, to $30.63.
But oil stocks fell on a sector downgrading by J. P. Morgan. Exxon Mobil, a Dow component, dropped 51 cents, to $34.06, while ChevronTexaco lost 69 cents, to $63.05.
Battered European stocks fell further, with the benchmark index in Germany down 4.44 percent, in France down 3.62 percent and in Britain down 4.80 percent.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Prices Mixed
(By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices were mixed yesterday, as yields neared half-centurylows and a rebound in stocks deterred some investors from buying the fixed-rate securities.
"Treasuries are running out of steam," said Gary Pollack, who helps manage $10 billion at Deutsche Bank's private banking unit. "You have to wonder how much they can rally at these levels. How much lower can they go?"
The benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 1/32, to a price of 102 13/32. The note's yield was unchanged at 3.59 percent. The 30-year bond rose 18/32, to 111 30/32. Its yield fell to 4.61 percent from 4.64 percent.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Is Narrower As Economy Slows Buying 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12 

 BODY:
The trade deficit narrowed in January from a record as Americans bought fewer foreign-made goods in a slowing economy and exports rose, the Commerce Department reported today.
 The trade gap in goods and services was $41.1 billion, trailing only a revised $44.9 billion deficit in December, the department said. For all of last year, the deficit reached a record $435.7 billion. 
 Growth forecasts are slipping as consumers rein in spending and business investment is stagnant, suggesting that Americans may buy fewer imported goods. Economic growth may ebb this year to 2.3 percent from 2.4 percent in 2002, a U.C.L.A. study said. In February, manufacturing slowed, 308,000 jobs evaporated and consumer confidence reached a nine-year low.
"We will see less inventory building in the first quarter and therefore fewer imports," given the prospect of war with Iraq and the slowing economy, said Elisabeth Stoegmueller, a Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein economist in New York who projected that the deficit would narrow to $41.5 billion. "It comes down to final demand in the end, and that is just not picking up yet."
Imports fell 2 percent in January, to $123 billion, led by declines for autos and consumer goods, while exports rose 1.6 percent, to $81.9 billion, helped in part by a weaker dollar. The dollar has fallen 26 percent against the euro and 9 percent against the yen in a year, making American goods less costly relative to European and Japanese products.
Economists had forecast a deficit of $43.4 billion compared with $44.2 billion in December.
Imports of autos and parts dropped 4.9 percent in January, to $16.8 billion. Americans bought 3.9 percent less in imported consumer goods, and companies spent 1.1 percent less on capital goods like telecommunications equipment and computers.
Rising oil prices, spurred by political discord in Venezuela and war expectations in the gulf region, pushed the value of petroleum imports to $7.4 billion from $7 billion the previous month. The price of oil surged nearly 15 percent, and the number of barrels imported fell to 268.4 million from 289.3 million as Venezuelan exports dropped.
Shipments abroad of consumer goods rose 6.9 percent in January, to $7.4 billion, led by a surge in pharmaceuticals. Foreign companies bought 2.5 percent more capital goods.

PERSON: Howard Fast 

HEADLINE: Howard Fast, 88, Best-Selling Novelist, Dies 

BYLINE:  By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
Howard Fast, whose best-selling historical fiction often featured the themes of freedom and human rights, elements in his own tumultuous political journey through the blacklisting of the 1950's, died yesterday at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 88.
 Mr. Fast was one of the 20th century's busiest writers, turning out more than 80 books -- plus short stories, journalism, screenplays and poetry -- in a career that began in the early 1930's. 
 With novels like "Citizen Tom Paine" (1943), "Freedom Road" (1944) and "Spartacus" (1953), Mr. Fast won popular acclaim for authenticity and detail, creating stories that even his critics admired as page-turners. 
Mr. Fast's fiction was always didactic to a degree, opposed to modernism, engaged in social struggle and insistent on taking sides and teaching lessons of life's moral significance, and he liked it that way.
"Since I believe that a person's philosophical point of view has little meaning if it is not matched by being and action, I found myself willingly wed to an endless series of unpopular causes, experiences which I feel enriched my writing as much as they depleted other aspects of my life," he said in a 1972 interview. 
Despite the international popularity of historical novels like "Paine," which glorified the professional revolutionary, and the huge commercial success that Mr. Fast's well-paced narratives achieved, his work tended to succeed or fail as art to the extent that he distanced himself from ideology. 
At his best, in a novel like "The Last Frontier" (1941), about the flight in 1878 of the Cheyenne Indians to their Powder River home in Wyoming, he achieved powerful effects through imaginative objectivity. At his less successful, in novels like "Clarkton" (1947), about a textile-mill strike, and "Silas Timberman" (1954), about an academic victim of McCarthyism, he was sometimes faulted as being drawn toward propagandistic sentimentality.
His output was slowed but not entirely interrupted by the blacklisting he endured in the 1950's after it became known that he had been a member of the Communist Party and then refused to cooperate with the House Un-American Activities Committee. He served three months in a federal prison in 1950 for contempt of Congress, a charge arising from his refusal to produce the records of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee.
Mr. Fast joined the party in 1943, a decision he often said was made at least in part because of the poverty he experienced as a child growing up in Upper Manhattan. He left the party in 1956, disillusioned by the Soviet Union's own stunning revelations of Stalin's terror and the spread of anti-Semitism there.
He wrote a book about his political experiences, "The Naked God" (1957). "I was part of a generation that believed in socialism and finally found that belief corroded and destroyed," he said in an interview in 1981. "That is not renouncing Communism or socialism. It's reaching a certain degree of enlightenment about what the Soviet Union practices. To be dogmatic about a cause you believe in at the age of 20 or 30 is not unusual. But to be dogmatic at age 55 or 60 shows a lack of any learning capacity."
Howard Melvin Fast was born Nov. 11, 1914, in Manhattan, one of four children of a working-class couple. His father, Barney, was first an ironworker, then a cable-car conductor, then a garment worker. His mother, Ida, died when he was a child. He often worked part-time jobs to help make ends meet, and graduated from George Washington High School.
He sold his first story to Amazing Stories magazine when he was 17. The next year he sold his first novel, a historical romance called "Two Villages," to the Dial Press for a $100 advance.
In 1939, after he had published two more books, Simon & Schuster published "Conceived in Liberty," a novel about Valley Forge, which has sold about a million copies and has been translated into more than a dozen languages. That was followed by "The Last Frontier" and then "The Unvanquished" (1942), about George Washington during the bleakest months of the Revolution. The critic Carl Van Doren said "The Unvanquished" was "the next thing to having been on the scene at the time." 
But Mr. Fast's breakthrough came in 1943 with "Citizen Tom Paine," which the playwright Elmer Rice called, in a highly favorable front-page review in The New York Times Book Review, "a vivid portrait of one of the most extraordinary figures of the 18th century."
Many critics and historians agreed that the book played a significant role in restoring the reputation of Paine, the pamphleteer who had been "greatly neglected and greatly misunderstood," Rice wrote, "the victim both of a conspiracy of silence and of a campaign of calumny."
In 1944 came the best-selling "Freedom Road," about a former slave in the post-Civil War South who becomes a United States senator and then fights for his life against the Ku Klux Klan. In 1979 "Freedom Road" was made into a television mini-series starring Muhammad Ali and Kris Kristofferson.
From the start, Mr. Fast said, "Freedom Road" was more than a book with a black as the central character. "Its viewpoint," he said, "was considered a shocking one for either popular fiction or for history. In it, the Reconstruction was seen as a time of black renaissance. The carpetbaggers were not raping the South, as in the then popularly held view, but were helping the blacks to education and economic achievement." 
During those years, Mr. Fast won the Stalin International Peace Prize, in 1953, and "Spartacus," about a slave revolt in ancient Rome, was published. Because of the blacklist, the manuscript went from publisher to publisher without success. Finally, a Doubleday executive said that Mr. Fast should publish it himself but that Doubleday would order 600 copies for its bookstores. It became a best seller.
The stigma of the blacklist gradually faded after Mr. Fast's repudiation of Communism. "Spartacus" was reprinted as a paperback and in 1960 was made into a successful movie starring Kirk Douglas. Many other successful novels followed, including "April Morning" (1961) and a best-selling multigenerational saga of the Lavette family that began with "The Immigrants" (1977) and included "Second Generation" (1978), "The Establishment" (1979) and "The Legacy" (1981). 
Mr. Fast's first wife, the former Bette Cohen, died in 1994. He is survived by their children, the novelist Jonathan Fast of Greenwich and Rachel Ben Avi of Sarasota, Fla., and three grandchildren. He is also survived by his second wife, Mercedes O'Connor, whom he married in 1999, and by her three sons, Connor Denis, of Old Greenwich, Augustus Denis, of New Orleans, and James Denis, of Old Greenwich.
Mr. Fast also wrote a popular series of detective stories under the name E. V. Cunningham. His hero was a nisei detective, Masao Masuto, a member of the Beverly Hills police force. Masuto was a Zen Buddhist, and Mr. Fast himself was very much involved in Zen, "as a form of meditation and a very nice way of looking at the world," as he put it. 
Mr. Fast continued to write into his 80's. His last novel, "Greenwich," a story of a high-society dinner party in Greenwich, Conn., and an exploration of guilt and redemption in American society, was published in 2000.
"The only thing that infuriates me," he once commented, "is that I have more unwritten stories in me than I can conceivably write in a lifetime."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Pataki Sees The Enemy, Carrying Pens

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
"With your financial support, I will be able to get my message out to New Yorkers directly -- without distortion from the elite, liberal media -- and to fight on a level playing field with our opponents."
-- Gov. George E. Pataki, in a fund-raising letter to supporters last week, in which he also warned that "we cannot take these liberals lightly."
 NOW this is irresistible. A governor who has made an art of saying as little as possible about as much as possible is suddenly worried about getting his "message" across? For what purpose is he raising money if he is not planning an ad campaign against his "opponents," an intention denied by his chief spokeswoman, Lisa Dewald Stoll. 
 And who, pray tell, are "the elite, liberal media"? It is tempting to wax indignant at this point. Let us instead fall back on facts.
During his re-election campaign last year against H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, Mr. Pataki was endorsed by most major daily newspapers in the state, and they run the ideological gamut. Among those that supported him: The Times Union of Albany, The Post-Standard of Syracuse, The Record of Troy, The Star-Gazette of Elmira, The Staten Island Advance, The Daily Messenger of Canandaigua, The Poughkeepsie Journal, The Times Herald-Record of Middletown, The Buffalo News, Newsday, The New York Post, The Daily News and The New York Times. 
Could the "elite, liberal media" refer, perhaps, to The Post-Standard of Syracuse, which in its endorsement said it was time for Mr. Pataki "to burnish a legacy that will put him in the same company with the political giants who have led New York State in the past"? Maybe he meant The New York Times, which called him a "generally sensible steward of the public's money"? Or The Poughkeepsie Journal, which praised his environmental record?
Perhaps Mr. Pataki believes that the papers that supported him but now question his fiscal policies -- notably his opposition to higher taxes -- have fallen under the spell of the liberal elites. 
Or maybe his scorn is intended not for editorial writers but for reporters, who cover the news, which tends to cling to facts.
It is a fact that as a result of Sept. 11, a bad economy and the budget policies of the governor and the Legislature, the budget gap in this year's budget and next stands at a projected $11.5 billion. It is a fact that in just three years, the state budget has grown to $90 billion from $74 billion -- almost $10 billion more than was necessary to keep pace with inflation.
It is a fact that the governor expanded Medicaid benefits -- which he is now trying to cut back -- and that he spent money that could have improved health care on wages for hospital workers whose leader then endorsed him.
It is also a fact that to close the budget gap the governor wants to go deeper into debt, spend nonrecurring revenue and cut programs. And that he has been criticized not only from the left for refusing to raise taxes significantly but also from the right for not cutting enough and for raising fares and fees and supporting some modest tax increases.
As E. J. McMahon, an analyst with the conservative Manhattan Institute, points out, to complain about how the large budget gap developed -- by the governor and lawmakers spending generously and using up most of the state's reserve funds in an election year as the economy weakened -- "is not conservative or liberal."
Mr. McMahon, who does not take Mr. Pataki's letter very seriously, added that he has criticized the governor's current budget plan, "largely from the conservative point of view." 
"I am happy he is not increasing taxes," he said, "but I am concerned he is not doing enough to reduce spending." 
Eugene Keilin, former chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission and an alumnus of the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, said he considered it unfortunate that the state's budget problem had become so politicized. "We did not get through that fiscal crisis on ideology," he said. "People did what was practical, not what was ideological."
Perhaps Mr. Pataki could take a cue from the 1970's -- or better yet, the 1960's. His news media plaint recalls the famous advice once given to President Lyndon B. Johnson when, deeply mired in the Vietnam War and its deficits, he blamed the press for producing his "credibility problem." Unsparingly, the White House press secretary, George Reedy, told his boss: "You don't have a press problem. You have a political problem."

HEADLINE: 2 Committees Offer Budgets; Impact on Deficit Is in Doubt 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12 

 BODY:
The House and Senate Budget Committees presented budgets today that would cut taxes and eventually balance the budget, but the plans would accomplish deficit reduction in ways that are probably politically unrealistic.
 The House plan proposes a balanced budget in 2010. It reaches that level by showing nearly $500 billion in spending cuts in popular benefit programs like Medicare, Medicaid and veterans' health care. 
 The Senate plan would reach a balanced budget in 2013. It would restrict spending sharply for military and domestic programs in the fiscal years 2009 through 2013, with spending levels that might be easy to vote for this year but that might be difficult to justify as the years affected drew closer. 
The Senate plan also includes a proposal that the Republicans say they hope will increase the prospects for approval of oil exploration in environmentally sensitive areas of Alaska. 
Neither plan takes any account of a possible war against Iraq or reconstruction costs afterward, a fact that Democrats said made the plans unreliable.
The plans are called budget resolutions. They are not binding and do not carry the force of law.
The tax and spending levels for fiscal years beyond 2004, which begins on Oct. 1, are merely advisory and can easily be changed in the years ahead.
But the resolutions establish the framework for the actual tax and spending legislation Congress will consider this year for fiscal year 2004 and create parliamentary procedures that could affect the outcome of that legislation.
The plans show deficits in the 2004 fiscal year slightly lower than the one the president proposed in the budget he sent Congress last month.
As computed by the Congressional Budget Office, the president's budget calls for a deficit of $338 billion; the House committee, $324 billion; and the Senate committee, $330 billion. 
The details of the House and Senate committee plans are not so important at this stage because they are sure to be changed before a final plan is adopted by Congress. Both committees are stacked with Republican loyalists, who, as they showed in the House tonight, can outvote the Democrats at every turn.
But a group of moderate senators who hold the balance of power in the closely divided Senate have made it clear that they will not accept more than a part of the $726 billion in tax cuts that the administration proposed as an economic growth package and that both committees included in their plans.
What is more important than the details is the principle underlying the budget plans. It is that the only way to cut taxes and balance the budget is to reduce spending on the military or the most popular government benefit programs.
The Senate plan, for instance, appears to hold military spending in the fiscal years 2009 through 2013 below what the budget office says would be necessary to support the same spending levels President Bush has proposed for 2008.
The House plan would save $470 billion over the next decade in benefit programs. Assuming Social Security is untouchable, the reductions could not be attained without cutting Medicare, Medicaid, student aid, veterans' health care and other program that lawmakers are reluctant to vote against.
Representative Jim Nussle, Republican of Iowa and chairman of the House Budget Committee, insisted that the plan he drafted would "one, protect Americans; two, get Americans back to work and strengthen the economy; three, get the budget back on a path to balance."
But the top Democrat on the panel, Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, said the Republicans had "built their budget around their single-minded goal of enacting large and fiscally irresponsible tax cuts" that would lead to unacceptable reductions in essential programs like Medicare.
The Senate plan has two features that would be especially important if they end up in the final resolution.
One would allow Senate consideration of oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge under procedures that would not permit a filibuster.
That means the centerpiece of the administration's energy policy and one that is anathema to most Democrats and environmentalists could be approved by a majority vote instead of the 60 votes that would be needed to break a filibuster.
Based on senators' voting records and past statements of position, the Senate is divided almost 50-50 on the issue, and a majority vote could go either way, say lobbyists who follow the issue closely.
The other important feature would reinstate budgetary discipline rules that were in effect from 1991 until this year.
The rules were sometimes bypassed, but they were instrumental in achieving deficit reduction in the 1990's. 
One rule required any tax cut or increase in spending for a benefit program to be offset dollar for dollar by a tax increase or spending cut.
This rule would not go into effect until the Bush tax cuts were dealt with.
Another rule set specific spending caps on the government programs that are subject to annual Congressional appropriations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, left, and Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, at a Budget Committee meeting yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After Years of Cash Flow, Universities Hit an Ebb 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
For the first time in 15 years, charitable contributions to universities and colleges dropped last year, according to a survey of 960 institutions that will be released today. The figures provide some of the clearest evidence to date of the effect that a shrunken stock market and weakened economy are having on philanthropy.
 Educational institutions vie with churches for distinction as the nation's top beneficiaries of philanthropy, but in the year that ended June 30, 2002, donations fell 1.2 percent, to $23.9 billion, compared with $24.2 billion in the same period a year earlier, according to the survey. 
 Adjusted for inflation, giving to education fell 2.5 percent. "That may not seem like much, but it comes at a time when other sources of revenues like government support and income from endowments are also in decline," said Ann Kaplan, director of the survey, by the RAND Corporation Council for Aid to Education. 
Ms. Kaplan said three-quarters of the institutions responding to the survey reported a decline in 2002.
Georgetown University's experience was typical. After raising $92 million, a record, in the 2001 fiscal year, fund-raising fell 15.2 percent to $78 million the next year. "We're not used to declines," said Michael Goodwin, a vice president at Georgetown.
Mr. Goodwin said some of the decline could be attributed to the 2001 terror attacks, but Georgetown, like other universities, has been finding it harder to raise the multimillion-dollar gifts that helped spur increases over the last several years.
Those gifts are not gone. On Tuesday, Old Dominion University announced that Frank Batten Sr., who created the media empire called Landmark Communications Inc., had given it $32 million, and yesterday, Harvard Business School said that Mr. Batten had given the same amount to its capital campaign. 
University officials say they have heard reports that Mr. Batten plans eight more big gifts. He did not return a call to his office.
"That's the exception that proves the rule," Mr. Goodwin said. "Most of the people we're talking to who have the ability to make that kind of a gift are either not as well off as they were two or three years ago or they are uncertain about the future."
University fund-raising officials agree that winning donations is more difficult now, but some have still fared well. "We're on target here to have our eighth consecutive record year and hit the $100 million mark," said Christopher R. Reaske, vice president for development and alumni relations at Boston University.
Mr. Reaske said the university had pulled in $71.4 million as of March 7, a 39.5 percent increase over the same period last year. But Mr. Reaske said pledges of $10,000 and more were down 9.7 percent compared with last year. 
The survey showed giving fell most sharply, 13.6 percent, among alumni, who have traditionally accounted for the largest part of charitable giving to higher education. While support from foundations increased 5 percent and corporate giving held steady, they could not offset the drop in giving from alumni.
Carol Weston, an author of books for teenagers, planned to celebrate her 25th reunion this year with a larger than usual gift to her alma mater, Yale University. But after doing her taxes, she changed her mind.
"It would be great if this year I could say, 'You know, I'm going to give in the thousands instead of in the hundreds,' " Ms. Weston said. "But I just don't feel I can."
Development officials say it is too early to tell whether the fund-raising dip will continue.
"While we're ahead of the game now, we would adamantly stress that we'll still have to wait and see," said James Kunetka, executive vice president for communications in the office of resource development at the University of Texas at Austin. "I'm not at all ready to say this is going to be a banner year."
Cash contributions peaked three years ago, but in the first five months of this fiscal year, which began Sept. 1, $75 million came through the university's door, a 19 percent increase over the same period a year earlier.
Mr. Kunetka hesitated to call that a turnaround because he said some donors had paid pledges early, increasing gifts beyond what they might have been. 
"It's hard to know at this point how much is the economy and the stock market and how much is the normal ebb and flow of fund-raising," Mr. Kunetka said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Stock Option Reform Plan Is Stalled at the S.E.C.
A plan proposed last summer to give shareholders veto power over moves by companies to dole out stock options is stalled at the Securities and Exchange Commission, which concedes that the rule will not go into effect in time for annual shareholder meetings.
 Directors of at least one big company have approved a big stock option plan. Some shareholder advocates worry that other companies, too, will rush new options plans onto their books, in case the rule goes into effect by the end of the year. Page A1. 

The Financial Accounting Standards Board voted to overhaul rules on stock options and to push for greater disclosures from companies in their pension fund accounting. C5.

Some Interest in Publishing Houses
The first round of AOL Time Warner's auction of its book publishing houses Warner Books and Little, Brown drew preliminary bids from publishers, including Random House and W.H. Smith. HarperCollins, however, decided to drop out, diminishing the sense of strong competitive bidding. The company initially hoped to raise $400 million from the sale, but the price may well fall below that. C4.

Late Bargain-Hunting Lifts Stocks
Late-session bargain-hunting lifted stocks. The Dow Jones industrials rose 28.01 points, to 7,552.07. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.46 points, to 804.19. The Nasdaq composite gained 7.77 points, to 1,279.24. C7.

Lawmakers in Japan proposed several measures meant to prop up the stock market. World Business, Section W.

Crude oil futures closed at a 12-year high after the Energy Department reported an unexpected decline in inventories. C7.

Trade Deficit Narrows From Record
The trade deficit narrowed in January, to $41.1 billion from a record $44.9 billion in December, as Americans bought fewer foreign-made goods in a slowing economy and exports rose, the Commerce Department reported. C2.

MTV Refuses Antiwar Commercial
MTV has refused to accept a commercial opposing a war in Iraq, citing a policy against advocacy spots. Nonetheless, viewers in New York and Los Angeles will be able to see it starting today because its backers bought time on local cable. Advertising. C4.

The feud between the YES Network and Cablevision ended with a one-year deal to make the channel's Yankees and Nets games available to three million subscribers. D1.

El Paso Appoints Interim Chief
The El Paso Corporation appointed Ronald L. Kuehn Jr., a director, to be interim chief executive after the search to replace William A. Wise was disrupted by a proxy fight. C3.

Olivetti Chairman Plans Merger
Marco Tronchetti Provera, left, who is chairman of Telecom Italia and Olivetti, announced a plan to merge the companies by exchanging Olivetti stock for the 45 percent of Telecom Italia that Olivetti does not already own. Telecom Italia investors reacted with fury, saying the proposed merger would shortchange them. World Business, Section W.

Natalie Merchant Is on Her Own
After 17 years with Elektra Records, Natalie Merchant has decided to go it alone. She will release her next album this summer on her own label, Myth America Records. E1.

Why New Savings Plans Won't Work
Even as they put holes in the budget, President Bush's tax-deferred savings plans are unlikely to encourage people to put more money away. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: HOW IT WORKS; 
In a Single Swipe, a Wealth of Data (Beware of Thieves)

BYLINE:  By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
IT'S one of the unsung heroes of modern commerce, a small electronic device that, almost as much as oil and electricity, keeps the economy humming. Without the magnetic card reader, how would America's credit-happy society function?
 Card readers are found just about anywhere that money changes hands: at stores, restaurants, A.T.M.'s, even gas pumps. But they are also used in many other places where the currency is information, not cash. People attending trade shows, for example, are often given magnetic ID cards that with a simple swipe at a booth can pass along a name, address and phone number. It is the electronic equivalent of dropping off a business card. 
 But there is a dark side to this technology. Criminals have discovered that small battery-powered readers known as skimmers or wedges can be used to steal credit-card data from unsuspecting consumers. Counterfeit cards can then be made that can be used to ring up huge charges that may go undetected.
The card reader is a relatively simple device, at the heart of which is a head not unlike the head on atape deck. In fact, the stripe on a credit card is analogous to a short piece of magnetic tape. Like the music on a standard cassette tape, the information on the stripe is in analog, not digital, form.
All readers and cards are created under a set of technical standards established by the American National Standards Institute and the International Organization for Standardization. Every card of the same type must have the same data in the same places so they can work in readers worldwide.
On financial cards, the stripe on the back has three tracks of data that contain information like account number, account holder's name, card expiration date and PIN code. There is also a field for discretionary data, which might include further security information or link the card to another account.
The reader's head reads each track simultaneously as the card is passed through. No two people swipe at exactly the same speed, so electronic circuitry in the reader insures that the data is read correctly regardless. But that also makes card-number theft relatively simple. Skimming relying on such devices, which are often sold by small fly-by-night Internet companies for anywhere from $250 to $1,200, poses a growing problem for law enforcement and is costing consumers millions of dollars a year.
In a recent raid in Queens, detectives discovered a laptop computer containing 4,300 stolen card numbers that had been taken from patrons in pharmacies, shoe stores and convenience stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. 
Like many similar groups around the world, the Queens ring had equipped itself with everything to make counterfeit cards, law enforcement officials said, including legitimate blank cards that may have been stolen from American Express and MasterCard. The officials estimated that counterfeit cards using those numbers could be used to purchase roughly $13 million in goods before all of the fraud was uncovered and the cards canceled.
In most skimmer rings, the numbers are obtained by low-level operatives, often store clerks or waiters, whose jobs involve handling customers' cards. They can easily pass the cards through a small skimmer that they carry or have placed next to a cash register.
"The waiter takes your card, the waiter leaves your table, reaches in his apron, swipes your card through the skimmer, and in two seconds -- even less -- compromises all of your numbers," said Gregg James, a special agent in the financial crimes division of the Secret Service.
Criminals may not bother to conceal the skimmers from victims. "In a lot of cases they may wear them on their belt, and most people don't know what they are looking at," said Skeet Rolling, director of fraud control services for TSYS, a global payment processor based in Columbus, Ga.
Some skimmers have been more audacious, taping one of the devices to an A.T.M. with a sign asking patrons to use the "card cleaner" before all transactions. Others have concealed a skimmer inside a hollowed-out pager, also worn on the belt.
Skimmers contain a small memory chip that can usually hold 50 to 100 card numbers, and the skimmer operator usually gets a payment for each number obtained. The numbers can then be downloaded to a computer connected to a card encoder, which can record the data on the magnetic stripe of a blank card.
"Skimming is essentially the full replication of the information on the mag stripe," said Joel S. Lisker, senior vice president for security and risk management for MasterCard International.
It is nearly impossible for consumers to fend off skimmers on their own, but the card companies are working on strategies. One simple way is to require merchants to enter the three-digit card verification value that is printed on the back of a credit card but not recorded on the stripe. Credit card companies are hesitant to push for the measure because it can slow transactions and may tempt consumers to use a competitor's card instead.
Magneprint, a promising technology that is being developed by MagTek, a large manufacturer of card readers, and tested by MasterCard, essentially reads the fingerprint of a stripe's magnetic particles -- that is, the iron flecks on which the data is actually recorded. 
The distribution of those particles is random and therefore unique to every card. It cannot be replicated or altered by a thief, and it does not change as the stripe wears down with use. In this technique, a portion of that fingerprint is recorded as part of the information on the stripe and compared with the actual pattern on the stripe. If the card is a copy, the two will not match.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Encoded Engines of Commerce"Magnetic card readers have become nearly as ubiquitous as the plastic cards that carry the personal, professional and financial details of people's lives. When a card is swiped through a reader, a magnetic head inside gathers the information in the stripe. On a credit or debit card, the information includes the card-holder's name, account number and PIN code and expiration date, among other details. In a legitimate transaction, the data is transmitted by the merchant to the issuing bank for payment authorization. But the information can be vulnerable to capture and theft by criminals equipped with card readers. THE DATA TRACKSThe magnetic stripe is divided into three tracks. Every card of a given type must place the same data in the same positions so that the information can be read by machines anywhere in the world. To align properly with the sensors on the read head, the first track must be 218 thousandths of an inch from the edge of the card. WHAT THE TRACKS SAY -- Besides the name and account number, the encoded data includes information like the card's expiration date, secondary accounts to which it is linked and discretionary data like a PIN verification key. Track 3 also has an area for "use and security" details including credit limit, billing cycle and country of origin. DATA TRACK 3ACCOUNT NUMBERUSE AND SECURITY DATAADDITIONAL DATA DATA TRACK 2ACCOUNT NUMBERADDITIONAL DATADISCRETIONARY DATA DATA TRACK 1ACCOUNT NUMBERNAMEADDITIONAL DATADISCRETIONARY DATA THE CIRCUITRYThe circuit board at the heart of the reader processes the data from the three data tracks on a card swiped through the machine, formats and integrates it and transmits it through a connected computer to the issuing bank. DATA DECODER CIRCUITS -- One chip processes information from each data track, converting it from analog to digital form. MICROPROCESSOR -- Converts the serial bit stream produced by the decoder circuits to characters that the computer can interpret. SERIAL CABLE -- Draws power for the reader from a connected computer and transmits data back to it. MAGNETIC READ HEADThe information recorded on the data tracks is in analog form, much like music recorded on magnetic tape. Sensors on the head read the information and pass it to the data decoder chips on the circuit board. TRACK READ SENSORSOn the front of the read head, there is one sensor per track.(Source: MagTek) Drawings (Frank O'Connell/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Job Training Depletes Labor Pool for Garment Factories 

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
Chinatown's garment factories, already reeling from a string of setbacks, are facing an unexpected challenge: longtime garment workers are turning down factory work and instead taking paid job-training classes that they hope will lead to better-paying jobs.
 This is the garment industry's busy season, with orders coming in for next fall's fashions and temporary jobs opening up. Factories need workers, and now some of those workers -- many of them women in their 40's and older -- say that the industry's future in New York City is dim. They also say that a job training program pays them just as much for a chance to learn English and new skills as they would earn working in a factory sewing days, nights and weekends. 
 "It's not just if there's a job available now," Li Fang Yu, 44, who has worked in Chinatown's factories for a decade, said of the 13-week job training program she has begun. "I came to America for a better life."
For women like her, it is often their first chance to take English classes and vocational training while also having an income. The Sept. 11 Fund, a relief organization, makes paid training available for about a dozen weeks to about 1,500 workers who lost their jobs or income because of the terrorist attack at the World Trade Center. The fund has six organizations in the city that provides paid training in fields like hotel hospitality, truck driving and home health care. Some of these programs have attracted garment workers.
The fund is unusual in that it pays dislocated workers who qualify a weekly stipend of $300 for 25 to 35 hours of training a week for three months. The women say the stipend is about what they would earn in factories, usually working longer hours and weekends, and only when there is work to be had.
Their rationale worries the people who run factories in Chinatown and to a lesser extent those in Brooklyn and Queens. The garment industry's busy season is roughly between now and May. Some factory owners say they will not be able to fill their orders on time, thereby risking future contracts.
Chinatown's garment factories are already reeling from the export of work to overseas factories, fashion industry problems and the difficulties of manufacturing in New York City. "We're not against the training," said Paul Lau, executive director of the Sportswear Apparel Association. "It's just that right now this is a busy season."
Chau Ying Cheung, who is 45 and has worked in factories for the last nine years, said the industry's seasonality is a big problem. Mrs. Cheung is not going to stop learning English, she said, because she knows the factory jobs will not last long. 
"One month later, there's almost no work," Mrs. Cheung said. "I'm looking for a better career."
Mrs. Yu and Mrs. Cheung are actually not leaving the garment industry, just moving up. Both are enrolled in an apparel-training program that teaches people to work in the sample rooms of fashion designers like Vera Wang and Donna Karan. Hsiuhua Chiang, who has run the program -- which is now getting help from the fund -- said that she had been able to place 20 of the 25 graduates from the previous class and felt optimistic about the future. 
Factory owners desperate for workers have resorted to taking out full-page want ads in the city's Chinese newspapers with minimal results, they say. Some have also requested that job training be put off temporarily. 
Officials at the fund say they are sympathetic to the garment industry's plight but they doubt that there are enough jobs in Chinatown, even temporary ones, for the unemployed, who number in the thousands. Right now there are about 110 factories with 7,000 workers, down from 256 factories and 15,000 employees before Sept. 11, 2001. 
Chinatown's garment industry has not had an easy time recovering from the effects of Sept. 11. After the terrorist attack, orders were canceled when trucks could not get past road restrictions, and the sagging economy did not help. 
New York City does enjoy an advantage over some some other garment-making areas because it has an abundance of two kinds of people: fashion designers and immigrant women, like Jie Zhen Wen. "I haven't stopped working in 20 years in garment factories," said Mrs. Wen, who is 49. In that time, she has also raised five children, who now range from 15 to 24. She did not have the time or the means to learn English, she said.
When she began taking job training and English classes last month, she was working at the factory only on Saturdays. The busy season had not started yet. 
Now Mrs. Wen spends the week at an apparel training program run by the Chinese American Planning Council at 55 Avenue of the Americas. She used to do assembly line work at the factory, like sewing collars onto blouses. Now she is learning how to go from designing a dress to producing it in three months, while also studying English. Her goal is to get a job with a fashion house in Midtown. 
Mrs. Wen said that the garment factories had provided good work for many years but that she wanted to earn more money and move up in the world. She finally has a chance do that, she said. "You can work in the garment factories and that's all you do," Mrs. Wen said. "If I can learn English and work in an American company, it's much better."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Li Fang Yu, left, and Jie Zhen Wen are taking job training and English classes as part of a paid program at the Chinese American Planning Council. The program is paid for in part by the Sept. 11 Fund. (Alan Chin for The New York Times)
